div.p: LA PICARA, OR THE TRIUMPHS OF Female Subtilty, Diplay'd in the Artifices and Impostures of a Beautiful Woman, who Trapann'd the mot experienc'd Rogues, and made all thoe unhappy who thought her handome: Originally, A Spanih Relation, Enriched with three Pleaant NOVELS. Render'd into Englih, with ome Alterations and Additions, By JOHN DAVIES of Kidwelly.
LONDON, Printed by W. W. for John Starkey, at the Mitre within Temple-Bar. 1665.
IMPRIMATUR,

div.head: To the worthily Honoured, Sir JOHN BERKENHEAD KNIGHT, Mater of the Faculties, and Mater of the Requets to his Majety, and one of the Members of the Honourable Houe of Commons.
div.p: THe world is come to that improvement of experience, as to account Dedicatories, more certain acknowledgements of obligation than any Noverint Univeri, epecially when there is a great ditance of Quality between thoe by whom they are made, and thoe to whom they are directed. That this hould be thought uch, I am rather pleas'd, than troubled, ince, my being oblig'd, argues my being known, to you, and conequently, that, from the one, I derive a atisfaction; from the other, an advantage.

The last Piece, which came abroad under my obcure name, was The Travels of the Embay from the Duke of Holtein, into Mucovy, and Peria. The excellent Peron who was the original Author of it, Olearius, oblig'd, with us, most of the Neighbouring Nations, who alo rendred his work into their everal Languages. I am told it was not unkindly receiv'd here; onely the occaion I have to peak of it now, is, that the coming forth of the Englih Tranlation, with greater lutre, than haply it had done otherwie, is, among thoe of ome others, due to your encouragement.

But I am not to date your notice of me from that; I must decend much lower, to a Time wherein you thought it dangerous to know, or be known to, many. Be not tartled; when dangers are over, there remains onely a pleaing remembrance of them. It was, long before the Committee at Derby-Houe, was advanc'd into a Councel of State, an Age ince, conidering the ubequent reign of Tyranny and Barbarim, and the perpetual alarms and frights, whereto worry'd Loyalty was every where expos'd. Thee you have happily weather'd out, and een the contrivers thereof at last overtaken by the low pace of divine Vengeance, an advertiement to All Chritians
and Lay-Elders, who either gratulate or envy you the favours of a Prince, for whom you would have run yet greater hazards.

As to the Piece I now preent you with, I have onely this to ay. It is a Spanih Relation, written by D. Alono de Catillo Savorano, a famous Author of that Nation. One of the most refin'd Wits of France thought it worth his pains, to render it into the Language of his Country, with all the graces and advantages it might derive from either. I have done it out of the latter, with a freedome of alteration and addition, as my fancy led me, to make it the most divertive I could in ours, which is the onely recommendation of all things of this nature. My Author promies his Readers a continuation of the Story, if what is already publih'd be kindly entertain'd: I do mine, the like, upon the ame precaution; but with this particular inducement, That it will give me further occaion to aure the world how much I am,

closer.signed: Your mot humble, and very much obliged Servant, J. DAVIES.

div.head: LA PICARA, OR The Triumphs of Female Subtilty.
The Firt Book.
div.p:
THERE is a Treatie in the Spanih Tongue, entituled IL PICARO, which being rendred into Englih, under the Title of THE ROGUE, or, The Life of Guzman de Alfarache, the humour took o well in this Nation, that He and his Rogueries were everal times committed to the Pres. The Deign of that Work was to repreent a Peron, on whom either Nature, or a trange acendency of Mercury had betowed o liberal a Talent of cheating, thieving, and circumvention, that he not onely trapan'd all he dealt with, but alo became a Precedent and Pattern to all thoe, who, out of neceity, or inclination, have been forc'd to live by
their hifts, or, as ome would have it, by their wits. The preent Tract hath ome reemblance to the excellent Piece before mentioned, inamuch as it brings in a Woman, engag'd in as great deigns as thoe of her Predeceor Guzman, but with this diadvantage, that the weaknes of her Sex obliges her to make ue of the aitances of Men for the better proecution thereof. Both Treaties were originally written in the Spanih, a Language we are oblig'd to for mot pieces of this nature: and as, in the former, the Relation is pleaantly interrupted by certain merry tales and tories; o in ours, there is an intermixture of Novels, to heighten the Reader's atisfaction and divertiement.

The draught I am to give of this Miracle of Female ubtilty may be of very great advantage to three orts of perons. Thoe who feel in themelves a certain dipoition to be wicked, may be admonih'd, and reform, before they have occaion to repent; they, who, defying all advertiement, are reolv'd to be michievous, may, out of an apprehenion of the enuing punihment, be deterr'd into caution; and the innocent and vertuous may learn a leon of prudence and circumpection, to avoid thoe nares that are laid for them. The things I write are not uppoititious, or fram'd in my own imagination, but uch as really happened in one of the mot eminent Cities of Spain; which yet if any man have not faith enough to believe, I have no other advice to give him, but that he would travel to thoe places, where our Scene lies, to diprove me.

As to her Peron, She was young, prightly, and very beautiful; three dangerous advantages, when
they are attended by thoe endowments for which he was no les famous, to wit, Craft, Impudence, Hypocriie, and an inatiable longing for the goods of other people; and all thee trengthned by a bent of nature, as being the iue of Parents, who, intead of giving a timely check to thee vicious inclinations, rather incourag'd her in them by their example, as being addicted to the ame themelves.

Seignor Trapaa, Father to this excellent peron whoe atchievments we intend to decribe, had been condemn'd to the Galleys, for having aum'd to himelf the Order of the Knighthood of Chrit, before he had made the neceary trials, upon which his Majety betows that honour, by the judgment of his Soveraign Council of Portugal. His deign in doing it, was that he might more conveniently follow his profeion of tealing about the Court, where he was repected as a Knight, and the better, under that cloak, to play thoe pranks of villany, wherein he was uch a Profeor, that the mot expert might have heard his Lectures. A certain Woman, whom he us'd to trade withall, incens'd againt him upon the account of ome jealouie, that he reerv'd not all his kindnes for her, put in a charge againt him, the iue whereof was, That he got the aid preferment in the Galleys; where he pas'd over the term of his condemnation, and omewhat more. He was dipos'd into that Squadron, which is called the Squadron of Spain, and tranlated from Toledo to S. Mary's Port, with the ret who were in the ame Predicament of Slavery. He had made an attempt to recover his liberty, but the plot being dicover'd, he was put to greater hardhip than he had otherwie been.

As oon as the Lady Etephania (o was called the jealous Woman, who had hewn him that trick) undertood that he was gone to exercie that painful employment, though he were not of an over-compaionate nature, very eriouly repented her, that he had been the caue of his miery, and conider'd that he could not make a better atisfaction for that injury, than by proffering her elf to him in marriage as oon as the time of his penance were expir'd. What inclin'd her the more to this kind of reparation, was, that he had already had a Daughter by him, which Daughter is the ubject of the preent Treatie. With this reolution, he left the Court, and went to Sevil, hoping, in that great and famous City, he might the ooner hear ome news of him, whom he had reduc'd to o great miery, and whom he would gladly once more ee at liberty.

Etephania had a houe very well furnih'd, being a Genoee's Widow, who had left her very well to pas. That, and the care he took to go omewhat high in cloaths, gain'd her uch a repute at Madrid, that he was look'd on as a peron of ome quality: but he oon lot that, when the hitory of her life came to be known, epecially this particular of it, that, out of an exces of jealouie, he had preferr'd to the Galleys a young Gallant, whom he had often entertain'd in a feather-bed. That imprudent ally made her abhominable in the ight of her mot intimate acquaintances of her own ex, whoe indignation he allow'd to be the more jut againt her, when he conider'd, that he had cat away her elf on an impotor and a racal fit onely for the Galleys.

Thee reaons and reproaches oblig'd her to remove
from Madrid to Sevil, taking all he could conveniently carry along with her, and elling the ret, which brought her in a coniderable umme of mony. Having thus order'd her affairs, he went towards Sevil by Coach, with two Maids to wait on on her, intending to continue there, till the time of Trapaa's erving in the Galleys were expir'd; which being near out, (for he kept an exact account of it) he undertood that the Spanih Galleys were arrived at S. Mary's Port. She immediately went thither, not o highly clad as he was wont to go at Sevil, but in a more modet habit, that it might not be afterwards cat into her dih, that he had been the wife of a Galley-lave, and withal one he had courted out of his chains into her embraces.

She immediately undertood that her Gallant was in the Captain's own Galley, very jocund, and advanced to the office of a Fore-man, a preeminence among the Slaves which exempts them from rowing, and he had acquir'd it of the General by the pleaantnes of his converation; nay, had he not had that charge, he was by this time grown o well acquainted with the Galleys, that he minded not much whether ever he got out of them. But the arrival of Etephania remedi'd all. Her firt buines was to treat about his liberty, peaking to thoe perons on whom the buines depended, and preenting them with certain umms of mony, before Trapaa had any knowledge of her deign, whom he could not have een, as having not yet tirr'd out of the Galley. So that he was extremely atonih'd, when he came to undertand, that ome perons did not onely ue bare olicitations in order to his liberty, but were
alo liberal of their mony to procure it, yet could it never come into his thoughts, that his old Love Etephania hould have chang'd the cruel humour, he had left her in, into one o mild and obliging.

All things being concluded and agreed upon for Trapaa's liberty, his chains were knock'd off, and he was told, that he might go whether he would. In the mean time he could not imagine who had procur'd him that happines, which was no mall one, inamuch as though the poor Slaves have erv'd out the time of their condemnation, yet are there ome caues found that hinder their being et at liberty, nay ome are o unhappy, that having been condemn'd for four years, are forc'd to tay there five, or ix.

Seignor Trapaa was extremely atonih'd, when he found himelf in the preence of his Etephania, and undertood, that it was onely by her means he had recover'd his liberty; he receiv'd him into her arms, and he, to expres his gratitude, return'd o obliging a reception with the like carees; o that the kindnes he then receiv'd of her, made him forget the reentment he might have of the mieries he had occaion'd him. He was troubled to find her in a much different habit from that he had left her in at Madrid, for he knew not that it was out of deign he had o diguis'd her elf, nor could he at that time give him an account of it, by reaon of the Captain and others being preent, who had conducted him, and whom he was oblig'd to entertain at dinner. Having treated them as well as he could, all withdrew, ave onely Trapaa, who continu'd till in the Inne with his Mitres. Finding themelves alone, they reiterated their carees, and outvy'd one the
other in aurances of the atisfaction they conceiv'd at that interview. Trapaa render'd her his thanks with all the grateful acknowledgments imaginable, for the pains he had taken, and the goodnes he had had to deliver him out of the cruel torments he endured. On the other ide, Etephania begg'd his pardon for the michief he had done him, and all the mieries her malice had caus'd him, telling him withall, that he could not imagine any other way to repair the injury he had done him, than by joyning hands with him in matrimony, if he lik'd the propoal, ince he already had a daughter by him, and wealth enough for both of them to live at their eae.

I leave you to judge whether this motion were not pleaing to Trapaa, one that would have napp'd at the leat proffer of good fortune, upon his coming out of o evere a School of penance. As if he had forgot the former, his Anwer was in renew'd embraces, thereby atisfying her with what joy he accepted of the advantageous offer he made him, entreating her to give him an account of his Daughter, whom he was paionately deirous to ee.

Etephania over-joy'd to find his entiments o cononant to her expectation, preented him with a noble riding-uit, which he had purpoely caus'd to be made for him, and the next morning betimes they took their journey towards Sevil, where Trapaa finding his Daughter (who might then be about eight years of age) he acted a part he never had done before, that is, was olemnly married to the Lady Etephania, in facie Eccleiae. They chang'd their lodgings, and indeed the quarter of the City where
they had liv'd, being reolv'd to lead another kind of life than they had done before. For Etephania imagining, that the hardhip which her dear Love had endur'd in the Galleys, had abated omewhat of his former extravagancies, and that the grey hairs he had brought thence would reclaim him from his debauches, endeavour'd to get him ome creditable employment in Sevil, as well to keep him out of idlenes, as out of a conideration that he hould bring in omething towards the houe. But an untoward dipoition, uch as was that of Trapaa, is not o eaily brought into dicipline, and if he had as yet behav'd himelf with ome reerv'dnes, it proceeded from the influence, which the perpetual admonitions and rebukes of his wife had over him, and not out of any bent to vertue in his nature; o that, through his own neglect, he could find himelf no other employment, than that of frequenting Gaming-houes, and Plays, and thoe other places, where thoe, who are naturally inclin'd to loth, think fit to pend the greatet part of their time. This carriage of his extremely troubled his wife, who yet willing to avoid all matrimonial dicontents, wink'd at his diorders, and endeavour'd to find ome comfort in the converation of her Daughter, whoe beauty was already become the common dicoure of the City.

Idlenes, the eminary of all orts of vices, by degrees brought Trapaa into his former cutom of Gaming (the Sea wherein o many Etates are wrack'd) o that beginning at firt to play for little (as if it had been rather for Recreation than otherwie) but afterwards venturing more and more, he in a hort time made a hift to lavander whatever he
could lay hands on of his wife's. She was enible enough, that many of her things were wanting, and doubted not but her Husband was the conveyer of them; but all he could do was to weep, and bemoan her elf, charging none with her misfortune, but her elf. Trapaa perceiving her o much troubled, promied reformation; but the damn'd lechery of Gaming prevailing more and more upon him, his luck was uch, that in four years he either old or pawn'd whatever was worth it in his houe. Finding himelf at lat reduc'd to very great neceities, he began to cat about how he might recover himelf a little: he would have been content his wife (who was as yet handome enough) hould have condecended to lewdnees unworthy her recover'd reputation, but he perceiv'd he was grown o honet, and o alter'd from what he had been before, that he had not the confidence to peak to her of any uch thing. For he was o extremely troubled at the diorder'd demeanour of her husband, that he grew in a manner careles of all things; nay he little minded the education of her daughter, who was by this time come into the—teens, and, by reaon of thee ditractions in the family, liv'd as he pleas'd her elf, appearing every day at her window, and that not with little affectation.

The grief and regrets which poor Estephania conceiv'd at her being reduc'd to neceity, heightned by the dicontent caus'd her by her husband, brought her into a icknes, whereof he died about a year after, with a perfect repentance for her pat mi-carriages, reinforcing at that extremity all her pirits, that he might die as happy a death, as her husband
had occaion'd her living an unhappy life. She was very poorly buried, Trapaa having not the means to betow any more cot upon her than he did. He was in his turn troubled, at her death, and acknowledg'd, but too late, his great overight in that he had o long continu'd his debauches, and that if he had follow'd her good advice, he might have liv'd handomely all the ret of his days. All the comfort he had now left, and all the hope on which he grounded his happines, was the beauty of his Daughter, which he thought uch, as would bring him a Son-in-law, that might relieve his neceities; never conidering that the vertue of the Age conits in wealth, and that all perfections and graces have no charm in them, if depriv'd of the attractions of riches.

The unfortunate Trapaa, as cruh'd as he was with mieries, continu'd till a contant frequenter of the Gaming-houes, not indeed to play himelf, for he had not wherewith, but to receive what he had ometimes given, to wit, the Barats, a little preent the Spaniards are wont to betow on thoe, who look on them while they are playing, when they have had a good hand, and this is commonly the uret revenue of thoe who have ruin'd themelves by Gaming.

The little aboad which Trapaa made at his own houe gave his daughter the greater freedom to follow her own inclinations. She would be perpetually at the window, which induc'd abundance of young Gallantillos to make their appearances in the treet he liv'd in. The Father, who was not ignorant of what pas'd, though he might have prevented, yet wink'd at it, out of the deire he had to ee his daughter advantageouly match'd, that he might afterwards help
him out of his neceities. This indeed was the mot likely means he had to recover himelf. He thereupon left the little Rufina (o was his daughter called) to her own liberty, hoping, that, by her ininuations, he would in time have the dipoal of their hearts and pures who courted her. His deign prov'd more fortunate than he had imagin'd, inamuch as among the many, who languih'd for her, there hapned to be one very rich, who was over head and ears in love with Rufina. She aum'd the title of Donna, a title belongs onely to women of noble extraction, becaue her Mother had taken it before her, which if he had not, her Daughter would not have balk'd it, as being an honour which cots little or nothing.

The peron who was o remarkably her Suitor had the Agency of ome affairs of Peru, one whoe credit much exceeded his etate, was accounted very rich in the enuring Office belonging to the Indies, and about fifty years of age. Though he knew well enough that his Mitres had no fortune, and that he mut withall be charg'd with the ruin'd peron her Father, yet was he reolv'd to take her, for better, for wore; whence may be deduc'd this obervation, That when Love becomes Mater of an aged peron, it is a very hard matter to dipoes him. Laurentio de Saravia (o was this amorous Elder called) was o beotted with the beauties of Rufina, that the Treaty of Marriage was concluded in les than eight daies, and he had the earnet of a happines, which he thought would have lated as long as he liv'd. He took his Father-in-law into his houe, though he knew him to be a great Gameter. The firt days of the Nuptials were pent as they are wont to be in uch Solemnities; he gave
his wife new cloaths, rings, and jewels, yet uitably to her condition; for being a peron pretty well tricken in years, he was no lover of exces, an humour which pleas'd not Rufina, who minded nothing o much as gaudy cloaths, and long'd for whatever he aw worn by women of a quality much above hers; and this abated not a little of the love he bore her husband, who was of an Indian dipoition, covetous, and careful to preerve his etate. Knowing, as I told you, that his Father was a great Gameter, and a peron run out of all he had, he truted not his wife with the keeping of his Cah, no not with the management of what was pent in the houe; which quite defeated the hopes of Trapaa, who imagin'd, that, upon the marriage or his daughter, he hould command what were in her power; o trangely was he poet with the retles pirit of gaming.

Rufina, perceiving her husband was taken up with his affairs, took occaion to go abroad every morning, upon pretence of a certain devotion he had undertaken, that it might pleae God to make her a Mother. With this excue he blinded her husband, but the true motive of her allies, was to hew her elf in the Streets and at Church. The firt of thoe who upon ight of her, fell in love with her, was a Citizen's on of Sevil, one of the mot debauch'd young men of his time, one, to ay all of him in a word, who had brought himelf almot to the ame condition as Trapaa: he was decended of vertuous Parents, but his diorders had drown'd their good reputation. His name was Ruperio, a Spark of a goodly preence, and one who prov'd o fortunate in the courting of Rufina, that he was wholly at his devotion, hoping to
receive uch great preents from him, as might put her into cloaths utable to her beauty, which was more than he could have expected from the Mier her husband.

The firt demand he made to him, was very modet, conidering it came from a Merchant's wife, to wit, that he would betow on her a Gown of the ame Stuff and Fahion as a Neighbour of hers had, whom he named, and withall a gold-watch to hang by her ide, promiing him in requital of that favour that he would not deny him any that lay in her power. Ruperio, who by his inolent boatings had raied her into a peruaion of his being a peron that had thouands at his command, promis'd to do what he deir'd; but being not able to perform, he et his wits to hew that trick, which his pure could not. He happened to be well acquainted with her whoe Gown was to be his pattern, he went to her, and intreated her to lend it him, pretending it was onely for the repreentation of a Comedy, which was to be acted in a Nunnery. It could not be deni'd on uch an account; o that at the end of three days, which time he told Rufina that it would be making, he ent it to her houe, while her husband was abroad in the City about his buines. The Watch he told her was not yet finih'd, but that as oon as it were, it hould be brought her, intreating her in the mean time to accept of another of leer value, as a hotage for the appearance of the other. She return'd him her hearty thanks, was extremely pleas'd to ee that he had been o punctual, and to hew her elf grateful, he gave him all the atisfaction he could expect from her.

He took leave of Rufina, who reolv'd to peruade
her husband, that a certain Kinman of hers had ent her that Gown from Madrid, that o he might not be jealous of her. On the other ide, Ruperio was contriving how to get it return'd to her, of whom it had been borrowed. Saravia not knowing him, he effected his buines by this cheat. About three or four days after the delivery of the Gown to Rufina, he puts himelf into the habit of a Servingman, and jut at dinner time comes to Saravia's houe, aying that he was Servant to the Lady to whom that Gown belonged. Saravia order'd him to be brought in, which being done he told him that he was ent by his Mitres for the Gown he had lent Madam Rufina, onely to ee the fahion of it. Saravia turning towards his wife, ask'd her what Gown the fellow would have? She preently knowing her Gallant, Friend, aid he to him, come hither to morrow morning, and you hall have it. But my Mitres, replies Ruperio, hath commanded me not to come back without it; for this afternoon he is to go a Chritning, at which he is Godmother, and he mut needs have it. How hall I know, replies Rufina, that you have any relation to that Lady, and that you now come from her? The crafty Companion perceiving what he would be at, and that he had no mind to return it, The Gown, aid he, is of uch a colour, the Trimming uch and uch, and it was ent you in a green cloth, done about with a ilk fringe. Saravia hearing him give uch particular marks, Sweet-heart, aid he to his wife, you have nothing to reply, for ince he demands it with o much earnetnes, it mut needs be his Mitres tands in need of it, and if you are
unwilling to rie out of your place, give me the key of your Trunk where it is, and I will go and fetch it. Rufina upon this had not a word to ay, and at lat ready to burt with indignation, he roe from the Table, took the Gown out of the Trunk, and delivering it to Ruperio, Preent my humble ervice, aid he, to Madam Leonora, and tell her, I beg her pardon, that I ent it not home ooner, which I could not, in regard he hath not been here ince who borrow'd it for me to have another made by it.

The diguis'd Gallant receiv'd the Gown, and left Rufina, her eyes all on fire, and vext to the oul, to find her elf o impudently affronted. Saravia ask'd her upon what account he had borrow'd that Gown; he made anwer, That he had done it at the intreaty of an acquaintance of hers, who was deirous to have uch another, as being extremely taken with the fahion of it. She peruaded her husband to any thing, who, poor man, undertood little of the world beides his trading. In the mean time, he was extremely incens'd againt Ruperio for the lovenly trick he had put upon her, in depriving her of a garment he was much taken with, and whereof he thought her elf indiputably poes'd. She thereupon reolv'd to be reveng'd on him, what ever it cot her; but thinking to communicate her deign to her Maid, who was privy to all her ecret deigns, Trapaa, who over-heard them, came to know the whole tory; and being acquainted with the Gallant, as being one who hanted the Gaming-houes, and conceiving himelf oblig'd to revenge the affront done his daughter, he meets him in the treet one
day, and tells him, he deir'd to meaure the length of his Sword, upon what account he hould know, when they were come to the place. Ruperio follow'd him out of the City, and being out of Peoples ight, Trapaa told him what had occaion'd his giving him that challenge. They preently drew, and made everal paes, but at lat Trapaa prov'd the more unfortunate, for he was run through the heart, o that he died immediately, having not the time to make the leat act of contrition; a judgement commonly happens to thoe who lead uch Lives as he had done. Ruperio took Sanctuary, and Trapaa's Body was brought to his Son-in-law's, where it was receiv'd, with a mixture of joy and grief; joy, that the Houe was disburthen'd of one of the mot humourome and inupportable perons in the world; and grief for the future charges of his enterrment.

In the mean time, Rufina made it appear by her lamentations and tears, that his death caus'd her as much affliction as it brought her husband joy. She would not hear of any conolation, pretending he had lot all her upport in this world, for all the kinred and friends he had were now exchang'd for a husband, whom he could not affect. On the other ide Saravia thought himelf the happiet man in the world, to have a wife handome and young as his was. But he was indeed a little too handome and too young for him; that proportion of Age, which Parents ought chiefly to mind in the dipoal of their Children, was not oberv'd in this. 'Tis not to be expected an old Man can pleae a young Girl. When a woman comes once to light her huband,
he is in the way to fancy any body. But for Rufina, the paion he had withall of going highly in cloaths, and to be reveng'd of Ruperio, made her break forth into all the excees, that exaperated Woman-kind can fall into, defile the Marriage-bed, and implicitely give her elf over to all thoe things, whence he might derive either atisfaction or advantage. Nothing ran o much in her head as the injury he had receiv'd from Ruperio, which he thought uch, that he would not have Liv'd, but out of a hope to be reveng'd of him. But in regard he mut have other hands than her own to do that, he ought out all opportunities imaginable to aure her elf of a Gallant, who would vigorouly execute her commands.

One of thoe Fridays, which are olemnized with a great concoure of people from Eater to Whituntide, in Triana part of the Suburbs of Sevil, through which paes the Quadalquivir, the famous River of Andaluia, and the Looking-glas of that wealthy City; Rufina went into a Boat cover'd with branches, to go and ee that Fetival, to which he was carried, by the expres order of her husband, by a Neighbour of his, whom he thought one of the mot dicreet and virtuous Women in the world. But he was not the firt Man that was deceiv'd in a Woman; for, on the contrary, he was one of the wantonet and withall the implet of the whole Sex. She therefore took up a Boat for her elf, Rufina, and two other Women of their acquaintance; but though he had given the Water-man his full fare; yet was he eaily perwaded by him to take in other perons into the Boat, and among thoe, a
young Man, who had his Sentinels at the Water-ide to give him notice of uch an opportunity. As oon as they were got into the Boat, Rufina unveil'd, and the Gallant (whom we will call Felician) had no ooner een, but he was urpriz'd with her Beauty. He thought her o handome, that he peruaded ome of his friends, who tood on the River-ide, to come into the Boat, and to effect that, greas'd the fit of the Water-man. Being all got in, Felician took his place next to Rufina, into whoe favour it was his deign to ininuate himelf. He was Son to a peron of Quality, who had rais'd himelf to a vat fortune in the Indies, and had no Children but only this, who dipoing of his wealth, as he pleas'd, it was conceiv'd it would not be long ere he catter'd abroad what his Father had not in o hort a time raked together. For he was a contant Gameter, a perpetual Courter of Ladies, and he maintain'd a coniderable crew of Hangers-on, who did him no other ervice than accompany, and encourage him in his debauches. Beides thee noble qualities, he was extreamly extravagant in point of cloaths, a vice not extraordinary in thoe young men of Sevil, who have all things at their own dipoal, as he we peak of had.

Having, as was aid, eated himelf next to Rufina, and his Camerades next to her friends, the Boat put off, and went very leiurely down the River, for which the Water-man was o much the better paid. Felician thought this time o precious that he lot very little of it; he dicover'd his Love to Rufina in uch obliging expreions, that he gave abolute credit to his words, and, by her attention, atisfy'd him, that he was not dipleas'd with his company.
Felician was a very ingenious peron, and of an excellent good humour, upon uch occaions as thoe; he deliver'd himelf with uch a martnes and grace, that the Ladies were extreamly well atisfy'd, epecially Rufina, who thought nothing comparable to his converation. She gave him her name, told him where he liv'd, and what profeion her husband was of, and in a word made him a kind of Confeion of her more ecret affairs. Felician was as open to her, concluding his dicoure with a thouand protetations of ervice and obedience. The afternoon was pent in complements and courthip, and to the great atisfaction of Rufina, who had two deigns to carry on at the ame time; one, to be reveng'd of Ruperio, by the aitance of Felician; the other, to cajol the latter out of omewhat towards cloaths and her extravagant expences. Nor did the buines happen otherwie than he had deign'd it.

From that day Felician began to frequent the treet where Rufina liv'd, epecially when he had intelligence that her husband was abroad about his affairs. Rufina, on the other ide, reolv'd not to be over-eaily conquer'd; for when he remembred how he had been erv'd by Ruperio, it rais'd in her a certain fear of receiving the like affront from another. Before he admitted his entrance into the Houe, he thought fit to make trial of his liberality. Of this he was in a hort time pretty well atisfy'd, for Felician had been a prodigal all his Life, but upon this occaion exceeded all he had done before, ending her preents of cloaths, jewels, and other things, beides the expences he was at in treatments and
collations: So that Rúfina was the mot atisfy'd Woman in the world. 'Tis commonly aid, that the higher a Man's enjoyments are, the ooner he is cloy'd, but it happen'd otherwie with Felician, for his affection to Rufina encreas'd daily, and came up to that height it could not well be greater.

It happen'd about this time, that Ruperio got at one time above ix hundred Crowns at play. He went always very high in cloaths; but this unexpected good fortune made him omewhat exceed his former gawdines. But with that good, he had this ill fortune, to find out, that Felician was een very often in the treet where Rufina liv'd, and to infer thence, that he made ome addrees to her. This jealouie awoke the love he had ometimes had for her; it troubled him that he hould have any Rival, and thereupon he reolv'd to retrive himelf into her favour, and repair the injury, he was now enible, that he had done her. Upon this account, he pas'd everal times through her treet, which caus'd not a little perplexity to Felician. Rufina was enrag'd to ee that the Impotor had the impudence to make any pretence to her favour, after the notorious affront he had receiv'd at his hands. She conider'd there was no way to be rid of his importunities, but to engage her beloved Gallant Felician in her quarrel, by peruading him, that Ruperio's deign was to diplace him out of her affection, which if he valued, he would find ome means to check the inolence of his Rival, and deliver her from his odious Courthip. See what employments Women do many times put on their Gallants! etting them on, like Cocks, to fight, till they have detroy'd one the other.

Rufina thought it not prudence to acquaint Felician with what had pas'd between her and Ruperio. No, he took a afer coure: She told him, that Ruperio was continually importuning her with very advantageous proffers, which yet, for his ake, he lighted. Felician believ'd her, and that the rather, in regard he met him every day, and many times in the night, walking the rounds about his Mitres's houe. To incene him the more, he added, that were it not for that troubleome peron, he would ee him oftner than he did. There needed no more; Felician being thus enflam'd into jealouie, met with Ruperio one night in his Mitres's treet, when he knew Rufina was a-bed, and her husband looking over ome Accounts, which concern'd his Agency. As oon as Felician had perceiv'd Ruperio, he call'd him by his name, and having talk'd a little while together, to avoid the dicovery of any quarrel in the Streets, he conducted to a little byplace, which happen'd to be over againt the room where Saravia kept all his papers, and where he then was, very buie looking over them. The two Rivals being come to the place, Felician addres'd himelf thus to the other.

p.q:
Signor Ruperio, I have for ome days pat oberv'd, that you have frequented this treet more than you hould have done, and I was omewhat at a los to know, what might occaion your coming hither, in regard there are everal Ladies of worth, which might oblige you thereto. But I have at lat dicover'd, that Madam Rufina is the caue of your diurnal and nocturnal haunts hereabouts; and this I am aur'd of, not only by what
I have een my elf, but alo by the relation of her ervants, to whom you peak, and whom you would corrupt by preents to introduce you into their Mitres's favour. I have been her Servant a good while, and the ervices I have done her have gain'd me her affection, o far that I have receiv'd the greatet favours from her that I could expect. I am not a peron much given to boat of my good fortunes; but to prevent your further progres in this affair, I am forc'd to make you this particular dicovery, which I doubt not but you will entertain as a great ecret, as every peron of honour ought to do. I have acquainted you with my love, and the advantages I have made of it, to oblige you to forbear all applications to this Lady for the future. Which if you do, you will exempt your elf from many inconveniences, and eae me of thoe reentments, which I am now full of.

div.p: Ruperio hearkned very attentively to the dicoure of Felician, and Rufina's husband no les, hearing things that concern'd him o nearly. And yet though the tory he had heard was extreamly prejudicial to him, and could not but add very much to his diquiet, yet mut he needs tay to take Ruperio's Anwer; which was to this effect.

p.q:
Signor Felician, I cannot wonder at all, that you hould be o careful to oberve, with what devotion I courted Madam Rufina, ince you were o much concern'd in it as you tell me; and I believe you will be as little urpriz'd at my being engag'd in the ame deign, being, as I find you, ignorant what are the grounds of my Love, and the reaons I have to proecute it. I am as backward
as your elf to proclaim the favours I receive from Ladies; but ince you expres your elf o freely to me, I conceive my elf oblig'd to do the like to you, that you may think my procedure the les trange. I was in this Lady's favour before you were, and I obtain'd of her the ame thing you boat o much of: by ome misfortune or other, I have lot it, yet not o, as but that I hope, in time, I re-intate my elf into it again, which to do, aure your elf I hall do whatever lies in my power. If I prevail, and that he will admit the continuance of my ervices, as I hope he may, your onely remedy is patience; for I am o far from quitting this pretenion, that I hall do my utmot to prevent her giving any entertainment to yours, and bring her to uch a pas, as not o much as remember, that you ever thought of her.

div.p: With that they both drew, Felician maintaining, that he onely ought to pretend to her, and Ruperio tanding upon the ame tearms. The dipute was oon ended, his Sword, who was in preent poeion prov'd the more fortunate, Ruperio, by a thrut through the heart, falling upon the place. The noie of the Swords was not very great, for Felician had done his work o uddenly, that none heard any thing of the quarrel, but onely Saravia, who, for his own reputation, would have kept it ecret. That the Body might not lye in that place, Felician took it on his Shoulders, and laid it before a Monatery, and went for refuge into another, till he found what would be done in the buines.

Saravia, atonih'd at what he had een and heard, began to be enrag'd againt his wife, contriving how
to be reveng'd of a Woman, whoe perfidiounes was the more notorious, the greater reaons he had to be grateul and loyal. She was fat aleep in her bed, never dreaming what had hapned in the treets upon her account. The firt thing came into Saravia's imagination, was altogether for revenge, to effect which his coure would be, to go up treight into her chamber, and to dipatch her, in bed, with a dagger. But he conider'd with himelf, that the Murtherer having carried away the dead body from his door, he might be charg'd with killing her without any caue, and that he would want proof, as having for witnes but two ervant-maids, who were more likely to depoe againt him. He therefore reolv'd, as the uret way to dipatch her, to give her a ecret doe of poion, uch as might remove her after a certain time: but he thought withal, that he hould not atisfie his own jut reentment, if he any longer delay'd a vengeance which requir'd immediate execution. He propos'd to himelf another expedient, which was, to leave both City and Wife, and to go to ome other place: but that deign was oon over with him, he having many affairs undetermin'd, and fearing the initer judgments might have been pas'd upon uch a reolution, to the hame and confuion of a man of his age and reputation. This reflection brought him to his firt deign of ending her going with the ponyard. But before he executed that cruelty (which yet rightly taken was not any, but a jut punihment for her offence) he thought it requiite, or his own vindication, to leave, in writing, the reaons, which had induc'd him to commit that murther. He took pen and ink, and began to et down the affront
he had receiv'd from his wife, and the revenge he had taken: but upon econd thoughts, and imagining he had not ufficiently expres'd the heinounes of her crime, he tore what he had written; and this he did to the third time, o great were the confuion and diturbance of his thoughts. He et himelf down to write the fourth time; but remembring that he was to begin his revenge with adulteries, and could not do it becaue he knew not the everal appellations thereof, he was at lat atisfi'd, that he hould be ufficiently reveng'd if he had but once dipatch'd his wife. A good part of the night lipp'd away in thee diquiets, viz. in writing, correcting, blotting out again, and tearing all he had written. At lat, being abolutely reolv'd in that rage to execute his deign, he made another writing, without any blot, having before-hand well conider'd what he hould et down; and when he had expres'd, the bet he could, the injury he had receiv'd, he was o're-come by o preing a grief that he fell down and dy'd uddenly.

All this pat, while Rufina flept. Awaking of a udden and not finding her husband in bed with her, he call'd him, and eeing he made no Anwer, he put on her petticoat, and went into his cloet, where he found a candle lighted, and Saravia lying on the floor, dead. She was atonih'd, as well he might; all he could do was to call up her Maids, who immediately came to the ight of this trange pectacle. They were no les urpriz'd than their Mitres at the trangenes of the accident. As they were going to convey the Corps to one of the bet rooms in the houe (before the neighbours had any notice of the
adventure) Rufina met with a paper, which eem'd to be not quite finih'd, wherein he found thee words.

That my jutification may be the better known to all thoe who hall read this paper, I declare, that all my unhappines proceeds from the lightnes and incontancy of my infamous wife, who, profaning the holy Sacrament of Marriage, by the acred Tie whereof we were join'd together in the face of the Church, without any conideration of the great affection I bore her, hath protituted her elf to two Gallants at the ame time, whe having quarrel'd for the precedence, which either of them pretended to over his adverary, the more unfortunate of the two was kill'd by the other, before the window of my houe. Having thus been witnes o my own digrace, and heard the whole tory of my dihonour, it was but jut I hould revenge my infamy, thus—Then ended the writing, for death urpriing him at that word he immediately expir'd.

Rufina was extremely ditracted at both what he aw and what he had read, o that, for half an hour, he knew not in a manner where he was, conidering with her elf, that the greatet ecrets in the world will be dicover'd at lat, and that it is Heaven's pleaure they hould be o, either for our reformation or our punihment. The death of her husband rais'd in her a certain mixture of fear and affliction: a fear, to ee how udden it had been, occaion'd by the reentment of an injury which he had done him; the affliction, to ee her husband deprived of life, and her elf ignorant how to diguie o unhappy
an accident. A little remore of concience, like a qualm over her tomach, troubled her, that he had been o perfidious to a man, who had lov'd her o well, and, by marrying her, had rais'd her from beggery to plenty. The great affection which the Neighbours knew that he had always born her, gave her a little confidence, and induc'd her to take the advice of one of her Maids, which was to carry her husband's body into his bed, and to cry out the next morning o loud, that the Neighbours might here it, whom he might, by her exceive lamentations, peruade, that he had found him dead by her ide when he awoke; and that her two Maids, to carry on the cheat, hould give out that their Mater had taken a urfeit, and died uddenly of it.

Having thus laid their deign, day came, Rufina cried out, and lamented with all her might, and the next Neighbours came in, who found her halfdres'd, weeping, and tearing her hair through madnes, that he had lot o good a husband. Her two Maids acted their parts very well, by relating the caue of their good Mater's death, and aying, that they advis'd him not to eat o much, or that otherwie he mut expect to repent it. All were atisfi'd with thee reaons, and ome of Rufina's friends were buie about her, out of a fear he hould have wounded, o well did he peronate the afflicted Lady. They did all lay in their power to comfort her, who, amidt all her grief, had not forgotten to burn the paper he had found, let it might have prov'd a tetimony of her micarriages. Some Officers from the Magitrate, who are never wanting upon uch occaions, came in oon after, and upon the allegations
of the Neighbours, that the deceas'd had ever liv'd very lovingly with his wife, went their ways, atisfi'd that he had not any way contributed to his death. Saravia was buried, and Rufina was o put to it to act the part he was then engag'd in, that he thought not of doing what Widows commonly do upon uch occaions, that is, to make the bet proviion they can for themelves, out of what their husbands have left. So that one of his Nephews, as oon as the Uncle was buried, eiz'd on all in the houe, and Rufina was forc'd to go to Law with him, to recover what he might lawfully lay claim to.

Let us return to ee what became of Ruperio's body. Being found in the morning by the religious Inhabitants of the Monatery, and not known by any of them, they were going, without ans ceremonie, to burie it, had they not been prevented by a Citizen, who advis'd them to expoe it in ome publick place, that it might be known, and that if he were one that had father or mother, or friends in the City, that they might know the misfortune happen'd to him; that by that means, they would ecure to themelves the charges of his interment, as alo the fees due for other prayers and devotions, in order to the repoe of his oul. This advice pleas'd the Superiour of the Monatery, who immediately ent word to the Magitrate, that they had found in the morning a young man dead at their Chutchdoor. The body was dipos'd into a little place near the Monatery, with two lighted wax-candles, by which place there pas'd by not long after a man that knew him. He told them who he was, and then went and carried that ad news to his Friends, who were
extremely troubled at his death, his Father having often foretold him, that he would come to uch an end; for, from the life he led, there could not any thing ele be inferr'd. He was buried in the Monatery, and a trict earch was made for him who had committed the murther: but Sevil being a vat and populous City, no dicovery could be made of him. Onely Rufina knew who it was, by the abence of her Gallant, Ruperio's death, and the paper he found in her husband's cloet. She was infinitely atisfi'd to ee her elf reveng'd of a peron, who had done her uch an affront; and it was a great happines to her, that no notice had been taken of the bloud, which the deceas'd had pilt at the place where he was kill'd. Had the Magitrate known of that, it would have brought her into ome trouble, for the Neighbours would have tetifi'd, that they had often een thoe two Rivals in that little treet.

By this means Rufina is become a Widow, but withall poor and detitute of all accommodations, having onely the tock of her beauty to et her elf up again; and that, together with her honour (if it may be aid he had any left) he reolv'd to protitute, that he might live in ome meaure utably to what he had done before. Saravia's Nephew, who had taken poeion of all his etate, was entencd to pay Rufina omewhat upon the account of dower; but it was o inconiderable, in repect of the expence he was wont to be at, that he was forc'd to leave the houe he was in and take one of a lower rent. Nor had this Nephew what he expected by being heir to his Uncle, for the etate was extremely perplex'd, o that having even'd accounts with the Creditors,
he had but little left for himelf.

Rufina, having remov'd into another Quarter of the City, and being young, umptuous in cloaths, and perfectly handome, did not as many other Widows are wont to do, who, as oon as their husbands are march'd off, dres themelves as fine as hands can make them, and deriving a little advantage from their mourning eek out opportunities to hew themelves to the Gallants purely out of a deign to get other husbands. But ours, though young, had had o great experience, that he reolv'd to play another game, and that no mall one.

There was come in the Fleet from Peru a man born amidt the Mountains of Leon, who had begun his fortune by the relation of a Servant to a Merchant of Sevil, and one who, upon his Mater's cot, and ome little trading into the Indies, was grown rich, inomuch that within few years, he was accounted one of the ablet Merchants that traded to Peru. He makes another voiage thither, being advanc'd to a certain publick employment, and having thereby added much to his wealth, he was return'd again to Sevil, in that years Fleet, where he old the commodities he had brought over at double what they had cot him; o fortunate was he in all his ventures.

Marquina (o was this lucky Merchant call'd) was a peron of about fifty years of age; the mot covetous and wretched't natur'd fellow that ever was. He grudg'd himelf what he eat and drunk, though even below moderation; nay he many times fated purpoely to pare o much. He had no more ervants than he needed; his whole Train conited in a Factor, a Lacquey, a Moor-lave, who look'd to his
Mule, and a Maid to dres his pitiful Commons. He kept his Family o hort in point of victuals, that it was wondred any one would erve him; his Mierdipoition found the whole City dicoure; another would have been aham'd of it, but he onely laugh'd at it, applauding himelf, and making it his whole buines to heap up wealth, whereof he had abundance.

Rufina hearing this account of him, began to conider all the circumtances, and after he had a little reflected thereon, he concluded, that he might be made an excellent Cully, whom if he could mite, as he expected, her condition would be better than ever it had been. Marquina liv'd without the City, in a little Tenement he had purchas'd of one who ought him ome mony, which he knew not well how to get in otherwie; for he was naturally o perfect a lave to his profit, that he little minded his pleaures. So that he got that Tenement, with a neat houe on it, very cheap, and in atisfaction for his debt; it tood near S. Bernard's Monatery, in the midt of a pleaant valley. He liv'd here to pare the rent of a houe in the City; he had o fortifi'd it, that no thieves, either by day or night, could make any breach into it; all the doors were of extraordinary thicknes, the windows had bars and grates, the walls very high and very trong. He had ecur'd the place within with many fire-Arms, which he always kept charged, Halbards, and Partians, which were dipos'd near the gate. He was forc'd to take one peron more into his retinue, to wit, a fellow to order his Garden, and to make the bet advantage he could of it, a married man, who hould
carry the fruits and other things to the market to make the bet of them, o vigilant was his Avarice. His treaure was dipos'd into a ecret place behind his bed where he lay himelf, in trong iron chets; and every night before he went to bed, he, like an over-doing Contable, earch'd all the rooms in the houe. Thus did this wrerched fellow live, though he had no children to ucceed him, for he had never been married, nor intended to be, though very advantageous Matches were daily proffer'd him.

Rufina had laid her deign to bring in this covetous Merchant into the nooe, and to effect it, he communicated it to a peron who was excellent at uch things, and an ancient acquaintance of her Father's Signor Trapaa. This man had plaid ome pranks at Madrid, which had occaion'd his removal thence to Cadiz, and his atchievments there, his departure thence to Sevil, where he went lurking up and down, and pending ome mony, which it had cot him more hazard than pains to get. He was one of the mot accomplih'd men in point of Thievery of his time, but very fearful of falling into the hands of Jutice, let there might rie up in judgment againt him ome of his former offences; which were uch as had preferr'd him to the Galleys, where he had made acquaintance with Trapaa, and had continu'd it at Sevil. This peron (whoe name was Garay), Rufina took to ait her in the compaing of her deign. Having given him intructions what he was to do, and told him, that Marquina return'd not to his houe, till about Sun-et, as he was wont to do, they both pas'd by Marquina's garden, he on a Mule, and he on a good Hore. She had put off her Mourning,
and put on another dres, with a hat and feather, as the Sevil-Ladies are wont to go, when they are in the Country.

They pas'd by the Garden, jut as the Gardener was opening the door. Garay coming up to him, Friend, aid he, here is a Lady would not willingly go into the City to day, if you will afford her entertainment this night. I will atisfie you to your own deires; beides that you will do us an ex • raordinary kindnes, for you will thereby prevent a great misfortune which he cannot otherwie avoid. The Gardener, who was afraid of his Mate • s dipleaure, told him that he durt not be o bold, as to receive any peron into his houe, without his knowledge, though he had not exprely forbidden him the doing of any uch thing. But Garay, who knew the vertue and power of mony, took a coniderable um out of his pocket, and giving it to the Gardener, Here, friend, aid he, take this in earnet of more. The Gardener's wife longing to know what buines they might have with her husband, comes up to them, and eeing the proffers were made him, undertook to lodge the Gentlewoman in her own room, making it appear to her husband, that their Mater hould never come to the knowledge of it, in regard their houes were at a good ditance one from the other, and that they hould not be o unhappy, as that he would that night earch the whole houe, as many times a toy took him in the head to do.

In fine the wife's arguments prevail'd, o that the Gardener was content the Gentlewoman hould lodge ecretly that night at his houe, upon the receipt of ix Ryals which Garay gave him as an
earnet of a greater umme promis'd him. He thereupon took down Rufina off the hore, and brought her into the Garden, where he took leave of Garay, who had already receiv'd the orders whereof we hall give an account hereafter.

Being come into the Gardener's room, he took off what cover'd her face, and atonih'd the Gardener and his wife at the ight of her beauty, though he eem'd to be very melancholy, as if ome great misfortune had happened to her, to wit, that which he had ready to relate to Marquina, in cae he might come to peech with him. The Sun was hardly et, but he came into the Garden: the Negro entring a little before to have the door opened, which he himelf lock'd on the inide, and carried the key along with him. He chanc'd to be that night a little more weary than he us'd, which occaion'd his going to bed very betimes, after he had eaten a piece of bread, and ome of his own Garden fruits, and wah'd them down with a glas of pring-water. He onely viited that part of the houe where he lodg'd himelf, and came not down to the Gardener's, which ecap'd not his privy earch, when he thought of it. His family, who kept more fating-days in the year, than the Church her elf had appointed, upp'd that night, in imitation of the Mater, very oberly.

Marquina gets up the next morning betimes, and gives the Slave mony to go to the market, while he went about his affairs in the City, with order to have dinner ready againt his return. Rufina was at a los how to compas her deign, finding things fell not out according to her expectation: but till waiting the opportunity, he told her entertainers that he was extremely
troubled at her Uncle's tay (o he called Garay) and that all her adnes proceeded thence. The Gardener's wife, who was a good hearty woman, found her all the diverion he could.

Marquina comes home at noon, with an intention to dine in his garden, and before he ate down, he would needs take a turn about it, to ee if any thing were wanting; and he oberv'd that there wanted ome pieces of wood for the more convenient watering of the everal Knots. As he was going to the Gardeners to ee if he had any fit for that purpoe, the wife perceiving him coming, very hatily huffled Rufina into a little back-room, where he was wont to lie: but in regard it could not be done o uddenly, but that Marquina coming in might hear the ruffling of the ilks, and ee Rufina's hadow, he teps into the room where he was retir'd, and having found her, he led her out by the hand, and bringing her into the light, he found her o beautiful, that he was atonih'd thereat. The Gardeners wife wonder'd, that her Mater, intead of chiding her, as he expected, onely ask'd her who the Lady was. She anwer'd, that, the night before, paing by their door with an ancient Gentleman, who eem'd as ad as her elf, they had very earnetly intreated he might be lodg'd there but that night, to avoid a great misfortune, which would have hapned to them, if they had gone any further.

While the Gardener's wife was giving Marquina this account, he very attentively conider'd the trange Lady, who eem'd to be extremely troubled in mind, which added to the attractions of her Beauty. Marquina was o taken therewith, that dicarding
his unociable and covetous humour, he told the Gardener's wife, that he had done very well, in entertaining that Lady, though contrary to his orders, which in uch a cae were not to be oberv'd, where compaion and charity plead for the relief of thoe that are in trouble. This Lady, aid he, deerves a better reception than he hath found in your poor lodgings, I heartily proffer her my houe, if he will but honour it with her preence. Rufina thank'd him very civilly for his obliging proffers, and intreated him to allow her the privacy of ome other lodging, for the little time he had to tay there, in regard he expected an Uncle of hers to come and fetch her away that night.

Marquina, who began to be enflam'd, was orry to hear that her tay at his houe would be o hort, but after a little paue, he told her, that though it were but for an hour, he would infinitely oblige him, in the acceptation of the proffer he made her with o much affection. She, who expected that cue all the while, told him, that, to make ome return to o great civilities, he was ready to wait on him. With that he went to Marquina's apartment, whither he led her by the hand, to the great atisfaction of the Gardener's wife, who extremely wondred to ee her Mater, contrary to his cutom, of a civil and obliging humour. As he pas'd through the rooms, he took particular notice of all things; for though Marquina were naturally a very covetous peron, yet, as to the furniture of his houe, he was otherwie. He had very rich Tapetry, Chairs utable thereto, and Cabinets of Ivory and Ebony, nay indeed many things brought out of the Indics, which though they
cot him not much there, are here of very great price. He immediately commanded his Slave to prepare an excellent dinner, an employment he undertook with great alacrity, as knowing he might make ome advantage of that extraordinary liberality of his Mater. Rufina din'd with him, who treated her till with the bet the Table afforded, with importunate excues that there were no better for her.

As oon as they had din'd, he conducted her into a chamber, et forth with a great number of excellent pictures, where there was alo a umptuous bed, of China-work, and intreated her to repoe her elf on it, a cutom the Spaniards have in Summer, as oon as they have din'd, by reaon of the ultrines of the Country. He intreated alo to give her diquiet ome remiion, out of an aurance, that he hould be as afe in his houe as in any Sanctuary, and that he hould not want any thing lay in his power. She again return'd him her mot affectionate thanks, and complying with his deires, he taid alone in the room, which was the ame where Marquina took his repoe every day. He went into another, where he laid himelf down, much troubled and diquieted, as being fallen deeply in love with his fair Guet, and not knowing by what means he might induce her to favour him in what he deir'd of her, which if he could effect, he concluded himelf the happiet man in the world. Before he acquainted her with his deign, he was deirous to know the caue of her grief, and what might occaion her topping at his Garden, and thereby find whether there were any obtruction that might oppoe his deires to erve her. To be atisfi'd in this, it was requiite he taid till he aw • ke;
but he lept not at all, for he pent the time in conidering, what Anwer he hould make him, when he came to quetion her.

Marquina thinking it now time to peak to her, in order to the atisfaction of his curioity, goes into her chamber, telling her it was a cloe day, and that he was afraid he might over-leep her elf, and craving her pardon that he had taken the boldnes to give her that caution. She thank'd him for the tendernes he had for her health, and aur'd him, that he had not refreh'd her elf at all, the trouble he was in not permitting her to take any ret. He begg'd of her that he would no longer mother the caue of her diquiet, and renew'd the proffers he had made to erve her to the utmot of his power. Having return'd him her thanks, and thinking it now time to make ome progres in her deign, he gave him this relation of her adventures.

q.p:
Granada, one of the mot famous and eminent Cities of Spain, is the place of my birth; my parents (there's no neceity I hould name them) are of the mot antient and mot noble families of any in all the Mountains of old Cateel, and the whole iue of their matrimony was onely a Brother of mine and my elf. My Brother pent the youthful part of his age in courting Ladies, and, among other young perons like himelf, he plaid ome mad pranks of youth, which oblig'd him, for fear of falling into the hands of Jutice, to abent himelf from Granada; and for my part, I made it my onely buines to erve and humour thoe who had brought me into the world. I pent the days at my needle, not taking example from my companions,
who onely minded their divertiements; nay I was o ignorant what love meant, that I laugh'd at whatever related thereto, and thought thoe, who pent their time in courthips and entertaining thoe they call'd their Gallants, little better than o many ditracted perons. But Love it eems would punih this contempt of mine, and you hall ee how he did it. My Father and Mother being one day gone to viit a friend of theirs in the Country, who had buried his wife not long before, I heard in the treet the clahing of words, as if ome people had been fighting. I look'd out at the window to ee what might be the matter. I had never been guilty of uch a curioity before, and had it been God's pleaure I hould have hunn'd it then, I hould not now be telling you my misfortunes, which are uch, that I hall never think on them without tears. I there aw, to my orrow, three men with their words drawn, fighting againt one, who defended himelf with o great courage, that he not onely made his party good a long time againt o many enemies, but alo hurt two of them in the head, he himelf having receiv'd onely a light wound. Thee three Hectors finding themelves o worted by one peron, reolv'd to do their utmot to take away his life; o that exaperated by their wounds, they pres'd upon him o much, that he was forc'd to retreat within our gate, where they gave him two everal thruts into the breat, upon which he fell, and was left for dead. Mov'd with compaion to ee o proper a young man o diadvantageouly engag'd, I came down to the gate,
calling my Maids about me, to ee what might be done for him, (our houe being in a lone-treet) for thoe who were come upon the noie we made were o few, and thoe unarm'd, that they were not able to part them. We lock'd the doors and brought him in, and a Chirurgeon was immediately ent for. His wounds were o great, that we thought fit to dipoe him into a bed, in a ground-room, where my Brother was wont to lie. The young man thank'd me very civilly for the favour he receiv'd from me; but alas! that good office began with Compaion, but ended in Love. The Chirurgeon view'd his wounds, but could not preently give any certain judgment of them, though he whiper'd me in the ear, that he thought they might cot him his life. That account of him truck me to the heart, for having een him fight o gallantly, I mut needs acknowledge, that I had even then conceiv'd an inclination for him. But his kind expreions afterwards, and his thanking me o gentilly for the obligations he aid I had put upon him, rais'd it into a perfect Love. My Father and Mother return'd from their viit, and, ere they were got to our houe, were told by one of the Neighbours, a peron of ome quality, what had happened in their abence, and how that I had put a period to a quarrel, by entertaining the wounded party into their houe, out of compaion and a fear that he might be kill'd; whereat they were well atisfi'd, and commended the charitable office I had done at uch an extremity; for they were perons who gladly embrac'd any opportunity to exercie their charity. They viited the wounded,
encourag'd him to take heart, auring him he hould want nothing their Houe could afford, and acknowledg'd it well done by me, that I had o recu'd him, upon which I took occaion to pend mot of my time in waiting on him; him, I ay, who is the caue of all the troubles and afflictions which lye o heavy upon me. At the econd dreing, the Chirurgeon aur'd us that his wounds were not mortal, which caus'd much joy in our Houe, particularly to me, who became every day more and more paionately in love with him. As often as I could get out of my Father and Mother's fight, I went to pas away the time in his Chamber, for which kindnes he made me extraordinary acknowledgments.

This young Cavalier was born at Pampeluna, and one of the mot eminent in that City. His buines at Granada was to proecute a Law-uit, againt a very powerful peron, who finding but little jutice of his ide, that the caue was of great importance, and that notwithtanding the favour he had in Court, the Judges mut pas entence againt him, would put a period to the Suit by a horter cut, and rid himelf of his Adverary, by employing three Men to murther him, who were his own menial Servants. A month lipp'd away, ere Leonardo (o was the wounded peron named) got out of his Bed, having all that time been attended with as much care as might be. The econd day after his getting up, he had the opportunity to ee me, for my Mother was gone abroad upon a viit, wherein I accompany'd her not, becaue I had a greater mind to be alone with my young
Gallant. He dicover'd himelf to me o opportunely, and gave me uch enible aurances of his affection, that it rais'd a no les in me towards him, inomuch that there pat mutual promies of fidelity between us. I knew nothing all this time that my Father was upon a treaty of Marriage between me and a Gentleman of Granada, who was infinitely deirous to enter into our alliance, while I was very well atisfy'd with the choice I had made my elf. Leonardo, coming to hear of the others pretenions to me, was not a little troubled at it; but the onely remedy was patience, in regard he would make no dicovery of his Etate, till his Law-uit were ended, which he hoped would be in a hort time, and I in the mean time kept my Father in play with peruaions, that he would not be over-haty in concluding my Marriage with the Granadine.

Leonardo being perfectly cur'd, and requiting the kindnes and noble entertainment he had receiv'd at our Houe, with many coniderable preents, return'd to his own Quarters, to bring his buines to a final end. For my part, my troubles increas'd more and more upon me; for my Father, never giving me any notice of it, as if I had been a peron not at all concern'd, concluded the contract with the Granadine, and pas'd his word he hould have me; which when I came to undertand, I was o trucken, that I minded not what I did. This new Servant of mine, who expected ere long to be my Mater, came to give me a viit: but I oon atisfy'd him, that he had reckon'd before his Hotes, for whereas he had flatter'd himelf
into a foolih imagination that he hould have found the kindet reception in the world from me, he met with uch a repule, as he himelf concluded, mut rather proceed from the averion, than any indifference I had for him. In a word, being not of thoe Favourites of fortune, who promie themelves the attainment of things impoible, he eaily dicover'd, that my refual was the effect of ome other caue, than the modety, which a young Maid ought at leat pretend to upon uch occaions: and knowing withall that the wounded Leonardo had lodg'd ome time in our Houe, he preum'd, that my didain towards him was occaion'd by the love I had for the other, and thence inferr'd, that having not been o happy as to prevent him in the acquiition of my favour, he had, at bet, but a hazardous after-game to recover it. The jealouie he conceiv'd upon this preumption oblig'd him to make trial of all the ways he could imagine, to be aur'd of it, o as that he might not do any thing, whereof it hould afterwards repent him. Should all do o, there would not be o many groundles quarrels. I was in an extraordinary confuion during thee overtures; I acquainted Leonardo with my condition; he came to ee me that very night, and we agreed, the next, to leave my Father's houe, and to go to ome of his Relations, where we might be ecretly Married. The expected hour being come (unhappy hour to me, conidering the misfortunes I have run through ince!) as my Dearet and I were going out of the Houe and croing into another Street, my jealous Servant (who pent the nights to be aur'd
of his upition, which he now found to be too true) preently knew us, and, attended by two Servants, he et upon Leonardo, never thinking of any uch urprie; o that ere he had the time to draw his Sword, he receiv'd three mortal wounds, and fell down dead, having not been able to peak one word. The little noie which the murtherers had made, occaion'd the Neighbours to come out with lights, upon the appearance whereof they ran away, fearing they might be dicover'd. By this time there was a great tir at my Father's, that I could not be found, while I was in a manner dead, to ee my Dearet lying breathles at my feet. Having recover'd my elf, I conider'd it was to little purpoe for me to tay in the treet, after uch an accident, o that putting off my Pattins, and tucking up my Coats, I ran away as fat as I could, to a friend's houe of my Father's, an aged peron and very poor, whom I told what had happened to me, and how much it concern'd me not to tay any longer at Granada. Whereupon taking a Hore, he et me on him, and brought me to the next Village, where we took up another for him, and thence we are come hither, to avoid my Father, who, accompany'd by Officers, makes a earch after me, as I have undertood by the way. For that reaon I thought it not afe, that we hould go into Sevil as oon as we came hither, but that it was better I conceal'd my elf in ome place near it. It was the pleaure of fortune to direct me to this Habitation of yours, into which, upon extraordinary intreaties your Gardener ventur'd to receive me for this lat night.

Thus Sir, have you the tory of a wretched Maid (if there ever were any uch) whoe onely comfort now is in the good entertainment you are pleas'd to afford her. May Heaven requite your charity, ince there cannot be a greater than to relieve uch as are afflicted and perecuted to the extremity that I am.

div.p: The concluion of this dimal tory, which Rufina had had the time to invent and tudy o well, was a hower of Crocodile-tears, which rais'd uch a compaion in Marquina, that he could not forbear them himelf. The ubtle Baggage, who notwithtanding her counterfeit tears oberv'd all the actions of Marquina, perceiv'd that he gave credit to her feign'd tory, and that Love began to enter at that breach which compaion had made in his heart. This encourag'd Rufina to proecute her impoture, being now in a manner confident to bring it to ome effect. They continu'd a good while together, he weeping, as if he had done it for a wager, and he endeavouring all he could to comfort her: but that comfort came not up to the height of offering her the remedy he could have wih'd, for he had not yet overcome his covetous humour.

Having with great attention conider'd the great beauty of Rufina, her affliction, and trange adventures, and that this happines was as it were fallen into his mouth, he inferr'd that Heaven, as a ignal addition to his former happines, had directed her to his Houe. This was the firt love that had ever mov'd Marquina's heart, and, in all orts of perons that firt paion ever acts violently. Is Marquina fallen in love? He mut needs then be liberal. Hath
he entertain'd Rufina into his Houe? That kindnes will be the dearet to him that he ever did. O Love! O ininuating Paion, who dot bewitch the World, who dot ruine and beet Men! what Metamorphoes dot thou not work in them? what Dipoitions dot thou not change? what Reolutions dot thou not dipence with? what Felicities dot thou not diturb? And what Hearts is it not in thy power to often? That of this inatiable Mier, which had cat off all ene of humanity towards his nearet Relations, love hath chang'd; o that he hath transform'd a covetous and ordid Peron into a liberal and magnificent. He is extreamly taken with Rufina; he is paionately in love with her; he will ere long be Mitres of his heart and wealth. She aid many things in her relation, which might have betray'd her, had not the affection, wherewith Marquina hearkened to her, clos'd both his Eyes and Ears: nay, he was o prepoes'd with his paion, that he would have believ'd many other things from her, though they had been more improbable than they were.

The effect of this ad narration of Rufina, was, that Marquina proffer'd her all the favour and aitance he could expect from him, his Etate, Life, Heart and Soul, giving her the title of abolute Mitres of all he was poes'd of, further entreating her, of all love, to give over thinking of her misfortunes, and aure her elf that he was in a Houe where he might command, and that what ever he deir'd, her orders hould be obey'd, as far as it lay in his power. Rufina very kindly thank'd him for o many generous proffers, concluding her complement
with a freh hower of tears, a kind of tempet he could raie, when ever he either pleas'd, or tood in need thereof.

With thee artifices, he became Mitres of Marquina and all he had, o as that he might dipoe of him and it, as he pleas'd. Her beauty had given him a kind of Itch, and he was mighty deirous to try whether he would be as willing to cure him of it: but he knew not well how to acquaint her with his indipoition; he reolv'd at lat, in cae he could do no good upon her by his ubmiions and preents, to ue the lat remedy, which was to Marry her. This is a Bait that many times takes the hyet of that ubtle Sex; but when they are o taken, he that does it is commonly napp'd himelf. I told you before, that Rufina had no other deign than to examine the Chets of the greedy Merchant, and that he would not be any way engag'd till he were ecure of her prize; for the racally trick hewn by Ruperio, had made her extreamly ditrutful.

p.U: taid all that day in his Garden, and neglected his buines in the City; but the next morning betimes, leaving his Guet aleep, he takes his Mule, and goes about his ordinary occaions, having charg'd the Gardener's Wife, to get a good breakfat for the Lady, as oon as he were awake, and to have a care of the Houe. He lock'd the Chamber-door where his Money was, and as he went out, charg'd the Gardener not to uffer any to come into his Garden, but the Old man who had brought Theodora thither, for that was the name the diembling Rufina had given her elf.

div.p:
That done, he went about his buines, attended
by the little Negro, whom he gave Money to buy Proviions for a good Dinner. Rufina got up, and the Gardener's wife punctually obey'd the orders he had receiv'd from her Mater, treating her the bet he could, out of this repect, that all the Dometicks made their advantage of thoe magnificences. Rufina comes down into the Garden, where he took occaion to commend the walks, and contrivances of it, for the Gardener kept it in very good order, and well upply'd with herbs, fruits, and flowers. Finding the Sun beginning to grow hot, he went into the Houe, where caually meeting with a Lute, on which Marquina's factor was wont to play, he et it in Tune, and made that her entertainment, till uch time as Marquina return'd from the City, who hearing her at it, was not a little glad to find that perfection in her more than he knew before. Perceiving that Marquina hearkened to her Muick, he joyn'd her Voice to the Intrument, to breed one maggot more in his brain than he had already. She ung o excellently, that Marquina was ravih'd at the melody, and acknowledg'd that it was not the Voice of a mortal Creature, but an Angel come down from Heaven. He continu'd his attention a while, imagining he would have begun another Song; but perceiving he laid by the Lute, he comes into the Room, and, tranported with joy, How hath this poor Habitation been felicify'd, aid he to her, by your retirement into it, mot adorable Theodora? What happines did the hour of your arrival here bring me who never had known any before? What honour have I receiv'd in beholding your trancendent Beauty, and to oberve in you from time to
time a thouand unknown excellencies which are not dicover'd at the firt ight? This houe may, no doubt, enter into competition with Heaven it elf, ince uch an Angel honours it with her divine preence. What I ay, Madam, is but little, in comparion of the paion I have for your worth, which were it to be commended proportionably to the apprehenion I have of it, I think the mot eloquent perons that ever were, would be at a los for expreions uitable to o adorable a ubject. You pres too hard upon me, Dear Sir, replies the counterfeit Theodora, eeming to bluh at thoe exceive praies; I am not uch a tranger to my elf, but that I know it argues exces in the highet degree, to betow uch extraordinary commendations, on a peron that deerves o little.
