Had I mitruted your being within hearing, I would have put off my diverion to another time, ince 'tis not unlikely my Voice may eem harh to you, compar'd to the excellent ones of this City, which you often hear, unles it be, that generous natures have an inclination to favour perons of mean parts, by flattering them, by their praies, into an imagination, that their endowments are greater than indeed they are. No more complements, I beeech you, replies Marquina, rais'd up to the highet pitch of beotted Love, my words come hort of my faith, and I am to aure you withall, Madam, that though I have heard excellent Voices in Sevil, (for I mut confes there are ome uch) yet yours is infinitely beyond any of them. Your mot humble Servant, Sir, ays Rufina, your commendations are infinitely beyond my deerts, and
the honour you do me can do no les than raie in me a hearty wih, that my poor abilities might find you ome further diverion with this Intrument, ince you are pleas'd to acknowledge your elf o much atisfy'd therewith: But my troubles are o great and preing, that in what I did, I minded onely my own. I mut ee them at an end, ere you leave this Houe, ays Marquina to her, and therefore let me intreat you, if you cannot conclude an abolute peace with your afflictions, at leat condecend to a hort ceation of arms.

p.q:
Thee reiterations of your favours mut needs extreamly oblige me, replies Rufina, and conequently force me to a greatful compliance with your commands, as far as lies in my power: but I cannot promie it you o fully as I wih, finding the peron who brought me hither, hath forgotten he did it, otherwie he would have found ome means to have given me a Viit once in three days. Let not that create you any trouble, replies the amorous Merchant, but rather imagine there may be ome jut caue of his neglect. I have ome apprehenion, aid he, that he may be return'd to Granada, out of a fear, that, being mis'd there, he might be quetion'd as a Complice of my ecape; and this would prove the greatet of all my misfortunes, for if he be gone, he hath carried all I had along with him. Never fear it, ays Marquina, for he mut have more compaion than to forake you in o great an extremity; but though he and all ele fail you, aure your elf, I hall not, whereof I cannot give you a greater aurance, than you may derive from this incere protetation, of my being o paionately
your Servant, that I imagine not my elf to be the ame peron I was before I aw you. This transformation is wholly to be attributed to your Divinity, and thence you may inferr the influence you have over me.

div.p: Having o aid, Marquina made an abolute dicovery of his Love; the cunning Gypie pretending he undertood not his meaning, return'd civil Anwers to the proffers he made her, acknowledging her elf extreamly oblig'd to him for his kindnes, and that he doubted not of the performance of what he was pleas'd, out of his own good nature to promie. By this time, Dinner was et on the Table; they both at down, and the entertainment was very noble, uitable to the Love of the Founder; for where that little Deity comes once to reign, the firt Act he makes, is for the banihment of all baenes and avarice.

Rufina and Garay had agreed together, that he hould come to her, when he were ure the old Merchant was abroad, and that he hould diguie himelf like a Beggar, that he might not be known, nor any upition be conceiv'd of him. She had tudied everal ways to choue the Merchant of ome part of his Treaure, but he could not fix on any one he thought might prove effectual, the Chamber where it was Lock'd being extreamly fortify'd. She had continu'd there three days ere he had either een or heard from Garay, and during the time, he expres'd o great a dicontent, as put Marquina to much trouble, in regard it kept him from making thoe free dicoveries of his Love, which he would otherwie have done. In the mean time Rufina,
who watch'd all occaions, cunningly dicover'd the place where the Old man hid the Keys of his Iron chets.

Marquina went, according to his cutom, into the City, which being oberv'd by Garay, he comes to his Houe in Beggars weeds, as they had agreed together, with two Crutches. Being got under the Window, at which Rufina was looking out, he begg'd an alms of her. She threw him down omething, and ask'd him whence he came, whereto Garay anwering that he was of Granada, he eem'd to be extreamly glad, and thereupon turning to the Gardener's wife, Let us go down a little into the Garden, aid he to her, this poor fellow is come out of my Country, I would fain have ome dicoure with him, to know what news he hath brought thence. The poor Woman upecting nothing, made no difficulty to let him into the Garden. Rufina ask'd him how long it was ince he had left Granada; whereto he anwering, about nine or ten days, he continu'd her quetions o long, that the Gardener's wife weary of their dicoure, and having omething ele to do, left them. Being rid of her, they conider'd what was to be put in execution the night following, and agreed upon the coure they were to take, to poes themelves of Marquina's Treaure.

That done, Garay departed, and Rufina went up to her Chamber, telling the Gardener's wife, he had undertood o much from that poor fellow, concerning her affairs, that it would not be long ere he return'd into her Country. The Gardener's wife, and the Maid were little pleas'd to hear that news, as fearing their Mater would, upon her departure, re-aume
his niggardly humour, and keep as mierable a a houe as he had done before, nay haply put himelf and all the ervants to a greater penance in their diet, to get up what had been quander'd away, during her aboad there.

Marquina being come home found Rufina that night more cheerful than at any time before; which gave him the confidence to acquaint her more freely with his love then he had done, and to aure her of the diquiet he was in upon her account. Rufina eem'd not to take it amis, nay by a greater familiarity then he had expres'd towards him before, he rais'd in him ome hopes of eeing his deires atisfi'd: whence the old dotard began to preume, that the fort would in a hort time be taken in upon reaonable tearms. Upon this preumption, he betow'd on her a Ring, which he had purpoely bought for her, wherein was a Diamond worth about an hundred crowns, et about with little Rubies. The Lady gave him many thanks for o noble a preent, and in requital promis'd him a Leon on the Lute, to which he ung ome new Aires, though he quarrell'd at the dulnes of the Intrument. Marquina promis'd her a better the next day. They parted for that time, but with different thoughts, Marquina deirous to obtain thoe favours he expected from Rufina, and to oblige her thereto by preents, which overcome the greatet difficulties; and Rufina contriving how to compas the robbery he intended.

The next day, Garay (a peron of great experience in uch deigns) got ome others of the ame profeion to carry on the work; and having oberv'd Marquina going into his houe, they taid till he
were gone to bed, which was omewhat late, for Rufina, who held a correpondence with them, had purpoely kept him up. About midnight, Garay and his Camerades brought a thing that had the figure of a man, tuff'd with traw, having about him a cloak, which cat over his houlder, cover'd his face, and pitch'd it over againt the principal window towards the garden, which was that part of the houe where Marquina lodg'd, and left it there fatned to a take they had thrut into the ground. The night was omewhat dark, and o more proper for their deign. Having plac'd that figure, as I told you, they knock'd at the door o loud that it might have been heard from one end of the Garden to the other. Marquina awaken'd thereby leaps out of his bed, it being trange to him to hear uch knocking at his garden door, at uch an uneaonable time, as being a thing had never happen'd to him before. He call'd up his ervant, and bid him ee who knock'd at the door. The ervant went out between leeping and waking to ee what the matter was, calling as loud as he could, Who knocks there? But no body anwering, and he not minding the figure that tood in the garden, told his Mater that there was not any body.

Marquina upon that got into bed again and compos'd himelf to ret, but it was oon interrupted, for Garay knock'd more violently than he had done before, which atonih'd him the more, and oblig'd him to end down his m • n a econd time, to ee what the matter was. Bringing his Mater the ame account he had done before, he got up himelf, puts his cloak about him, and calls at the window, Who knocks at my door thus uneaonably? Whereto no
Anwer being made, he grew the more enrag'd; but looking a little more earnetly about the houe than his man had done, he perceiv'd the figure planted before his windows. Marquina was extremely afraid, at the ight of a peron, who, as he thought, knock'd at his door, yet made him no anwer, and auming more courage than he was naturally Mater of, he aid to him very loud, 'Tis baely done of you, Sir, to abue me thus, you hall find I am not a peron to uffer it; pray keep on your way, and diturb not my ret any more, if you think not your elf invulnerable, and that a brace of good bullets will make no impreion in your inchanted skin.

Having made that bravado he hut to the window and went to bed; but he was hardly got warm in it, ere they began to knock more violently than they had done before; which oblig'd him to take a fire-lock, which he kept always ready charg'd for the ecurity of his mony. Opening the window, he found till in the ame poture, him, who would not have tirr'd out of it, had he not been forc'd by ome other. What obtinacy of impudence is it in you, aid he to him, very much incens'd, to do a michief, you are nothing the better for, in thus diturbing my ret? 'tis impardonable, and deerves an exemplary chatiement; be you gone immediately from my door, or I hall end you going the next way. Whereupon cocking the fire-lock, and aiming at him, and the other never tirring, as it were out of a preumption, that he had not any fire-arms, wherewith he might make good his threats, he gave him notice the third time, that he would not oblige him to do a violence which he was unwilling to do. At lat perceiving he
minded not any thing he aid, but as 'twere defi'd him, he reolv'd to give fire, not onely to frighten him, but, if he could, to hurt him. He hot, and the figure fell to the ground, upon which Garay, who was not far off, cries out with a doleful tone, O God, I am kill'd; and immediately he and his Camerades made a great noie at the ight of a man o unfortunately murther'd.

Marquina was extremely troubled at what he had done, it being oberv'd, that covetous perons are for the mot part cowardly, and extremely fear what-ever may caue them any los. He hut the window, and in a great fright awaking Rufina (who had greater things to mind than leeping) told her what he had done. She eem'd to be extremely troubled at it, and much blam'd him, that he had executed o cruel a reolution. For since he knew himelf to be afe enough in his own houe, he might have uffer'd them to knock at his door till they had been weary; that he had better endur'd that noie, and lot a little of his ret, than be in the trouble he was in, that he had been the caue of a man's death. She added everal other reaons, which o confounded poor Marquina, that he knew not what to do. She advis'd him for his afety, to go immediately and take refuge in the Monatery of St. Bernard, it being certain, that if the dead peron were found there the next morning, he would be carried to prion, as being murther'd o near his houe. Marquina was o perplex'd, that he wih'd he had never come into the world; and it is to be imagin'd, that if Rufina had not been very highly concern'd to diemble upon this occaion, she would have dy'd with laughing. He
rais'd up all his people, and told them what had happen'd, and all blam'd him, for his being o forward to commit uch an action, which made the poor old dotard almot mad. He imagin'd himelf already apprehended, his mony carri'd away, and but a mall matter between him and hanging, at leat if he were oblig'd by tortures to acknowledge his crime, never conidering that it was pardonable for one man to kill another in his own defence. At lat, he reolv'd to go to S. Bernard's; but knew not how to dipoe of his mony. He thought it no prudence to leave it at the dicretion of his Servants; to carry it to a friend's houe (in cae he had any, for perons of his humour have very few) he had not time. In this ditraction he deir'd Rufina to advie him; he eeming very much troubled, and no les fearful than he, pretended he could not give him any; but after a little paue he gave him that advice, which he had prepar'd long before, and he follow'd it. She ask'd him what mony he might have in the houe? He ingenuouly confes'd that he had about four thouand crowns in gold, and omewhat better than half the aid umme in ilver. I'l tell you what I would do, were I in your cae, ays the ubtil Picara, (ince it cannot be carried to a friend's houe without being een) I would burie it in the garden, in ome place, where you may afterwards find it, by ome mark you hall et to that purpoe. This you mut do your elf, o as that your very ervants may not know any thing of it, let they might be tempted to prove fale to you; for the times are uch now, that a man mut have a care whom he truts. I would ait you herein, and keep your counel, were it not
that I am afraid, when the earch comes to be made, and I be left here, I hall be the firt taken; and I would be loath to run my elf into that hazard, having but jut ecap'd thoe I have acquainted you with. In the midt of his affliction, Marquina was troubled to perceive by his guet's dicoure, the diturbance he was in upon his account, and what truck him mot to the heart, was, that he aw himelf upon the point of loing her. This conideration forc'd from him not onely tears, but alo bitter exclamations againt the malicious crosnes of his fortune. Rufina deir'd him to be of good courage, peruading him to do as he advis'd him, and hope the bet. So that having commanded all his ervants to go to their everal chambers, and not to tir thence, he and Rufina, whom onely he durt trut, went to the place where the mony was. It lay in a huge chet, cover'd all over with iron-bars, and the keys were o extraordinary, that it was impoible to counterfeit them, or to get a piece thence by any other wile than what was invented by our ubtil Ferret.

They firt took out all the ilver, and then put the gold into a little box, and, having brought all into the garden, they made two holes, at ome ditance one from the other, in one whereof they put the ilver, and in the other, the gold, etting a mark that they might find the places again. Marquina took along with him two hundred crowns in gold, and gave Rufina fifty, to hift for her elf, till the buines were accommodated.

That done, they went up into the houe, whence they might ee everal perons walking with a light;
'twas Garay and his camerades, who repreented the Magitrate, which Rufina hewing him, advis'd him to make all the hate he could to St. Bernard's. To do that, they got over the garden wall, as being afraid to open the door, for they perceiv'd the actors of this comedy kept a watch there, with uch authority, as if they had really been the Officers of Jutice. All Marquina's family follow'd him over the wall, fearing they might come into trouble for their Mater's fault. Marquina and his Mitres lurk'd omewhere thereabouts, till it was day, that they might have the Church-door open, to get into the Monatery. Garay was hard by, to ee what became of Marquina and his people. Finding he had left his houe, and got into the Monatery with Rufina, he went about an hour after Sun-riing to St. Bernard's, in the habit of a Secular Priet, that he might the better peak to Rufina. She told him how things tood, and how they had buried the mony in the garden, and that it was all in ilver, intending to reerve all the gold for her elf.

About mid-night Garay and one of his Camerades went along with Rufina, diguiz'd in man's cloaths, to the garden. They help'd her over firt, to go and ee whether there might be any body in the houe, but all were vanih'd as if the houe had been viited. She thereupon call'd Garay and his companion, and, having taken up the mony, they carri'd it away, and took up their quarters at one of the farthet Inns of the uburbs. Having been merry a while, and drunk their own healths, and to the good ucces of their future deigns, they went all to bed, the two men together, and Rufina by her elf. As oon as she
found they were aleep, he puts on the ame habit, and returns to the garden. She took up the little box of gold, and, without any diater, got afe to the Inn before her companions awaked.

The next day, having divided the ilver, whereof he and Garay had the bet part, and ew'd up the gold in her cloaths, he left Sevit, taking Garay along with her, who, finding what advantages he might make of her company, reolv'd to run fortunes with her. They took their way towards Madrid, to which place they will be got, by that time we hall ee what is become of Marquina, whom we left in St. Bernard's Monatery.

Having continu'd there four days after Rufina's departure from him, he knew not what to think of her that he came not again, as he had promis'd. He addres'd himelf to one of the Monks, who had great acquaintances in the City, and intreated him to inquire what proceedings there might be againt him, upon the murther he had committed. The Religious man promis'd him an account of it; but having enquir'd at thoe places where he might mot probably hear thereof, no body could give him any atisfaction. He thereupon told Marquina, that he might afely go abroad and needed not to fear any thing. He went out one night to a friend's of his, whom he acquainted with all that had pat, as alo the great perplexity he was in, deiring him to make a more particular enquiry into the buines, than he thought the Religious man had done. He did o, and gave him the ame account as the other. Yet would not that atisfie him, but he mut deire his friend to go to his houe, whereof he gave him the Mitris key.
He went, and found it without any body in it, and his Mule dead, for want of meat and tendance. He went with this news to his friend, adviing him to come out of the Monatery, and go home, and thence about the City, as he was wont to do. The death of his Mule troubled him not much, o glad was he to find himelf once more at liberty: the onely thing gave him any diquiet, was, that his Theodora (under which name Rufina went) came not to ee him. But he imagin'd the caue of it might be, that, being a young Maid, he had helter'd her elf ome-where, to keep out of the hands of Jutice, or that haply he might have been met with by her Father, who, as he had told him, ought after her. He went to his houe, whither came oon after the Gardener and his wife, and the other ervants. He goes into the Garden, and, notwithtanding all the fear and ditraction he had been in, remembred the place where he had hid his mony, and was not a little glad to find the mark where he had et it; o that before he went to bed, he reolv'd to ecure his treaure in its former garrion. As oon as it was dark, he takes the Gardener with him, and a Lanthorn and Candle, and goes firt to the place where the Silver was, and bids him digg. He did o, but there was nothing to be found, whereat Marquina was extremely urpriz'd. He went thence to the place where they had laid the gold, and there they found as little, onely Rufina knew what was become of all. He walk'd everal turns about the garden, with much vexation, imagining the marks might be miplac'd; but what in looking after the marks, and what in digging; the night lipp'd away, o that at lat dipairing to find any thing that night, he behav'd
himelf like a peron ditracted. The Gardener knew not what he look'd for, nor for what reaon he had brought him thither. The poor man reolv'd to have a little patience till the next morning, being till in ome hope to find what he had hidden. He went to bed, or rather to pend the night in unufferable torments: but as oon as it began to dawn, he got up, and having call'd up the Gardener, they return'd to the work they had been at the night before. Having digg'd again at thoe places, where he was confident he had laid the mony, all they could find was, that there had been two holes made there before, and that mony or omething ele had been hidden there, but all was remov'd. This aurance made him run tark mad, throwing himelf on the ground, running his head againt the wall, and doing uch things as rais'd a compaion in his ervants, who thence concluded that he had lot his mony, and upected the feign'd Theodora, to have robb'd him, by the orders he gave them to earch after her all over the City. But he was far enough out of his reach, and had o wel ecur'd his mony, that it was not likely it would come into his chets any more. He kept his bed a good while, our of a pure madnes, that he had o oon lot, what had cot him many years trouble and pains to get together. The robbery was oon divulg'd all over the City; ome, who knew not his humour, pitied his misfortune, but uch as had experience of his inatiable avarice, were not a little pleas'd to find him o jutly punih'd.
div.trailer: The end of the firt Book.

div.head: LA PICARA, OR The Triumphs of Female Subtilty.
The Second Book.
div.p:
AS oon as our ubtle Picara had done her work at Marquina's, and had made a broken Merchant of one, who was accounted the wealthiet about Sevil, he thought it not prudence to make any long •• y, for fear of falling into the hands of Jutice, whoe Officers would be abroad, upon the ollicitations of the party robb'd. She was gotten far enough out of the way, ere he was enible of his los, for the next night after they had taken away the Money, he and Garay hired two Mules, upon which they came to Carmona, which lies about half a days journey from Sevil. They had taken up two places in
the Madrid-coach, which was to pas through that City, and take them up as it went. They lighted, at Carmona, at one of the bet Inns, where Rufina, keeping out of ight, was reolv'd to expect the Coach, conidering with her elf, what he might come to in time, now that he was already Mitres of four thouand Crowns in Gold, in good double Pitols and Quadruples, which was all that penurious Merchant had gotten together, during his whole Life, with much pains taking, and many a hazardous venture into the mot remote Climats. Behold here, the exemplary punihment, which many times happens to thoe mierable wretches, who become the Slaves of their own wealth. And what infinitely adds to their misfortune, is, that people are more apt to congratulate than bemoan it: for how can they expect that others hould have any kindnes for them, when they themelves have not any but for what they lay up in their Chets?

The Coach which our fortunate adventurers expected to carry them to Madrid, came at its uual time to Carmona. There were in it already ix Perons, a Gentleman, and his Lady, a Priet, two Univerity-Scholars, and a Servant belonging to the Priet, a young Lad about fifteen years of Age. They all knew, that there were two perons to be taken in at Carmona, who had paid omewhat extraordinary, for the bet places. They accordingly reign'd them, as oon as they perceiv'd their coming towards the Coach: but Garay, who was a very civil and obliging peron, would needs recommend his interet in the place to the Gentleman's Lady, whom he eated on the left ide of Rufina, and at himelf
in the fore-part of the Coach, with her Husband.

All being plac'd to their content, they left Carmona on the Munday morning, it being in September, when mot Fruits are ripe. All thought it a great happines, that they had met o good Company; but Rufina and Garay had another ecret atisfaction, ariing from the thought of the good prize that had brought them into that good Company. The Gentleman was a Peron of excellent dicoure; the Priet, of a very ociable and converative humour, and the two young Scholars made it appear, that they had not mi-pent their time at the Univerity, every one being deirous to make the bet dicovery he could of his abilities. The Priet took occaion to tell them, that he was going to Court, to get a Priviledge, to put two little pieces of his into the Pres, being uch as ome Friends of his had aur'd him he hould oblige the World in the publication of them. The Gentleman, who ate next him, was a peron acquainted with Letters, and expres'd a great curioity to know what they might treat of. Doctor Monalvo (o was the Priet called) told him they were Books of Dicoures, and Divertiements; repreenting to him that things of that kind, were kindly receiv'd at Court: that one of them was entituled, The Staple of Dicoure and Complements; and the other, The Flowers of Helicon; that the former contained twelve Moral Novels, with an intermixture of Veres; and the Flowers of Helicon was a collection of Poems written by him, during his Reidence at the Univerity of Salamanca. He told them withall, that, if they thought it not tedious,
he would entertain them with omewhat out of the former, when ever they hould be at leiure to give him attention.

Rufina, who was a great lover and reader of uch Treaties, intreated the Doctor, if it were no trouble to him, to read one of his Novels, promiing her elf, from the aurance he had of his excellent parts, that the tile and conceptions would be anwerable to the worthines of the Author. I have endeavour'd, all I could, Madam, ays the Doctor to her, to conform my elf to the tile now us'd at Court; my Proe is free from affectation, and conequently will not weary the Reader, nor are the conceipts o flat as to produce the ame effect. I make it my buines to give my Writings a little life and martnes, which may raie in the Reader an earnetnes to know the period of the adventures. I write as I peak, becaue I ee Men love thoe things that are natural, better than thoe which mell of too much tudy and affectation; and take it from me as a thing very certain, that it requires a certain meaure of confidence for any Man to write as the times go now; which proceeds hence, that o many excellent Wits buie themelves in writing, and publih things as admirable as ingenious, and not onely Men, who profes Letters, but alo ome Women. Among the latter, how are we to celebrate the ingenuity of Donna Maria de Zaras, and Soto Mayor, who hath worthily deerv'd the title of the Sibyl of Madrid, as alo the reputation he hath acquir'd of an excellent Wit, and to do admirable things in Poetry, having lately put into the Pres a piece containing ten Novels,
which are look'd on as o many miracles, by thoe who are Judges in that kind of writing? The excellency of her Proe, and the ubtilty of the deigns, together with the ininuating intertexture of the Veres, have given mate to the bet Pens of Spain. Donna Anna Caro de Malien, a Native of our City of Sevil, comes not much behind her, and may be allow'd near the ame meaure of praie. Her weet and harmonious Veres upend the Spirits, and charm the Ears of all that hear them, as hath been een, by thoe publih'd by her the lat Carnaval, at the new Palace, built by his Majety, near the Coure, which may be called the eighth Wonder of the World, ince he peaks of it, with an eloquence anwerable to the preparations which had been there made, many days before, for the divertiement of their Catholick Majeties. The Doctor having ended this dicoure, he took out his Book of Novels, and, the Company having compos'd themelves to ilence and attention, he entertain'd them with that which follows.

div.head: THE FIRST NOVEL.
All Covet, all Looe.
div.p:
VAlentia, one of the mot eminent Cities of Spain, the Nure of o many noble Families, the Centre of ingenious Spirits, and the acred Receptacle of the Bodies of divers Saints, gave Birth unto Don Alexander, a Peron of noble Extraction, Young, and Mater of all thoe excellent Qualities, for which Men are either lov'd or admir'd. Having
left his Country about twelve years before in the company of an Uncle of his, who had the command of a Troop of Hore in Flanders, he behav'd himelf with o much gallantry in thoe parts, that he was in a hort time advanc'd to be Cornet, under his Uncle, who dying, he upply'd his place, and o continu'd twelve years in the ervice of this Catholick Majety, Philip the Third, againt the revolted Provinces of the Low-countries. He was, at lat, in compenation of his Services, honoured with the Order of Saint James, with the ordinary allowances belonging thereto.

During that part of the year, which makes a kind of ceation of Arms in thoe colder Countries, his aboad was in the City of Antwerpe, where, by certain Letters from Valentia, he receiv'd the news of his Father's death, which made him, being the eldet, heir of a very coniderable etate. He might indeed now have lived plentifully on his own, and puru'd his pleaures, as many other young Cavaliers did, who place all the felicity of this Life in the infamous enjoyments thereof: But he, a dutiful Son of Honour, choe rather to continue the exercies of War, and erve his Country, than by a udden exchange of employments, blat his reputation, and incurr the reproach of a peron impatient of hardhip, and touch'd with a pice of effeminacy. This conideration dicovers him to be much more tay'd than thoe young Gentlemen, who prefer whole Skins, the hameful blandihments of Eae, and the warmth of their own Fires, before the honour, which a peron truly deerving that name hould endeavour to purchae in the ervice of his Prince. But Don Alexander
conidering withal, that he could not, upon this news of his Father's death, avoid taking a journey to Valentia, to order the dipoal of his Etate, he deired leave to do it, of his mot erene Highnes the Arch-Duke Albert, who, finding the jut occaion he had to go, eaily condecended, proffering him, at his return, what advancement he could reaonably expect: which oblig'd him to make the more earnet promies to come back into Flanders, contrary to the preumptions of many, who imagined, that he had made an Exit from the Military Stage, thence forward to follow the more pleaant divertiements of a Civil life.

Being come to Valentia, where his Relations and Friends kindly entertained him, he began to order the management of his affairs, not trifling away his time in unprofitable diverions, whereto young Men are but too much addicted. For though he were a Souldier, yet was he no lover of Gaming, a dipoition for which he was much to be commended, conidering his Age and Quality: inamuch as Gaming occaions a thouand misfortunes, and unhappy accidents, whereof there had happened not a few at Valentia. Nor was Don Alexander as yet any way inclin'd to Love, though he could not want occaions to expres his Courthip, and how far he had tudied the Myteries of Love and Eloquence, ince what added much to the Lutre of that City, was the great number of fair Ladies, hining in it like o many tars. But his mot ordinary employment was the exerciing of his Hores. Of thee he had four excellent ones, extreamly well manag'd, which he had bought in Andaluia, and on which he rode a hunting
the Bulls, according to the cutom of the Country, hewing himelf, at that port, more dextrous than all thoe who were accounted the Bravos of the City.

'Tis a cutom in Valentia, that at the beginning of the Spring, for the pace of about fifteen days together, mot of the families of the City go about the Silk-husbandry, which they have in the adjacent Villages. One day, Don Alexander rid abroad into the Country, through that delightful Plain which is near a Garden not far from Valentia, known by the name of the Monatery of our Lady of Hope, and having pent the whole afternoon about thoe pleaant Gardens, refrehing himelf with the weet cent of the flowers of the Orenge-trees, whereof there is good tore thereabouts, (the Sun being o low that it eem'd to be equally divided between us and our Antipodes) he pas'd by a Country houe not far from the pleaant River of Turia, where he heard, at a mall ditance, one playing on a Lute, o well, that he thought he had not heard any Muick comparable to it before. He topp'd his hore, imagining the peron playing on that Intrument o excellently might alo ing to it. He expected a while with much impatience; but the Muician putting the Intrument into everal different Tunes, did not what he o much deired, which was, to hear her voice. In the mean time night came on, and Don Alexander extremely delighted with the place he was in, gave his hore to his Lacquey, and cauing him to remove a little ditance off, he taid alone, under the green Balcony, whence the Muick came, to find out who made it. But he had not waited long, ere he could perceive, by the light of
the Moon, that it was a Lady, who being got into that Balcony to take the advantage of a gentle wind then blowing, began afreh her delightful Muick on the Lute, whereto he join'd that of an admirable voice, inging an Air, which made an abolute conquet of that Heart, wherein all the hardhips of War had not made the leat breach. Whence we may deduce this Remark, That Cupid can do more in a minute, than Mars, in a Troy-iege.

To ay the ame thing again in other words, The excellency of the Voice, and the trancendent nimblenes of the hand, the compliance and competition between them, o ravih'd our young Gallant, that he wih'd he might never give over, at leat not till he were atiated with that pleaure. But the Lady laid by her Intrument, and leaning her breat on the Balcony, though 'twere night, made a hift to ee the young Gallant, whom her Muick had ti'd o long by the ears; who alo perceiving her, would needs make his advantage of o blet an opportunity. So that getting as near her as he could, he broke forth into this Complement: How infinitely happy mut that abent Gentleman be, Madam, (for in the Veres he had ung, he bemoan'd the abence of a certain peron) who deerves o excellent a voice to bemoan his abence. I hould be extremely glad of his acquaintance, that I may give him that of this good news, that he is o obligingly bemoan'd by o deerving a Lady as you eem to be.

The Lady wondred to find her elf urpriz'd, but recovering out of her atonihment, though he knew not the peron who had poken to her, he gave him this Anwer. As to the Song you heard, Sir, you
are not to imagine it ung out of any tendernes I have for ome peron now far from me, and therefore you may pare your elf the trouble to learn who it may be, and conequently to tell him how highly he is in my favour, as you imagine. What aurance can I have of that, ays Alexander, knowing, by what I have heard from your own mouth, the predominant paion of your oul? How, I pray, Sir, may you be concern'd in that, aid he to him? Very much, replies he; for the enchantment of your voice hath been o powerful over him who hath heard it, that it is not without reaon he requires aurances of what he asks you, to prevent the diquiet, which he mut otherwie expect.

She could not forbear laughing at this dicoure of Don Alexander's, and telling him withall, that Women do prudently, when they are flattered, not to believe any thing that Men ay to them, in regard they never peak truth, repreenting things, not as they really are, but as they appear to their beguil'd imaginations,. Wherein, I pray, ays Alexander, do you think, Madam, that I have told you any thing hort of truth? Mitake me not, repli'd he, I do not charge you with a coming hort, but going much beyond it, for you are o prodigal of your commendations of a peron you are yet very little acquainted with, nay have not o much as well view'd, that, you mut either laugh at my implicity, or think me a great admirer of my elf, if I hould credit what you ay. To convince you of either your errour or palpable flattery, of many, I need onely give you this one intance, that, when
I my elf, and others whoe judgments I dare trut, think I do not ing tolerably well, you would make me believe, that my voice hath rais'd you into ectaies, when another would not have a minute's patience to hear me. Nay, Madam, replies he, take heed your reproaches rebound not upon your elf, diparage not your elf o far, and light not Truth o much as to call her by any other name than her own; you have an admirable voice, and the ubject of the words you ung mut needs be uch, ince it is not to be imagin'd you ung them in vain. To make them perfect, there needs onely the mixture of a little jealouie, were it not that the happy man, upon whoe account thoe words were made, knowing your worth, cannot give you any.

Upon this the Lady remov'd from the place where he was, that he might more commodiouly proceed in her dicoure with Don Alexander, (though he knew him not) for he imagin'd he could not talk at that rate without ome ground. Which made her ay to him, If you make any comparion between that enchantment you peak of, and the upicion you eem to have, I can aure you, that you are very well read in the art of Flattery, and therefore I beeech you, attribute not a melancholy humour I am ubject to, to any regret occaion'd by the abence of any peron, for I was never yet troubled with any uch thing, and I think hall not as long as I live. I would give all I am worth in the world, ays he, conditionally what you ay were true. Would your hazard be very great in that, replied he? Very little, aid he, conidering the account upon which I proffer it; but I hould ay
no les were I poes'd of all the world, and think it well betow'd. I am extremely happy, anwers the Lady, to hear things o highly poken to my advantage; but I hould be trancendently vain, to imagine I hould raie love in any peron before I am een by him: nay, I dare promie you, that if you had een my face, you would not haply be o reolute. My hearing cannot deceive me, replies he, and I preume, that the peron, who is o excellent to atisfie that part, may be the like in other things, which the envious night permits me not a view of at preent. And when you conider, that in the dicoure I have had with you, I have not talk'd of beams, nor plendor, nor us'd thoe expreions, which they eem to have tudied; who with affected Hyperboles, make it their buines to flatter and abue Ladies, you hould in ome meaure aure your elf, that I begin to conceive an unfeigned paion for you. Well, to humour you a little, ays he, I have ome inclination to believe you, which will be much confirm'd, if you tell me who you are. I have a deire, aid he to her, firt to deerve it by my ervices, that, in cae there may be any thing wanting in me, as to Quality, thoe I hope to render you may upply the defect. Nay then I am atisfi'd, aid he, that you are a peron of Quality, when you have uch a ditrut of your elf. Pardon me that I am forc'd to leave you, for I hear my elf call'd to receive ome company newly come into the houe, and if I hould not immediately be gone, ome would come and find me here. Do me the favour then, ays Alexander, to give me leave to wait on you here to morrow at
this time. I know not whether it may be in my power, aid he to him, however do you not fail to come hither; and though omething may prevent my giving you the meeting, yet hall I think my elf very much oblig'd to you. I hall infallibly expect you, replies the enamour'd Gallant, more fix'd in my reolution than the Stars, you ee, are in the firmament. Your lat words, repli'd he, if I cannot-leep to night, will find my thoughts a diverion to deceive the dull eaon; but when you come next, I beeech you, be not o liberal of your Hyperboles, me-thinks they grate the ear, and I think all that ue them great Flatterers, and conequently no great honourers of Truth, epecially conidering how meanly I deerve.

Having aid thus, and given him a very obliging alute, he got out of the Balcony, leaving Alexander in a little diturbance, to ee that he left him o oon: for he was extremely taken as well with the excellency of her voice, as that of her dicoure. He had a great deire to know who he was, and he had the ame curioity concerning him, for he immediately commanded a ervant to follow him, and not to return till he had dicover'd who he was: which he did without much trouble, inamuch as not far thence, he aw him get up on hore-back, and knew him, and preently return'd with the news to his Mitris, who was over-joy'd to hear it was Don Alexander, of whom he had heard uch noble things, and een behave himelf o galantly at the Hunting of the Bulls.

Don Alexander, being come home, enquir'd of a Neighbour of his, who that Lady might be to whom
he had poken; and decribing to him the place where he Liv'd, he undertood her name was Donna Iabella, (the Sir-name, for ome reaon, I hall forbear) a Lady of great repute in the City, and of extraordinary endowments, whoe undertanding was equal to her beauty, Daughter to one Don Berenguel Antonio, a peron of great fame for his long ervices in the Wars, who having quitted the Military life, and Married, well advanc'd in years, had left that fair Daughter, who was then Fatherles and Motherles, with a very inconiderable fortune; in regard her Father's etate conited mot in Penions betow'd on him by King Philip the Second, in requital of his Services. This Lady liv'd with an Aunt of hers, an ancient Gentlewoman, who for the mot part kept her Bed, and was then retir'd to that Country-houe, to look after her Silk-husbandry.

Thus was Alexander fully inform'd of all he deir'd to know, though he had already had a particular accompt of the perfections which made the City of Valentia full of dicoures of her Beauty and Wit, which was uch that he had the reputation of writing good Veres, a quality very recommendable in a peron of her Sex and Quality. Alexander had never een her, and was very deirous to do it, even before he had een her; and undertanding he Liv'd at that Country-houe, his deire was the more enflam'd: which made him Ride abroad the oftner, hoping to be favour'd with uch another opportunity as he had met with before. But he had not that happines a good while, her Aunt being o ick, that he could not tir out of the room where he lay. About fifteen days afterwards, the old Gentlewoman being
a little recover'd, he had the liberty to go and ee the Profeion of a Nun, at the Royal Monatery of Zaida, which was not far from the Country-houe: At which Ceremony all the Gallantry of Valentia, of both Sexes, was preent. Donna Iabella came thither alo, but having her face cover'd with her Mantle, and attended onely by one of her Women, he got into a little obcure Chappel.

Alexander, on the other ide, who fail'd not to be there, hoping to meet her, on whom he had faten'd his affections, wondred very much that he found her not among the other Ladies; and upecting he might be one of thoe who were retir'd into that Chappel, and had their faces cover'd with their Mantles, he went in to them, with two other friends, to whom he aid, (preuming it was he as oon as he aw her) The new-made Nun is not much oblig'd to thee Ladies, who retire to a place, whence they cannot ee thoe Ceremonies, which all the ret are o deirous to do: but I attribute this indifference to the little inclination they have to become Nuns. Iabella was not a little pleas'd to ee Alexander, whom he had before oberv'd in the Church, and wih'd not o well attended as he then was. However, changing her Voice, he return'd him this anwer. Being not invited to this Feat, we cannot expect the ame welcome as thoe that are: And for the little curioity we dicover to ee the Ceremonies ued, at the reception of a Nun, having een the like everal times before, we do not much mind this, in regard the eeing of it but once is enough to atisfie a peron inclinable to be a Nun. Nay then, I ee, ays one of Alexander's
friends, that you are not of their number who have a deire to enter into that Profeion. I have no Anwer to make you as to that, reply'd he, ave that a peron cannot enter into this tate of Life, unles he be thereto called by God, a favour I do not yet find in my elf that he hath done me. We may then, replies Alexander, infer from this dicoure of yours, that you are not Married, but deirous to be o. What my inclinations are, as to Marriage, aid he, I am not oblig'd to give you any accompt, who are very far from being related to me o nearly, as that I hould acquaint you with my reolution in a buines of that concernment. However, you may atisfie us o far, Madam, ays Alexander, as to let us know, which condition of Life you would rather chooe. Which I pray, Sir, would you advie me to, aid he to him?
That of Matrimony, ays Alexander.
What, whether I have the accommodations requiite to enter into that tate, or not? reply'd he.
If all be wanting, ays he to her, you mut endeavour to forget your elf, for he who is not born to be a Nun, and cannot be Married, mut remain Newter, as being uncapable of both. I could very well follow that advice, aid he.
But if you pleae, Madam, ays Alexander, to dicover, what your Mantle permits us not to ee, I will give you a better advice.

Coming up nearer her, as if he were confident of that favour, he met his deires, and purpoely gave him a full view of one of her fair Eyes, which Alexander's two friends alo took notice of. If the advice you intend to give me, aid he, hould
prove to my diadvantage, 'twere better, I hould till continue undicover'd, though to hear your advice, I hould not think it much to anwer your expectation. That can do you no prejudice, ays Alexander to her, in regard we have oberv'd ome things which aure us, that you ought to chooe the tate of Matrimony, in which you would make the peron you hould think worthy your enjoyments, the happiet Man in the world: Nay, ere I know any more of you than I do already, I wih my elf the peron, for whom that felicity is reerv'd. His two friends affirm'd the ame thing on their own behalf, being extreamly atisfy'd with her Wit, and the little they had een of her Face, Can there be any happines comparable to mine, aid he, who have three uch handome Perons at my Devotion, of whom it is in my power to make one the happiet Man in the World? Well, Gentlemen, ince you cannot expect I hould make a udden choice in a buines of this concern, you will give me leave to examine your everal perfections, that I may pitch upon him, who, in my judgement, may pretend to mot.

Upon that every one began to celebrate his own worth, and undervalue his Competitors. They pas'd away ome time in that pleaant dicoure, without any offence taken, though the place they were in hould have minded them, that ome other Converation would have been more uitable: But now a-days, young people are grown to that height of Profanenes, that they make little difference between Churches and Exchanges. But the Lady having had the patience to hear what every one had to ay on
his own behalf, he anwer'd them altogether, thus; I am fully inform'd of the qualities, and deerts of Perons every way o excellent; I am now to advie with my Pillow, to know which of the three I hould prefer, though to tell you the truth, I have in a manner reolv'd upon my choice already, finding in my elf a tronger inclination for one of the three than for either of the other two. The peron I mean hath many excellent qualities, but the particular inducement I have to think him worthy my approbation, is, that I know him to be a very great Wit; all I have to object againt him, is, that he fears I am already engag'd to ome other, whence I infer he is jealous, and conequently of an ill nature.

Alexander immediately apprehended he poke of him, reflecting on what had pat in their dicoure the firt time he had een her. The time being come for people to go out of the Church, the three Lovers out-vy'd one the other to find out paionate complements to take leave of the Lady, Alexander purpofely taying to be the lat, onely to whiper thee words to her. 'Tis too great a Tyranny, Madam, towards a Servant o paionately yours, in o long time not to vouchafe him a full ight of you: I beeech you, be more kind to him hereafter, leat your further didain may have ome fatal effects on him. The indipoition of an Aunt, reply'd he, whom I mut contantly attend, I hope, you will think an allowable excue; and what I tell you is much more true, than the expreions you make to me of your Love. But I will endeavour your atisfaction, and put a period to your complaints,
when, poibly, you leat expect it. Alexander had not the time to make her any Anwer, and o he parted from her, leaving her deeply in Love, and extreamly deirous to dicoure with him more at leiure.

Some few days after, Fortune favour'd her with an opportunity to her own wihes, at the ame Balcony where he had poken to her the firt time. As oon as he perceiv'd Alexander, he came down, and they dicours'd a long time together without any interruption. The effect of this interview and long conference, upon Alexander, was, that his Love, before little better than kindled, now broke forth into a flame. Iabella came not much behind him, yet had that command of her paion, as not to grant him the greatet kindnes that can happen between perons of different Sexes, though it were out of this onely reflection, that to have done it, at the firt interview, would have argu'd uch a compliance and eaines of Nature, as no Violence of affection hould ever be able to excue.

Alexander being now fully atisfy'd that Iabella was both a great Wit, and a great Beauty, writ everal Love-letters to her, and the better to expres his paion, he alo ent her ome Veres of his own compoure. Iabella knew, that Alexander, among o many other qualities he had acquir'd, was alo skilful in Poetry, and conequently was the more urpris'd and atisfy'd therewith. Some of his Miives he very modetly anwered in thee tearms.

p.hi: THoe Commendations which trancend the merit of the Peron on whom they are betow'd, do rather injure, than oblige, and diparage the judgement of the Giver, in as much as the Receiver, thinking her elf unworthy the honour, jutly takes the Elogy for a Satyr. I am not o much a Stranger to my elf, but that I can ditinguih between Flattery and Truth; nor am I o poorly conceited of my elf, but that I think I deerve omewhat of the praies you give me. I hall think it an obligation, if you abate ome part of what you tell me, and find out a mean between exceive praie and contempt, for the former my own imperfections advie me to look on as an abue. I have no great experience of your dipoition, and therefore think it not trange if I give not the credit you expect to your Poetry, becaue it is the Language of Fiction; nor yet to your Proe, becaue it proceeds from the ame Author, who, 'tis very likely hath read Romances. Whether they were the dictates of a incere Affection, or an obliging Complement, it is onely in the power of Time to dicover, and with all to aure me, whether I am to acknowledge your civilities, or reent the injury you have done me.

div.p: The fair Iabella found out an expedient to convey this Letter into the hands of Don Alexander, her newly caught Gallant, who, deirous to et himelf right in the opinion of his Mitres, and aure her of the luency of his tyle in things of this kind, caus'd the Meenger to tay, and take along with him this Anwer.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p:
I See then, Madam, o that you procure your own atisfaction, you care not what inconveniences I may run into; ince that to be more moderate in your praies (as you eem to deire) cannot be without o much the greater prejudice to my reputation, in that I think my elf far hort of trancendency, in that particular, and I am forc'd to bring in the exces of my Love, to upply the defects of my Poetry. That I may therefore be no more guilty of uch a crime, I will henceforth expres my elf in Proe, and in ome meaure do what you command me in your Letter. You would find it no great difficulty to believe me, if you knew what I feel; nay though out of modety you pretend to be ignorant of it, I defie you to do it, unles withal you reolve never to conult your Glas any more. Well, Madam, it may be the time of your converion is not yet come, when it hall, your eyes will be opened, and you hall find, that, of all the
hearts, ubdu'd by the charms of your Beauty, mine may haply be the least, but withal the mot paionate captive. Time, which gives all things their birth, perfection, and period, hall be the Touchstone, to try whether this be Truth or Fiction; nay I leave it to the ame old Gentleman to aure you of a thing, you yet pretend to be ignorant of, which is, that, while I live, you hall be ole Sovereign Mitres and Directres of my Inclinations. And then haply good nature, gratitude, and generoity will rather advie you to acknowledgements of the love I bear you, than a reentment of the injuries you charge me withal.

div.p:
This Letter gave Iabella that atisfaction concerning her new Gallant, which he expected. The frequent viits were continu'd of Alexander's ide, and the Epitolary correpondence on both ides: o that the inclinations they had one to another were, by thee degrees, heightned into a noble flame of mutual love. His Mitres commanded him above all things to keep his pretenions to her very ecret, which he inviolably promis'd to do. Nay he was o crupulous as to that particular, that if in the Church, or ome other publick place, her Gallant did o much as cat his Eye on her, in the company of ome friend, he immediately imagin'd, that he acquainted him with his paion; and, as if he had heard all their dicoure, he fail'd not to end him a Letter concerning it, if he could not ee him time enough, that he might receive her reproaches himelf. Alexander
clear'd himelf the bet he could, till auring her of the contrary; and enflam'd with love and indignation, all he could do was to dipel that diffidence, which troubled him extremely. But the ame Love, which is wont to reconcile the leer differences and diatisfactions that happen between Lovers, helps them alo out of the greatet and mot difficult. 'Twas Alexander's deign to marry this Lady, though her fortunes were very low: but he delay'd the doing of it, till he had effected a buines he was then engag'd to proecute. His Uncle and himelf had done the King very coniderable ervices in Flanders, for many years together, and he was then making his applications to his Majety for ome Command in compenation thereof. And the obtructions and delays he met with in that affair contributed more to his after-happines, than the expedition could have done, as will appear anon.

Iabella had taken order that he hould not be een in the treet where he liv'd, much les look up to her window to be een by her, and it was punctually oberv'd by Alexander, who was not known to have given her a meeting any where. But he her elf was the firt forgot what he had enjoin'd; it happen'd thus. During the time of the Carnaval, which, in Valentia, is celebrated with Macarades, Balls, Tiltings and Diguizes, Alexander had in ome of thee met with his Mitres, yet without dicovery of more than ordinary kindnes between them, though they had talk'd, and danc'd together. One evening, after the Ball, there was to be a meeting of certain Ladies, at the houe of a Friend of Iabella's, to which he with ome others had been
invited. Alexander and ome other friends of his were to be there, not in order to any Ball, but onely to dicoure. Iabella came there betimes before any of the ret, and oon after her a Woman, very umptuouly attir'd, attended by two Gentlemen-Uhers of her own retinue, whom her mother had ordered to wait on her to that Neighbour's houe, who was very much her friend. Alexander coming into the Room, was very kindly receiv'd by the Ladies then preent, whom he endeavour'd to entertain the mot lovingly he could, till the ret of the Company were come in. The Lady who came in lat rie from her eat to go and look upon a piece of Tapitry, that was in the room, wherein there were repreented lighted Torches; the admiration he expres'd at the excellency of the workmanhip, oblig'd Alexander to come alo to ee it. There was pen, ink and paper upon the Table; Laodamia (o was the Lady call'd) took the pen in her hand, and drew everal troaks upon the paper; Alexander took occaion to commend all he did with uch high complements, that his Mitres, who was already poes'd with a jealouie, to ee him o near her, was almot ready to burt with indignation to hear them. He, minding onely his own diverion in all he did, took no notice of it; nay on the contrary, being acquainted with Laodamia, through her Brother's means, whom he often viited, and a peron of much freedom in his behaviour, he continu'd his gameome humour, and natch'd out of her hand a pen he was making to write withal. After which, having dah'd a little ink upon her hand, he jetingly told her, that the blacknes of the ink never appear'd les
than it did then. She pretending to be dipleas'd at that freedom, gave him a clap on the houlder with her hand, to get off the ink; but perceiving he laugh'd at the revenge he had taken, he gave him another harder than the former. Iabella, who minded their jeating more than what was aid to her by the Mitres of the houe, (with whom he was then dicouring) tarts like a fury from her eat, and not conidering what he was doing, gave Alexander uch a blow over the face, that his noe bled. The poor man was extremely tartled at it, and all he could do was to take a handkerchief out of his pocket, to receive the bloud; telling his Mitres, very coldly, Well, Madam, you ee, I have kept the ecret you committed to my trut; you have firt reveal'd it, and trangres'd the Law you had made your elf. Concluding this reproach with a low Congy, he quitted the Room, and went home.

Iabella had no ooner given the blow, but he was infinitely troubled at it, not o much out of the repect he bore to the Mitres of the houe, who was her intimate friend, as for her, who had occaion'd her jealouie. In this Interval, her Siters, upon whoe accompt this meeting had been appointed, coming into the houe, Iabella had the opportunity to retire with her friends into another room.

Being got together, onely they two, My dearet Iabella, ays her friend to her, what do you think of? How are you grown another peron than what I have ever known you? I have hitherto admir'd your modety and reerv'dnes; how you hould now be guilty of uch a micarriage in Behaviour, is the matter of my atonihment. The action you
have done, aures me, without your peaking, what, in many words, you hould hardly have peruaded me to. I was ignorant of this Affection of yours, becaue you ever kept it ecret; and ince I know it by this dicovery, I am more oblig'd to your Jealouie, than your Friendhip. Alexander is a peron of worth and quality; I am very glad he is your Servant. You may hence-forward publickly own him, for it is to no purpoe to diemble.

Iabella was at uch a los, that he knew not what to anwer: but having a little recover'd her elf, I mut acknowledge, my dearet Acquaintance, repli'd he, ince this eruption of my jealouie and indignation hath betrai'd me, that Alexander is my humble Servant; my inconiderate paion, hath, to my hame, dicover'd what I kept not onely from your knowledge, but that of all others. I mut acknowledge, I ay, that Alexander erves me with a violent paion, which yet exceeds not the affection I have for him. I never aw him o indifferent, as he dicover'd himelf in this lat action; his familiarity with Laodamia touch'd me to the quick. That hort fury, which we commonly call jealouie, forc'd me to that extravagant dicovery of my love. Since what is pat cannot be re-call'd, ays her Friend to her, let us find out ome remedy to alleviate the inconvenience, for it is not fit we hould be depriv'd of Alexander's good company, nor he of the pleaure of this meeting. Beides, we hould not give Laodamia the time to make any reflection on this accident, or conceive apprehenions which would be diadvantageous to you. What is to be done in this conjuncture, repli'd
the jealous Lady?
The onely way I can think of, ays her friend, is, immediately to write to him. She follow'd her advice, and ent him thee Lines.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p: JEalouies, when they are really the effects of Love, though expres'd with ome harhnes, are rather to be accounted favours than affronts, by a Lover, whoe oul exhales a incere paion towards his Mitres. The injury I have done my elf in wounding my reerv'dnes, is greater than the violence you will do your elf in paing by what is now pat. It much concerns my reputation, that you immediately return to the Meeting. But if you perit in your reentment, you will have further occaion, if the los of my favour may give you any.

div.p: A Meenger was immediately ent with this Letter to Alexander, who expres'd much gladnes at the receipt of it, and, without any recollection, obey'd his Mitres, as being atisfi'd in mind, that nothing dicovers a real paion more than jealouie. He comes very gaily into the room where the Ladies were, which Laodamia perceiving was not a little troubled, for he doubted not of his being in love with Iabella, though he thought o well of him as to wih he had rather addres'd his affections to her elf.

Alexander, finding himelf in the preence of Iabella, thought it not fit to peak to any other, ere
he had firt aur'd her of his compliance with her deires. Approaching her with a graceful mile, he made her this complement. I have conider'd this room with as much repect as if it had been a Temple, and your peron no les, ince it not onely kept me from profaning the one, and offering any violence to the other, but alo from revenging my elf by that kind of Duel, which the Law permits between Gallants and their Mitrees.
Iabella repli'd, Being o much, as I am, a Servant to Madam Laodamia, I have taken upon my account the affront you have done her, when he would have hewn you a kindnes, never thinking of any Law that permits a man to revenge himelf of a Lady by way of Duelling. Laodamia, knowing that that indicreet action of Iabella's proceeded meerly from her jealouie, would not be engag'd in her excue, o that he very confidently made anwer thus. There was never o great a familiarity between us, Madam, as might oblige you to take my part with o much paion, in an occaion wherein I hould not have wanted confidence to revenge my elf: but not knowing any thing that hould oblige me to jealouie, and thinking not the affront done to me o great as you would peruade me it were, my precipitation was not accordingly o great as yours. I am very glad you make me the riddle of your interpretations; let them be thought uch by whom you pleae, but for my part, I have already given them a more eaie olution, uch as none in the company can be ignorant of. Iabella not a little mov'd at the freedom of that dicoure, would have repli'd; but the Mitres of the houe unwilling
the difference hould go any further, interrupted them, and oblig'd them to it down, for everal other Ladies were coming into the room.

Alexander was, that night, not onely very umptuous in his habiliments, but alo full of excellent dicoures, inomuch that there were few Ladies in the company, who were not much taken with him, among whom Laodamia was the mot concern'd of any. Her thoughts were full of what had hapned between her and Iabella, and hew was now reolv'd to ue all the artifices he could, to get away that Gallant from her: wherein at lat he had her deire, as hall be een anon.

All the favours which Alexander receiv'd of his Mitres, were done by her with extraordinary demontrations of affection, for indeed the Lady had a greater kindnes for him than any other, though at that very time he lov'd another abent Gentleman, whom he had granted more particular favours than ever he had Alexander. For the Gallant then abent had receiv'd of her by way kindnes, what in matrimony is called Benevolence, and conequently had he not been lot to all modety, he would have kept the promie he had made him, ince the breaking of that and her own Reputation were not ditinct actions.

This Gallant of hers, whoe name was Don Fernand Corella, had made a journey to Madrid, to proecute a Sute at Law againt the Count of Concentayna, his Uncle, for a coniderable Etate in Lands, which at lat was decided in the Sovereign Council of Arragon. He was return'd to Valentia, with a Decree to put him into poeion of the aid Etate,
which amounted to two thouand Crowns per annum. Iabella was extremely put to her hifts, not knowing how he hould keep in with both thee Gallants, and atisfie them at the ame time. She conider'd that her Honour was engag'd with Don Fernand, and her Love with Alexander: her affection being o much the more heightned towards the latter in requital of his aiduous attendances, as it was remitted towards the former, by reaon of his abence. So that it is as much a miracle to ee ome Women forget their engagements, (when they to whom they are made are once out of ight) and mind onely the preent enjoyments, as to ee Geee go barefoot.

But as drowning perons will catch at any thing, and the ditres'd are commonly glad of any advice. This Lady, whom we repreented before one of the greatet Wits of her Nation, reduc'd to this extremity, mut needs advie with a Maid, whoe fidelity and ecrecie he had great aurances of, reolving in her elf to find out ome expedient, whereby he might make ure of the one and not loe the other. She receiv'd Don Fernand into the Houe, in the night, thinking he could not civilly deny him the reiteration of a kindnes he had once granted him; and he kept the other in hand with Love-letters, allowing him not to ee her as often as he deir'd, as well to add fuel to his love, as that the other, whom he was more oblig'd to favour, might have the freer acces. Her excue to Alexander was, that he wanted not over-eers, that her friends were very hie in point of Honour, that one of them watch'd her day and night, and that the greatet pleaure he could do her, was, to forbear paing through the treet where
he liv'd, till he had aur'd him that the coat were clear. Alexander who really lov'd her, and upected nothing of the impoture, eaily credited all he aid, and punctually obey'd her.

Don Fernand was willing to require the kindnes he had receiv'd from her, by marrying her; but having a mother alive who would not have been well pleas'd with that marriage, he took occaion to put it off, hoping it would not be long ere he were remov'd out of the way, as being very ancient. So that he pas'd away the time very jocundly with his Mitres, while he, by her cunning ininuations and artifices, endeavour'd to bring Alexander into a fool's paradie, and make him believe all proceeded from affection.

There hapned about this time a difference between Alexander and another Gentleman, of the mot eminent about the City, whoe name was Don Garceran, as they were playing at Tennis. Some Friends interpos'd between them, and 'twas conceiv'd they were made friends; but the reconciliation prov'd uch as neither was atisfi'd. Alexander was a peron of a generous open nature, grounding his gallantry on the emploiments he had had in Flanders, and imagining that no man, having any thing to ay to him, would do it otherwie than by the ways of Honour. But his Adverary, conceiving he had more reaon to be offended than the other, who had not expres'd o much reentment, mother'd his malice, in hopes of an opportunity, wherein he might revenge himelf with advantage.

Don Fernand was gone to a certain place in the Country, where he taid three or four days. Iabella,
who had a great kindnes for Alexander, ent him word to come to her houe in the night, but o ecretly and with uch caution that none might perceive it, inamuch as the freedom he gave him, concern'd her reputation in the highet degree. The Amorous Cavalier obey'd her in this, as he had done in many other things he had commanded him, coming thither at uch hours as it was not likely any hould ee him. Thus, by his credulity he promoted the deigns of the ubtil woman, who would craftily make the mot of both her Gallants, o that, preventing their being jealous of one another, nay, knowing that they were Rivals, he gull'd them both. Had he been free to make her own choice, no doubt, he would have pitch'd upon Alexander for her Husband. But Fernand being aforehand with her, he could do no les, though 'twere onely out of a fear to loe him, and prevent the reproaches he might make her, than keep him till in play, and expect the performance of the promie he had made to marry her, as oon as his Mother were march'd off. But out of an apprehenion that even then he might poiblv break his word with her, he thought it prudence, to give Alexander alo a little more line. Upon thee coniderations, he uffer'd her elf to be courted by both: but of this kind of demeanor this Age affords but too many examples, which have bred great troubles and diturbances in the mot coniderable Families.

Alexander being now more kindly entertain'd by his Mitres than he had been, began to conceive a hope to obtain of her, within a hort time, the Grand Favour can be expected from a Woman. But he
reckon'd without his Hotes; for it was her fear, that, if he oblig'd him in what he o much deir'd, he might become abolute Mater of thoe inclinations, which he had o dextrouly divided between them both. However Alexander pas'd away the time pleaantly enough, during the abence of Fernand; but as oon as he was return'd to Valentia, Iabella began to put on a greater reerv'dnes, and would not be o much as een by Alexander. She made him uch plauible excues for it, that he, loving her as he did, believ'd all he aid, though not without ome upicion, that there might be omewhat ele in the wind: upon which account he often diguis'd himelf, that he might, undicover'd, viit the treet where he liv'd in the night. But he never could meet with any peron, of whom he might conceive any jealouie; yet that diguie did him a courteie; for by that means he ecap'd being dicover'd by the Cavalier who ought to be reveng'd of him. That he met not with Fernand in that treet, proceeded hence, that Iabella, fore-eeing all inconveniences, had ordered, that Fernand hould come to her houe, through that of a She-friend of hers, which was in another treet, and had a back-door, leading into a Garden joining unto Iabella's, in whoe embraces he pent the whole night.

It hapned, one night, that Alexander being in the treet where his Mitres liv'd, his Adverary, Don Garceran, attended by two of his ervants, comes into it by another way. Being not well aur'd it was he, they follow'd him at a ditance, being loath to do another that michief which they onely intended him. Alexander at lat oberv'd them, and finding
himelf unfurnih'd with Pitols, to deal with perons who never went without them, as having onely his Sword to defend himelf, he bethought him to make the ignal he was wont at Iabella's door, who, as good luck would have it, was come down tairs, after he had put Fernand into bed. She looks out at the window, to ee what her econd Gallant would have, who, as oon as he perceiv'd her, deir'd her immediately to open the door, otherwie he was a dead man, in regard Garceran, his enemy, follow'd him, and he was detitute of weapons to defend himelf. The Lady imagin'd that Alexander would onely have put a trick upon her, and onely aid o, that he might come in the ooner: but Alexander, with many oaths, affirm'd he aid nothing but the truth, and that Garceran, with two others, were coming upon him. Iabella was extremely troubled at his dicoure, and for anwer, told him, that a certain Gentlewoman of her acquaintance was come to ee her, and to be her Bedfellow that night, and that he durt not open the door, let he might be een by her. Alexander pres'd her the more to do it, aggravating the danger he was in, and charging her that he had little love for him, when he deni'd him entrance into her houe in o great an extremity, which the greatet tranger in the world would not have deni'd him. Iabella told him again, that he could not do it without prejudice to her reputation; that as to the Love he bore him, be needed not doubt of it, ince it could not be greater than it was, and call'd Heaven to witnes, that he was extremely perplex'd, that he could not atisfie his deires. Alexander told her, that ince her friend was in a room above-tairs,
he might without any cruple open the door, and let him tay below, till uch time as he might retire with afety.

p.U: eeing him o importunate, imagin'd it proceeded from ome upition he had conceiv'd of her, and that he had een Fernand coming into the Houe. To be aur'd whether it were o or no, he look'd into the Street, and aw the three Men who puru'd him, and whipering one to another, as being in ome uncertainty whether it were the Peron they look'd for. Thee circumtances fully atisfy'd her, that Alexander was in very great danger; and to find ome expedient to give him entrance, he bid him expect a little and he would ee whether he could open the door. She went up tairs to ee Fernand, who, wondring at her tay, ask'd her what occaion'd her going down. She told him her Aunt was not fallen aleep, and that he could not come to Bed, till he were, deiring him to have a little patience.

div.p:
Having thus atisfy'd him, he went into another room, to conider with her elf what might be done in uch an extremity. On the one ide, he aw Fernand poes'd of her Bed, a peron of a fantatick humour, yet one whom he was engag'd to, and had made Mater of the mot precious thing he had, and till humour'd out of a hope to be one day his Wife; o that her Honour was on his part. On the other, the Love he bore Alexander would have prevail'd with her, not to uffer him to be aainated by his Enemies, which he mut run the hazard of, if he reliev'd him not, it being in her power to do it: So that he was trangely ditracted, not knowing
whether he hould follow the dictates of Honour, or thoe of Love. At lat, after divers coniderations, that of Honour prevail'd with her, and oblig'd her not to receive Alexander into the houe. For if he did, he reflected that her reputation would be endanger'd two ways; one, that it could not be done without Fernand's hearing of it, who would thence take occaion to break his promie; another, that if Alexander were puru'd by his Enemy, and that he hould ee him come into her houe, he would be apt to make an ill contruction of it, and that might come to the ears of Fernand, even though he aw him not.

Having thus reolv'd to tick to the urer ide, he went down tairs, and finding Alexander till at the door, My dearet Love, aid he to him, Heaven's my witnes, how willing I am to atisfie your deires, by giving you entrance, not onely into my houe, but even into my heart, which is abolutely at your dipoal. I ee you are puru'd, as you told me, but it were too great an inconvenience to me, that you hould be een coming into my houe at uch an uneaonable hour, being a peron yet o unblemih'd in my reputation as I am. I beeech you conider with your elf what dicoures it might occaion. Beides my Friend, who is my Bed-fellow this night, is awake, and, as Women are extreamly inquiitive, he will be deirous to know the occaion of my tay, and who hath kept me o long from her, for there is a very great familiarity between us. Pardon me therefore, that I cannot grant your deire; it is the greatet affliction imaginable to me, that I mut leave you in uch a danger,
but reflecting on that of my reputation, I know you would not have me to hazard it, ince I doubt not but you are o generous, as to prefer my Honour before your own Life.

This unworthy treatment of his Mitres, in o preing an extremity, went to the very heart of Alexander, nay he was o tartled to find himelf thus undeceiv'd, that it would not have troubled him much if Garceran had et upon him, that he might be reveng'd of the affront done him by Iabella, by Dying before her Eyes. I hould never have imagin'd, aid he, parting from her, that you could have been o barbarous, as to put me off o poorly in o dangerous an exigency, or o inexorable, upon the entreaties of o faithful a Servant. You never had any real kindnes for me; that reputation you tand o nicely upon, would have run no hazard, either as to your Friend, or my Enemy, by your receiving me as a Husband, upon which accompt only I made my addrees to you, upon which if you, ungrateful Woman, had entertain'd me, and not inited on frivolous repects grounded on uch maxims as I cannot like, my heart had at this time been abolutely at your dipoal. To make it deervedly uch, hath been the main end of all my Courthips and Services, but Heaven would not permit it; and ince I could find no compaion in your heart, I will go and try what I may expect from my Enemy, with a reolution never to forget a procedure I am o much atonih'd at.

Iabella would have made him ome Anwer, and, extreamly mov'd at his dicoure, was reolv'd to hazard all, to aure him of her affection. But when
he went to call him, he was got a great way down the treet, puru'd by Garceran, who being aur'd he was the peron he look'd for, was going to et upon him. His reentment of her unkindnes, conidering the imminency of the danger, eem'd jut to her, and being extreamly troubled thereat, after he had blam'd her elf, he quarrel'd at Heaven, which in the mean time ecur'd her Lover from danger, and reerv'd him for happier adventures. Garceran coming within Pitol-hot of Alexander, perceiv'd that he had met with his Friend Don Jaymo, who, with his Servant, was going home to his Lodging, which prevented him from executing his deign. For Garceran being, in appearance, and that before everal perons, reconcil'd with him, all would have blam'd him, had he aaulted him upon the old accompt, epecially at advantage, and with Fire-arms. So that eeing he had lot uch a fair opportunity to revenge himelf, he lipp'd aide, to avoid being known, imagining he had not been dicover'd. Alexander related the whole tory to his friend, and how he had been puru'd thither; which he much wondred at, eeing Garceran o little minded the engagement he had made before o many perons of quality, and that o light a buines hould tick o cloe to his heart.

It was by this time very late, and as well for that reaon, as to be atisfy'd of what he upected, Alexander being near Don Jaymo's Lodging, reolv'd to take part of it that night, which his friend was very glad of. They got in, and ere they lay down, they fell into dicoure about what had pas'd. Alexander open'd himelf to Don Jaymo, and acquainted
him how things tood between him and Iabella. Don Jaymo had heard omewhat of the mutual love there was between her and Fernand, and was vex'd to ee his friend had o far mi-plac'd his affections, and particularly at the reolution he had made to Marry her; whereupon he could not forbear telling him what he had heard of her and Fernand. Which Alexander undertanding, he immediately preum'd, that the reaon why he opened not the door, mut needs be, that her former Gallant was with her. A thouand paages came into his mind, but he particularly reflected on the prohibition, which the crafty Gentlewoman had made him, of peaking to her in the night, and that it was onely ince Fernand's return from Madrid: Upon which communicating his thoughts to his friend, they joyntly concluded, that Fernand mut needs be in the Houe with her.
