To be fully aur'd of it, they ordered a Servant of Don Jaymo's to examine the buines, and to continue in the Street, till it were Day: and for further certainty, another Servant was appointed to tand centry in the other Street, by which Fernand was wont to get in at a back-door. With this precaution, they went to Bed together; but Alexander was in uch a diturbance, that he could not leep a wink. About half an hour before Day, one of the Servants brought intelligence, that he had een Don Fernand going out of the Houe belonging to Iabella's Friend, and that about the ame time, he had een Iabella in one of the Windows that look'd into that Street, looking on him as he went out, and that he was ure it was no other than he her elf. This accompt atisfy'd Alexander
o fully, that all the Love he formerly bore that impudent Woman, immediately vanihed. 'Twas not imaginable, that Fernand frequented that Houe, upon the accompt of the Mitres of it, who being turn'd of fifty, could not be courted by any Gallants. Beides, he had the reputation of being a very charitable peron in Love-affairs, and was wont to promote the enjoyments of younger people, and to give excellent directions how they might mot cautiouly accomplih their deires.

The night following, Alexander would himelf, from the Houe of a certain friend of his, ee Fernand getting into the Sanctuary of that charitable Sollicitres, and for his further aurance, he lay perdue upon the Roof, whence he dicover'd, that that favour'd Gallant continu'd there, till word was brought him that he might make his entrance into Iabella's. That very night, the diembling Goip, would needs endeavour to atisfie her Lover, as to the diatisfaction he might jutly have conceiv'd of her. To leave nothing unattempted, and to keep in as near as might be with all, he ent Alexander a Letter, by a Servant-maid, in whom he repoed great trut, and who was not a tranger to the Loves of both the Gallants, and promoted the deign of her Mitres in abuing them, for the advantage he reaped thereby. Hearing he taid to peak with him, he call'd her up, and receiv'd from her a Paper containing thee words.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p:
I Should not think the reentment you jutly have againt me o great as I do, were I able to expres the trouble I am in to have been the occaion of it. That I have not been o compaionate as the exigency requir'd, be pleas'd to attribute to the tendernes I had for my own Honour, the conideration whereof made me inexorable. I love you beyond my own Life; but one of my Birth and Sex may be pardon'd, if he acrifice all things to the ecurity of her Reputation, rather than expoe her elf to the cenures of ill Tongues. You may well imagine, when I deny'd you entrance into my Houe, that my good Name must run a trange hazard with that troubleome Bed-fellow, whom, to my unhappines, I was then forc'd to entertain. Notwithstanding the reentment wherewith you left me, you could not but oberve the distraction I was in: whence you may infer, how thankfully I have ince acknowledg'd the indulgence of thoe higher powers, who recu'd you out of a danger, which I thought unavoidable. You could not have lost your Life in that adventure, but mine must have run the ame hazard, and I do not know any thing but Honour,
which I hould prefer before two things I accompt o pretious. Let me therefore conjure you, to mother your reentment of it, and to appeae your indignation: which if I may obtain of you, I hall think all the devoirs your Love may require little enough to requite it. Your compliance with my deires herein will inform me what tendernes you have for her atisfaction and Life, who prays Heaven to preerve yours, as he wihes it may her's, who loves you with all her oul.

div.p: Alexander was extreamly incens'd at this Letter, and though he did all he could to diemble it, yet the Maid looking on him very earnetly during the perual, ufficiently oberv'd it in his getures. He intreated her to walk into the Garden, and tay for an Anwer, which was this.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p:
YOur atisfactions, hitherto, have ever heightned my Love, but this last hath wrought in me a quite contrary effect, for I know it to be as far from truth, as I am from diimulation. I never thought my elf a peron to be entertain'd onely to pas away the tedious interval of another Man's abence, nor to act the ridiculous
part you have put me upon, onely to come upon the Stage, between the everal Acts of your ecret prostitutions. If it be any atisfaction to you, know, I have diengag'd all reentments of your Hypocriie, and hall never complain of the frivolous Eluions, wherein you uffered my Love to Languih; no, I am more oblig'd to your Denials, than ever I hould have been to your Carees. My Life indeed would have been ecur'd, if you had receiv'd me into your Houe; but my Honour would have been irrecoverably lost, if, without my dicovery of it, you could have exercis'd your Charity on two everal perons, the ame night. 'Tis very probable you lov'd me beyond your own Life, when, being o cloely engag'd to another, you thought me the fittet Peron in the World to make your Diverion. I am really oblig'd to thoe who intended to be my Murtherers, ince by their means I came to dicover your impoture. Make ure of that fortunate Gallant, whom your charitable Neighbour was uhering to your Bed, while I was knocking at your Door. Make ure of him, perfidious Woman, and henceforth, keep all your Cares and all your Carees onely for him. Live as happily with him as the Concience of your Inhumanity towards me will permit, and never think more of Alexander, who, for his part, diclaims all future thoughts of you.

div.p:
It was not long ere this Letter came to the hands of Iabella, whom the Maid found in that Neighbour's Houe of hers, through which Fernand had acces to her. She receiv'd it with ome diturbance, and asking the Maid, what humour he found him in, he told her, that he had made her a very cold Reception, and that he expres'd nothing of the Kindnees he was wont to do, at other times. Iabella a little cat down at that dicoure, It eems then, aid he, I am not to promie my elf any great atisfaction from this Letter. Having open'd and read it, he was like one put into a fright, not able to peak. Her Friend ask'd her what it contain'd? he thinking it too great a burthen, to acquaint her by word of Mouth, gave her the Letter to perue. The old Croney, no les diturb than the young Mitres, found, that Fernand's love was dicover'd, to the great diadvantage of her Reputation, in as much as it clearly expres'd, that it was through her Houe, Fernand made his approaches to her Friend, whereat he was extreamly afflicted. Iabella was o troubled at the contents of that Letter, that he curs'd the day and hour he had uffered Alexander to court her: The onely comfort he could raie to her elf, was, that he knew him to be of o generous a dipoition, that, though he had a jut occaion to be incens'd againt her, yet would he conceal her weaknes, and not publih the correpondence there had been between them. This kind of generoity might haply be a little practis'd in the Golden Age, for the people living in this, have o far forgot the Tradition, that they aggravate Truths deplorable enough, with affected Lies and Calumnies, for which we mut
ever acknowledge our elves oblig'd to the ruling Cauits of the Times.

But Iabella's unhappines was not yet come to its height, and the malice of her ill fortune thought not this affliction heavy enough. When the wheel of that vagabond-Goddes begins to turn, every poke of it brings a new misfortune, one digrace coming till in the neck of another. It happen'd then, that as the Maid was coming out of Alexander's lodgings, to bring the Letter to her Mitres, Fernand aw her with it in her hand, he having been careles to hide it, becaue he was dis-atisfi'd with Alexander, who had onely that time omitted to make her ome preent. Fernand immediately began to upect omewhat, and, undicover'd, follow'd her to the houe where Iabella was, and got into one of the upperrooms, without any bodie's taking notice of it. The Maid, by a econd overight, having left the door open, he eaily aw what pas'd, he heard the Letter read from one end to the other, and withall, their everal dicoures and comments upon it; the afflicted Lady burting forth into indignation at every word, and not imagining he was over-heard, he ufficiently expres'd her reentment of o preing a misfortune.

The Gentleman in the next room, who would have been glad of any occaion to break the promie he had made to marry her (for a Lover once admitted to enjoyment hath other-guie thoughts than he who is till kept in hope) hearing all thee things, conceiv'd them a very fair pretence to diengage himelf. He therefore goes very confidently into the room where they were, and addreing himelf to
Iabella, who was mot tartled at his preence, I expected, aid he, conidering the mutual obligations between us, that you would have correponded thereto, with a incerity utable to my deires, which aim'd onely at this, to ee us one day made one by marriage, and to enjoy thoe pleaures lawfully, and without any ting or remore, which we have, upon hopes of the accomplihment of that acred Tie, preum'd to anticipate. But ince, ungrateful creature, I find you lot to all modety, and have entertain'd new Gallants, I am free, to dipoe of my elf as I hall think mot convenient: ince it were neither jut, nor rational, I hould be ineparably bound to a peron, detitute of all conduct and honour, and o live the ret of my days in perpetual jealouies and ditruts.Having o aid, he left the room, a little troubled at the ditraction of the Women, but well atisfi'd in his own thoughts, that he had drawn his neck out of the collar, that is, hifted himelf out of an affair, which bred him a great deal of trouble, ince his proecution of it to that point had been with the di-approbation of his Mother.

'Tis not to be imagin'd, that the contancy of any Woman, hould be able to endure o great a hock of misfortune. Iabella fell into a wound between the arms of her Friend, and continu'd in it a long time; but at lat being come to her elf again, he poke uch things as rais'd a great compaion in her who heard them. She ought for remedies to her miery, and not finding any trong enough to re-engage Alexander, who was acquainted with her former engagement, nor yet to bring back Fernand, whom he
knew he had offended, he was not able to mother the grief he conceiv'd to find her elf o jutly lighted by both. She imputed all her misfortune to her own mis-government of her elf. Whereupon he fell a tearing of her hair, and poke what-ever rage could inpire into a Woman exaperated in the highet degree.

She pas'd away the ret of the afternoon in continual diquiet, not finding any comfort in either her friend's dicoures, or her own. In the evening, he went to her own houe, but her ditractions went along with her, o that it is not to be imagin'd but the night prov'd as retles, as the day had been unfortunate. Let us a while leave her in her bed, now the ecret Remembrancer of her former micarriages, in the midt of her troubles and tranportations, and give an account what became of Alexander.

As oon as he had dipatch'd away the Maid with his Letter to Iabella, he ate down a while to conider with himelf what coure he hould take, for he aw there was nothing to be expected there, and that it was not for his reputation, to continue his viits any longer. He had always had a great inclination for the fair Laodamia, ever ince he had occaion'd Iabella to break forth into that extravagant dicovery of her jealouie; He conider'd he was a Gentlewoman well decended, and of a great fortune; and thereupon he reolv'd to make his addrees publickly to her, by demanding her in marriage of her Father and Brother, which they, upon the firt motion, very willingly granted, even with great demontrations of gladnes, inamuch as Alexander was a peron generally belov'd in his Country, as being endu'd with
thoe qualities, which deerv'd the repects and eteem of all. The Contract of Marriage was oon drawn up, and the buines immediately pread over the whole City of Valentia.

But when this news came to the ears of Iabella, imagine whether he were not extremely troubled thereat, nay o much the more, in that he pitch'd on the peron, whom of all the world he had mot reaon to hate, ever ince that fatal meeting, wherein he had expres'd o much indicretion. She aid a thouand things againt her, and made many imprecations againt him and her elf, charging Heaven with injutice, and ometimes bemoaning her elf, and ometimes curing her misfortune. But it was not onely one he had to cure; for the very ame day it was econded by another, yet greater, inamuch as Fernand, having had a plauible occaion to break the promie he had made to her, treated about a marriage, with another fair and rich young Lady, whom his mother had long before recommended to him. The Contract was in a few days drawn up, and though done as ecretly as could be, yet was it oon known all over the City, and it was not long ere the news came to the ears of Iabella. She till retain'd a lender hadow of confidence in the love of Fernand, which made her imagine he would not break the promie he had made to her, conceiving he had ufficiently oblig'd him thereto by the highet demontrations of love and tendernes. Thus he flatter'd her elf, till the very day that he was clearly convinc'd of the contrary, aw his marriage concluded, and her elf abolutely foraken. But reflecting on the other ide, what an unworthy breach of trut he was guilty
of, towards him, to whom he had devoted her honour, how could he imagine he hould not leave her in the lerch? How could he expect, if they intermarried, he hould be able to live with her in perpetual diturbances and alarms? The very day that certain news was brought her of this Gentleman's being married, he fell into uch extravagance, that he would be reveng'd of her beautiful face; he gave her elf everal blows, tore her hair, and did all the actions, which could onely proceed from madnes and dipair. Her fair eyes became two fountains, perpetually running; and when her ighes and grief gave her a little freedom of peech, Wretched woman that I am, would he ay, of whom all good fortune hath taken its lat leave; how deerv'dly is thy ingratitude requited with ingratitude? How jutly art thou punih'd, for having kept thy faith to a bae, treacherous, and perfidious peron, after thou hadt entruted him with the dipoal of the dearet thing thou hadt in the world? Thou ee't, he denies the debt; thou ee't, he paies it with incontancy and oblivion. Let all eaie-natur'd, and inconiderate women take example by me; let thoe, who, deluded by flatteries and feigned carees, are drawn in to loe what they hall never recover again, cat their eyes on my miery, and then conider whether there be any other in the world, whoe affliction may be compar'd to mine. I wih for what all others abhor, Death; but it is deaf and inexorable, nay lights me, and will not come and put a period to my troubles.

Having thus bemoan'd her elf into ome remiion of her grief, he went to ee her Friend, through
whoe houe Fernand came into hers; who though he endeavour'd all that lay in her power to comfort her, yet was her trouble o great, the caue of it o preing, and o little hope of any remedy, that all her remontrances prevail'd nothing. The onely expedient that eem'd then to offer it elf, was, to forbid the Banes, ince there was ome ground to do it. But what proof could be made of o ecret a Love, without any promie of marriage in writing, or any tetimony, but that of a Servant-maid, who, belonging to her, would not have been o eaily credited? A fair warning-piece, Ladies, for thoe, who, at the ame time, admit the Courthips of everal Gallants, without making any reflection on their Honours, the los whereof they are not enible of, till, by their ubtil cajollings, they are brought to remediles extremities. The lat and uret expedient this unfortunate Woman could pitch upon, was to become a Nun, upon which account he was receiv'd into the Royal Monatery of Zaida, three days after the Marriage of Fernand had been fully concluded.

This udden change occaion'd a great deal of noie and dicoure in Valentia; all wondred at it, epecially thoe who knew her to be one of the handomet, and the mot deirous to be courted, of any Lady in Valentia. It was indeed a kind of miracle, to ee a young Lady, who pent her time o paionately at Balls, Plays, and other publick meetings, exchange all thoe nobler enjoyments of life, for the imaginary felicity of mortification and retir'dnes. This udden reolution was attributed, at firt, not to the true caue thereof, for things were carried o cloely that very few knew it: but to the ecret inpirations
of that wind, which bloweth where it liteth, and is pleas'd to amue mankind with the trange ways it takes, to tranplant the affections of uch as are ordain'd to eternal blis, from the tranient vanities of this world, to the contant puruance of the perpetual joys of a better. Thus this Lady met with a kinder Spoue than he could have expected ele-where, and pent the ret of her time with great content bleing her former afflictions, and the croes of her love, which had brought her to the tranquillity he now enjoy'd. When he eriouly reflected on the gracious deigns of divine Love upon her, he thought it an act of gratitude, to acknowledge, to ome friends, how it had made her micarriages the ubject of its indulgence, and, intead of punihing, had rewarded her weaknes; nay uch was her deire to give God the glory of her converion, that he frequently ued this expreion, That in that Houe, wherein there are many manions, he hop'd there was one for uch penitent Magdalens as he, who, by timely repentance, expiate the follies of their greener years. Nor was this acknowledgment of hers unrewarded even in this life; for he became the Oracle and piritual Directres of all thoe, whoe Lovemisfortunes reduc'd them to any extremity, epecially thoe of her own ex, of whom he o effectually convinc'd many, that, diguting the world, they embrac'd a Religious life. After ome years he was advanc'd to the Government of the Monatery, after he had put forth everal little Tracts of Devotion, whereof one was in Vere, entituled, A Basket of Spiritual Flowers, or a Collection of Divine Poems. Thee pread her fame into divers parts of Spain, but
at Valentia, the anctity of her life, and her charitable directions to uch as had occaion to addres themelves to her, were the admiration of all, inomuch that he was reputed a Saint, even while he liv'd.

Fernand had a wife, but God was pleas'd to punih his perfidiounes with her barrennes, for he bore him no children; and intead of the great fortunes he expected with her, he had many bags, full of Law-utes, troubles, and differences with other people, and not a few dicontents with his wife. He wih'd, but too late, that he had rather entred into a Monatery, than into Matrimony, the inconveniences whereof ufficiently convinc'd him, that Iabella had made the better choice. He viited her often, and was oblig'd to her for her prudent and pious admonitions. Nay to atisfie the world, that he had left behind her in it all her reentments of his demeanor towards her, there are in a volume of Spiritual Letters which he put forth, everal Letters he had written to him, upon occaion of ome difficulties he had propos'd to her.

On the contrary, Alexander was the happiet man in the world in his dipoal of himelf; his Laodamia brought him many fine children, and, by the death of ome friends, a far greater fortune than he could have expected. They alo viited their old acquaintance Iabella, who received them kindly, and gave them occaion to admire the trange attractions of Divine Love in that peron, and the eteem they had before for the excellency of her endowments, was now converted into a reverence of her anctity, and an admiration of her conduct.

THis pleaant Novel entertain'd the Company till they came to their Inn that night. Every one took occaion to commend Doctor Monalvo, as well for the martnes of his Invention, as for the excellency of his Stile. The old Gentleman told him, that if the whole Piece were anwerable to the Pattern he had hewn them of it, no doubt but his Novels would be very well receiv'd in the World, and that he would gain as much Reputation by them, as they had had Pleaure: and thereupon he earnetly entreated him to communicate omewhat of the others to them, that o their Travelling might be the les tedious. The Doctor gave him and all the ret of the Company his very hearty thanks for the good opinion they had of him, and proffer'd them, when they hould be weary of dicouring, to divert them with ome of the other Novels, till they came to their Journey's end, provided they thought them not tedious. They all, with much gladnes and thanks accepted of his proffer.

Being come within a Musket-hot of the antient City of Corduba, heretofore the chiefet of the Kingdome, while the Moors were poes'd of all Spain, after Sun-et, an unexpected accident caus'd them to make a little halt. Two Gentlemen being come out into the Fields, upon a challenge, which one had ent to the other, and having fought, one of them was worted, being run through the Body in two everal places; which had oblig'd his adverary to make his ecape, to get into ome place of anctuary. The wounded peron cry'd out for ome body to receive his Confeion, jut as the Coach pas'd by: which being heard by the Company, Doctor Monalvo,
who was a Priet and Confeor, could do no les than get out, accompany'd by Garay, and Mitres Rufina, who had a great deire to ee the Wounded man. They came to him, and as oon as the Doctor had receiv'd his Confeion, and given him Abolution, he lot his Speech, being upported by Garay. The Doctor return'd to the Coach, and having called everal times upon Rufina, who pretended he could not get away Garay, the Coach-man perceiving it began to grow dark, put on the Hores, having ent them word what Inn they hould take up. Rufina was much troubled to ee the Coach gone, having left her and Garay behind, charitably exhorting the Dying peron to recommend himelf as much as he could to the mercy of God; but he was o far gone, that, to pare them further Exhortation, he gave up the Ghot. They were much troubled what they hould do with the Body, when certain Officers of Jutice came in, who, having at a ditance een the Dead peron in the Arms of Garay, and a Woman tanding by, and had notice before that two Men were een going out of the City, with a deign to fight a Duel, preently imagin'd, that Garay was one of them, and conequently the Murtherer of the other; upon which preumption, he was ent to Prion, and order given the Jaylor to put him fat enough. Rufina had more favour, being confin'd in the Houe of one of the Officers, who was to have a care to her forth-coming. They both us'd all the arguments they could to clear themelves, from having any thing to do with the Murther, alledging upon what occaion they came to the Body. But their own words would not be taken, and it was preum'd
the Duel had been upon the accompt of Rufina The Judge order'd her to be brought to his own Houe to be further examin'd, which was accordingly done. When he came thither, there were in the Room everal Gentlemen, and among others a Genoee, a very rich Merchant, whom ome buines of his own had brought thither. They had no ooner een Rufina, but they all admir'd her Beauty and the Majety of her Air, but the mot atisfy'd of any was the Genoee, who, to give him his due, was of a very amorous contitution. Rufina was extreamly troubled that uch an affront hould be done her by the way, as perceiving that if they were taid the next day, they hould loe the opportunity of continuing their journey. The Judge put everal Quetions to her, concerning the Duel, and the Gentleman's Death; whereto he anwered, that he knew nothing of it, that he was coming in the Sevil-Coach, to go for Madrid, accompany'd by ome other Perons then in the Inn, whom he named; That as the Coach pas'd by, a certain Peron, who had been Wounded upon the High-way, not far from them, call'd out for ome body to receive his Confeion, and that a Priet who was with them in the Coach, went out to do it, with whom alo he went out of curioity, accompany'd by an Uncle of hers, who came along with her. They ordered, in regard it was grown late, to adjourn the buines till the next day, that a more exact enquiry might be made into it, and, in the mean time, that all who came along with the Coach, hould not tir from Corduba, without permiion. This done, Rufina was brought back to the Officer's Houe, where he was to continue
that night. The Genoee, who liv'd not far from it, accompany'd her; but though he had liv'd at a far greater ditance, he would have thought it no great way to wait on a Lady, with whom he was already over head and ears in Love. Taking leave of her at the Officer's houe, he proffer'd her all the Services lay in his power, for which he thanked him, yet taking it for no more than a Complement. The Vexation he conceiv'd at her being thus unexpectedly taid, brought her into ome fits of a Feaver, the firt, of a Tertian, which he afterwards fell into.

The next day, all the perons, who came in the Coach, being examin'd, gave the ame account as Rufina had done before, whereupon Garay was et at Liberty. Other witnees alo who knew omewhat concerning the Duel, were heard, and gave the Judges a perfect knowledge of the Murther. Garay went immediately to viit Rufina, expreing himelf extreamly troubled at her indipoition; he did all he could to cheer her up, that they might proecure their Journey: but the Phyitian, who had viited her, advis'd her not to remove thence, till he had recover'd her Feaver, and told her, that he could not travel any further, without hazard of her Life; which being o, the Coach-man was forc'd to leave them behind, but they were adjudg'd to defray the charges of their tay, and he to deliver up what they had in the Coach. The Genoee came often to ee the fair Traveller, at the Officer's houe, and began to treat her very nobly, an humour the more remarkable in him, who, for ordid niggardlines might be compared to the covetous Marquina; but Love,
though but a mall Deity, yet many times does very great miracles, turning Avarice into Prodigality, and Cow • rdice into Courage.

Rufina kept her Bed fifteen days, during which time, he was contantly viited by Signor Octavio, (o was called the amorous Genoee) and after the Viit, came in a Servant with a treat of Sweet-meats, and Wild-fowl, which the Officer and his Wife were glad to ee, for the bet hare fell to them. At lat, the Lady, with her Health, recover'd alo her good Complexion, and her Beauty, and the Genoee continuing his civilities, proffer'd her a Houe with a fair Garden, which he had on the ide of the pleaant River Quadalguemir. Garay, whom he called her Uncle, advis'd her not to refue that proffer, for he had dicover'd the Man to be extreamly in Love with her, that he was very Rich, and that they might get as much out of the Genoee, as they had out of the covetous Marquina. Rufina accepted the proffer, and et things in order to go to the Genoee's, and to continue there till he had recover'd her elf o well, as that he might proecute her Journey. The Genoee would not have it known at Corduba, that he had brought her to his Country-houe, to prevent peoples talk, and other inconveniences that might have enu'd. So that, with the conent of Rufina, he gave out, that he had left the City in order to the proecution of her Voyage. Accordingly, there were two Mules brought for her and Garay, and two others to carry their Luggage, and having left Corduba, towards the Evening, to blind the eyes of the inquiitive, they kept on their way towards Madrid: but having Rid out about half a League, they turn'd
back again, and took up their quarters at Signor Octavio's, which was not above two flight hots from the City. There he expected her, with a magnificent Supper, which he had provided. Here the Genoee dicover'd his Love to her more freely than he had done before. He was a peron of about forty years of Age, of a good Manly countenance, having buried his Wife ome two years before, by whom he had had no Children. He was a whole-ale Merchant, and traded in all orts of Commodities, inomuch that all the other Merchants, not onely of the City, but alo of other places thereabouts came to him, for he held correpondences in all parts. He was a very thrifty peron, nay, to give him his due character, I hould ue other expreions. He had ome yearly Revenue, beides twenty thouand Crowns in ready Money, and ixty thouand in Credit, and his own Trading, which was very great. He was a great Student, and had tudied at Pavia and Bologna, before he became Heir to his Brother, who Dy'd a very Rich man in Spain, and that Inheritance it was, that occaion'd his Marriage at Corduba. He had o paionate an affection for Rufina, that he ued all the ways he could imagine to ininuate himelf into her favour. Upon that accompt it was that he proffer'd her the ue of his Country-houe, to take the Air, and recover her Indipoition, conceiving, that, being at his own Houe, it would be the more eaie for him to compas his deires. She had been told by Garay, that this Merchant was a well-feather'd Fowl, and might be eaily pluck'd, and ince this good Luck had fallen to them by chance, they hould make the bet advantage they could of it.
That night, they onely Supp'd, and every one went to his ret, for it was very late. The Genoee made as if he would have returned to the City, and lye there; but his Servants, whom he had before intructed, peruaded him not to go abroad at that uneaonable time of the Night, for fear of meeting with any Thieves: beides, there being a Pres in the City, many young Men preum'd to do michief in the Night, and robbed all they met. At lat, being peruaded not to tir out, he was glad to pas away ome part of the Night in dicouring with Rufina, and being got to Bed, his buines was to conider, by what means, and with leat charge, he might obtain his deires of her. Several things came into his mind, but the eaiet he could find, uitably to his humour, was to forget her, and never think of her any more; for he knew the Age we live in to be uch, that it is a miracle to get any kindnes in Love, without Liberality.

The next morning he commanded omewhat hould be made for her break-fat, not imagining he was up: But when word was brought him that he was out of Bed, the Genoee would needs go into her Chamber, to chide her for riing o oon, and by that means to ee whether Rufina's beauty were any way oblig'd to artifice. He found her kembing her head, and o he had a full ight of her hair, which was of a great length, and of a Chetnut colour. The Genoee gave God thanks, who, with o many other perfections, had betow'd on her uch an excellent Head of hair: but he was much more atonih'd, when, upon her dividing them into two parts, to make him an anwer, he aw her Face, as beautiful as
it had appear'd to him when he went to bed; a thing able to enflame a peron les enclin'd to Love and more to Avarice than he was, inamuch as there is not a greater charm, to ecure a Lover's heart, than to ee that the beauty of his Mitres is natural, and corns to borrow any thing of Art. Rufina indeed was not much troubled to look after waters, paints, pomatums, unguents, and uch things, wherewith uch women, who tand in need of them, haten on their age with their wrinkles, and loe their youth ere they are aware. She onely wah'd her elf in fair water, and needed no other vermilion to heighten the beauty of her face, than that of her own lively complexion. The Merchant ask'd whether he would be pleas'd to ee his Garden? She made anwer, that he was extremely oblig'd to him for the trouble he gave himelf to divert her; and to atisie him how kindly he took that favour at his hands, he went along with him jut as he was, without putting up her hair, which hanging down over her houlders, added much to her beauty, and it is not much to be doubted, but he had a deign in it. She went down with this new Gallant of hers, who thought it an extraordinary pleaure to have her by the hand; and in that poture he aw the whole Garden, eeming to be much taken with the delightfulnes of it.

Having recreated her elf with him, till the Sun Sun began to be omewhat hot, he return'd into the houe, and broke her fat, after which, having dicours'd of everal things, he deir'd to ee the whole houe. The amorous Genoee deiring nothing o much as that he might ee his wealth, hews her a great number of excellent Pictures, done by the bet
Painters in Europe, ome very rich pieces of Tapetry, Cabinets of Ebony, of everal fahions, embroider'd Beds, and all orts of Houhold-tuff of great value. In a word, there wanted not ought of thoe things requiite for the furnihing of a houe fit for a Nobleman. Having een all the rooms, he open'd a curious Cloet, near which there was a little Oratory, and in that Cloet there were a great many pieces of Painting, done at Rome, of extraordinary value, Agnus-Dei's of gold and ilver gilt, and Flowers, done as near the life as could be imagin'd. The Cloet was full of Books, very richly bound, and neatly dipos'd into gilt Drawers. Garay, who was a curious peron, and had read much, was looking very earnetly on the Titles of the Books, which were in one Drawer, and having put that into its place, he took out another, wherein there were others very curiouly bound, but had no Titles on the backs. Garay opens one of them, and finds the Author of it to be Arnaldus de Villa Nova, and near that were the works of Roino, Alquindus, and Raymundus Lullius. The Merchant perceiving him o taken up with the perual of thoe Books, ask'd him what he look'd on o attentively. I find here, Sir, replies Garay, a great many Books of Chymitry, and, from the curioity I oberve in your collection of Treaties of that kind, I infer, that you have tudied that Science. 'Tis true, ays the Genoee, I have pent ome time in the perual of thoe Authors; but how far, I pray, are you acquainted with them? Onely o far, replies the other, that I have pent the bet part of my life in that tudy. Nay then, ays the Genoee, you mut needs be a very great Chymit.
I am not to acknowledge what I am, replies Garay, we hall talk another time of thee things more at large; for the preent, I hall onely tell you, that, beides thee Authors, I have read all I could ever meet with that treated of this Science. I have turn'd over the works of Avicenna, Albertus Magnus, Terno, Pythagoras; the Secrets of Calidus, the Book of the Allegory of Morillus, that of the Secret Stone, and that entituled, De tribus verbis; beides many Manucripts, which I never hew'd any man. The Genoee was almot out of of himelf for joy to hear thee things. I am extremely glad, aid he to him, that this Science pleaes you, for I have a particular inclination for it. I know it very well, replies Garay, (which he aid, having already reolv'd how to put a lur upon him) but in regard I place a great confidence in you, I will tell you a thing in your ear, which you will be much atonih'd at. It is this (whipering him in the ear) that my Niece knows, without any tudy, in a manner as much as I do of this Art, and is very fortunate in the practick part of it, as you hall ee by experience. But I entreat you not to peak to her of it at this time, for he would not have it known to any, nay would not take it well. Garay could not have pitch'd upon a more likely way to bring the Genoee into the gin; for his avarice was uch, that he would have parted with his Soul to find out the Philoopher's tone, hoping, if he once got that ecret, ever afterwards to wim in gold.

Rufina buied her elf at the other end of the Cloet, while Garay made this dicoure to the Genoee,
and was looking upon ome other curious and pleaant Books, for there were of all orts. Yet was he not o attentive, but he heard omewhat of Garay's dicoure, concerning Chymitry, and perceiv'd the Merchant was much taken with it. The truth is, Garay had ome knowledge in that Science, and that he had pent a coniderable um of mony, to find out the Philoopher's Stone, which though many had ought, yet could not any affirm they had met with it. The ucces he had had in that buines onely atisfi'd him of their folly, who pent their time and etates in o ridiculous a diquiition, and he was glad to have met with uch an opportunity, to recover ome part of the mony he had quander'd away therein: for the Genoee, crediting what was told him by Garay, imagin'd himelf omewhat above a Prince. He told him, that, in that very houe, he had all things requiite to make the experiment, and thereupon brought him into a room full of Furnaces, Alembicks, Glaes, and Crucibles, with all the intruments us'd by the Chymits, and good tore of char-coal. Garay eeing that, concluded the Merchant would be eaily taken, and what made him the more confident was, that he imagin'd he undertood all thoe Books, whereas Garay was atisfi'd he knew onely o much of them as would erve to bring him into the nooe. In fine, they gave over talking of it any further at that time, though the Genoee was unwilling to quit the dicoure. They went down thence into a ground-room, the windows whereof look'd into the fairet part of the Garden, where dinner expected them. After dinner, Garay, pretending it was his cutom to take a nap, left the Merchant alone
with Rufina, to whom he took occaion to make a full dicovery of his love, auring her, that all he had was at her ervice, and deiring her to dipoe of it as he pleaed. She eem'd to entertain the proffers of his affection with much kindnes, yet at that time he onely rais'd him into a leight hope, hewing her elf very pleaant to him.

Having een a Lute, in one of the rooms above-tairs, he deir'd it might be brought down; for her Muick, at which he was excellent, contributed much to the bringing about of her deigns. The Merchant, who had a little skill at that Intrument himelf, was very glad to hear that he us'd it, and caus'd it to be immediately fetch'd, aying that his deceaed wife plaid excellently well upon it, and that about a ev'n-night before, having entertain'd ome of his friends with a Collation, they had et it in tune. The Lute being come, Rufina began to play, and made it appear, that there were very few could excel her at that Intrument. The Genoee was atonih'd at her dexterity, and to bring him abolutely to her lure, he ung an Air to it, but with uch a grace, that he was at a los, whether he hould more admire her hand, or her voice. The truth is, he had a particular excellency in both, o that his exceive commendations of them, were not o full of flattery as might be expected from a peron paionately in love. With a modet bluh, which pread it elf gently over her face (a thing he could command, though never acquainted with hame) he eem'd to expres a certain bahfulnes, and ere it was quite dipell'd, Signor Octavio, aid he to him, what I have done was onely for your diverion, be pleas'd to receive
it with ome regard to the deire I had to endeavour your atisfaction; which yet I have not done without much temerity, before a peron of o delicate an ear as you are, and one, no doubt, wont to hear the bet voices in the world. I never heard any, replies Octavio, that came near yours, and therefore I beeech you, let not your modety caue you any prejudice; nay rather be proud, Madam, of the excellent endowments you have o liberally receiv'd from heaven, and acknowledge the favours it hath done you; be more enible of your own worth, and think my approbation below it; and yet when I was a young man, I was much addicted to Muick, and ome would needs peruade me that my time was well betow'd in it. I mut confes, the Spanih Tongue comes not o naturally to me as the Italian, the graces and beauties whereof I have better tudied upon the Theorbo, which I am o far Mater of, as in ome meaure to atisfie the hearer. Whereupon perceiving that Rufina would have laid by the Lute, he deir'd her to make ue of it a little longer, and to ing one Air more, which he, to honour him, did.

Octavio took occaion to give his dear Rufina greater commendations for the excellency of her voice than he had done before, and he, to renew her thanks to him, for the favour he did her. He thought it time to give her leave to take a little ret, and he went himelf into another room to do the like. Garay, on the other ide, intead of leeping, was contriving how to get the Philoopher's tone, not for the credulous Genoee, but out of him. He had o far peruaded him of his abilities, in that Science, that
he deired nothing o much as to be as knowing in it as he was, but all out of no other deign than to atisfie his own inatiable avarice. He imagin'd that if he could find the Philoopher's Stone (a Rock rather, againt which o many have wrack'd themelves) all his houhold-tuff hould be of gold, that he hould become a Croeus, and that the wealthiet about the City, compar'd to him, would be little better than beggars.

Garay had alo a long dicoure with Rufina, about the means how they hould get the Gudgeon into the net: he gave her ome intructions in writing, that the Genoee might find he knew omething of the Science, at leat the tearms of it. Rufina got them by heart, and, to begin the cheat, Garay ask'd for ome links of a Gold-chain he had brought from Sevil. It was a large one, and if there were a dozen links taken from it, they would not have been mis'd. Being come into the City, he goes into a Gold-mith's hop to melt down thoe links, and reduce them into an Ingot, which he brought back to the houe, and communicated his deign to Rufina.

Octavio, who had lept all this while as oundly as if he had not been in love, comes in to them, and they began to talk of everal things, far from having any relation to the buines he had been about, which Garay did purpoely to engage the other to fall firt into that dicoure, and indeed within a quarter of an hour, he was gotten into the ubject of Chymitry. Garay dicours'd of it after the rate of a man that had pent his whole etate in the work; inomuch that Octavio was atonih'd thereat, for though he pretended much skill in the Science, yet could he
not but acknowledge himelf much inferiour to the other. Garay, deirous to give the Merchant all the atisfaction he could deire, told him, that he could turn what Metall he pleas'd into gold. The Genoee was ravih'd at the propoal, and earnetly entreated him that he might ee it done. Garay ask'd him whether there were any char-coal in the houe; the Genoee told him there was good tore, for he had had the curioity to make ome trials thereof himelf. They went up both into the room where they had been before, and finding it full of Furnaces, Creuets, Alembicks, and other Chymical Intruments, Garay aid to him, Here we have all things requiite for the preent. He caus'd ome fire to be brought, and having put a little Copper into a Creuet to melt, the Genoee aw it melting: Garay took a box out of his pocket, wherein there was a paper full of powder, which he aid was the mot principal ingredient in the whole work. He put it into the Creuet, which having brought as cleaverly as he could to a window, he pour'd out the melted Copper, and put the Ingot of gold into its place, and when he had cover'd it, he told the Genoee, that it hould not be tirr'd thence for half an hour. That time they pent in dicouring of everal things in Chymitry, wherein Octavio deir'd to make ome further progres. At lat, Garay thought it time to hew him what he had done, and o opening the Creuet, he took out the Ingot and hew'd it him. The covetous Mier was almot out of himelf for joy to ee it, though he were not fully atisfi'd of its being perfect gold. Garay wih'd him to have it tri'd by a Goldmith; which trouble he would needs take upon
himelf, and having found that it was very fine gold, of twenty two Carats, he returns extraordinarily well atisfi'd. While he was gone out, Garay intructed Rufina, how to effect their deign upon Octavio, who being more covetous than amorous, would have them immediately to begin the great work of finding the Philoopher's Stone. He promis'd Garay extraordinary recompences, and told him, that he would be at the whole charge, though it hould amount to twenty thouand Crowns.

Garay, who had contriv'd how he intended to gull the Merchant, return'd this Anwer to the great proffers he had made him. Signor Octavio, aid he, I am now gon almot even years beyond the grand climacterical year of my life, which is as much as to tell you, that I have pat the greatet and bet part of it. It were no hard matter for me, with the help of the Science I am now Mater of, to pend the little which is yet to come, at my eae, and it may be more plentifully, than ome of the wealthiet Grandees of Spain; and that I can be without any man's favour or aitance, I think you may have oberv'd your elf. And in regard I have no children, to inherit my etate, which, I thank heaven, is omewhat coniderable alo in Lands, the main concernment I have in this world, is to look after this young Woman, my Niece. She is already but too rich, in that he hath all I have, though her Father, who was my elder Brother, left her no mean fortune. She might, had he a mind to it, be as nobly married as he was before, for her late husband was decended from the noblet houes of Andaluia. Nor were it hard for me to add to
her wealth, you know it; but uch is my confidence in you, that I will tell you the reaon why I do not. That I am the ablet Alchymit in all Spain, is known to many, which being alo come to the ears of his Majety, I am ought after every where; but I have hitherto had the happines to keep out of their clutches, who are perpetually emploi'd to find me out, having pread a report, that I was gone • o •
England. It is not out of any contempt of the honours and wealth of this world, that I avoid the earches of thoe, whom his Majety hath enjoyn'd to bring me to him, but out of this conideration, that I would not purchae any favour with the los of my liberty, for I mut expect no les, than to pend the ret of my days in a noble kind of captivity. I will expres my elf more clearly to you. His Majety hath at the preent very great Armies a-foot in everal parts, which put him to a vat expence, uch as his own Revenue and what comes from the Indies are not able to defray: o that, to atisfie his ambition, he is forc'd to make ue of the indutry of his Subjects. Now were it my ad fortune to be found by thoe who o narrowly earch after me, the King, knowing that, with the aitance of my Art, he might eaily recruit the charge he is at, would immediately dipoe of me into ome Fortres, where being confin'd for the ret of my days, I hould be perpetually kept at work, to augment his Treaures, and upply his preing exigencies. I hould not think it much to do it once or twice, but the avarice of men is grown to that heighth, that they are not atisfi'd with abundance, if they have the
leat apprehenion, that the ource of it may ever be dried up. This is the true reaon, Signor Octavio, which obliges me to keep out of my own Country, and to play leat in ight; and therefore receive what I have told you as a great ecret, uch as I hould not have communicated to my own Brother, had he been in the world: but I have that confidence of you, that you will never reveal it.

Octavio return'd Garay his mot affectionate thanks for the great trut he repos'd in him, and thought himelf o happy in the dicovery he had made to him, that he conceiv'd the greatet Nobles might jutly envy him. His Anwer to him, was, that the grounds and motives, on which he conceal'd the excellent knowledge he had acquir'd, were jut and rational, ince that no doubt but he would be confin'd, though for no other reaon than this, to prevent his carrying over uch a Secret into another Country, to erve a King that were an enemy to his Catholick Majety. He acknowledg'd himelf infinitely oblig'd to him, and wih'd it were in his power to erve him; but having onely the wealth he was poes'd of to proffer him, he entreated him to dipoe of it as freely as if it were his own, and ince he had hewn him a trial of his abilities, that he would not think that enough, but ere he left Corduba, give him uch further intructions, as, being oberv'd, he might not micarry in the great work. Garay promis'd to atisfie his deires, telling him withal, that o precious a thing as Gold could not be gotten but with Gold, and that the foundations of all deigns require charge; that the Philoopher's Stone could not be found without cot and much
pains; that if he were reolv'd, he hould attempt the doing of it, he mut be at the whole charge, and that afterwards the profit hould be equally divided, and that in a hort time he would be glutted with wealth.

The Genoee, ravih'd at that propoal, proffer'd to pend all he was worth upon that accompt. Rufina promis'd to ait them. Nay, ays Garay to her, there is uch a neceity of your aitance; that we hall not be able to do o well without it. They thereupon reolv'd, that within two days they hould begin the great work. Garay told him, that the principal of the divine Elixir, (o the Chymits call the perfection of their work) was form'd of the olidity of Mercury, and other things which he nam'd to him, together with the urine and excrement of a red-hair'd child; that all was to be put into an Alembick, with powder of Aloes, the infuion of Opium, Toads greae, Arenick, and Salt-peter. But he hop'd to do it chiefly with the urine and excrements aforeaid, which he order'd Octavio by all means to procure, as being the mot neceary ingredient of all.

He promis'd to find it, and, to begin the work, the Me • chant deliver'd him five hundred Crowns in gold, to buy certain precious drugs, which he aid were neceary; and this the Genoee did the more willingly, as well out of the confidence he had to receive them multipli'd into o many thouands, as out of a deign he had thought on the night before, of making Rufina his wife, and by that means assuring himelf of Garay. Whereupon, that very evening after upper, he took occaion to carry Garay along with him into the Garden, and acquainted him with his
reolution. The Alchymit thought it a good way to further his work, and accordingly he approv'd of his intention, and acknowledg'd it would be a great honour to his Neece to meet with o worthy a Peron; but that there was one Obtacle to be firt removed. What may that be ays the other?
Garay told him, that his Neece could not be Married, till a Dipenation were firt obtained from Rome, in regard, that, out of the extraordinary regret he conceiv'd at the los of her late Husband, he made a Vow to enter into a Religious life; that the occaion of their going to Madrid, was to receive ix years Arrerages of a Rent due to them from a peron of Quality, who was very backward in paying, in order to her reception into a Nunnery; but that as oon as the Dipenation were come from Rome, they would conclude the Marriage, which he doubted not but he would accept, not onely out of the compliance he had ever expres'd towards him, but alo out of this conideration, that he was to match her elf with a Peron inclin'd to the tudy of a Science, wherein he had naturally attain'd o great perfection. Octavio was the mot atisfy'd Man in the world to have uch a parcel of good words given him, inomuch that from that very hour Garay became abolute Mater of all he was poes'd of.

Garay and Rufina having conferr'd notes upon this new Overture, were more confident than ever, to compas their deign. He freely laid out the Money receiv'd of Octavio in Drugges, peruading him they were not to be had under uch and uch rates. He alo furnih'd himelf with new Furnaces, Creuets and Alembicks, pretending that
thoe in the Houe before, were not for his purpoe. In the mean time, the illy Merchant was enquiring up and down where he might have the Urine of a Red-headed Child, which he had much ado to get; for the Mothers fearing it was to be us'd in ome operation of Witchcraft, would not eaily let him have it; but Money is omnipotent, and can do any thing. Garay could have done as much in one Day as in a hundred, as to the performance of what he had promis'd, but the poor Merchant mut be fool'd ome way or other, till he met with an opportunity to mite him, and take a Dog's leave of Corduba, with as much as he could hift away on two good Hores, which lay Leger in a ecret place for that purpoe.

He dipos'd all the Ditillations into the Furnaces, in the preence of Octavio; he bought ome Metals, as Bras, Copper, and Tin, everal orts of Salts, and other things commonly ued by Chymits; and etting Fire to the Furnaces, they Ditill'd what had been put into them, but contributing nothing to the buines, and only to abue him, who was at the charge of all the Foolery. As to Octavio's Love, he was much better treated than he was before; inamuch as ince the propoal of Marriage, Rufina, the better to carry on the main deign, grew more kind to him, epecially in Garay's abence, which the beotted Cocks-comb was o tranported with, that he knew not whether his head or his heels were on the ground.

About this time Octavio receiv'd a Bill of exchange of a coniderable Sum, to be paid within twenty days after ight. This, with the breaking of
ome of his Debtors in other Countries, put him into ome fear of doing the like, if his attempts in Chymitry prov'd not uccesful. But to prevent all inconveniences, he did what mot of his Quality and Kidney are wont to do, who being upon the point of breaking, ecure what they can of their Etates, that they may afterwards the more commodiouly remove into ome other Country. So our Merchant, finding himelf within ome ditance of breaking, provided for the misfortune, in cae it hould happen, and o promoted the michievous plot of Garay and Rufina, whom he truly acquainted how affairs tood with him, as if they had been his mot faithful Relations. Garay had left in the cutody of a certain friend of the Merchants, a good um of Money, and ome Jewels of great Value, with order they hould not be deliver'd to any but one of them two. Beides which, he brought ome to his Country-houe, and hid them in a ecret place in the preence of Rufina, of whom he had a confidence, as if he had really been his Wife. Garay, who was till buie about his Ditillations, put him into good hope, that within twenty days he hould ee the end of the great work, and his Houe full of Gold, to recover the los he had receiv'd by his Debtors.

About this time, there happen'd a buines which oblig'd Octavio to take a Journey, to advie with a Correpondent of his, how to prevent the misfortune he aw coming upon him. Garay and Rufina being entruted with the Houe, thought it a fair opportunity to dilodge, and make the bet they could of the preent game. They ecur'd all the Money and Jewels they could come at, and left the Plate and
ome other things, they could not o conveniently carry away, behind them, though with ome regret, thinking it more prudence to make a afe retreat with what were coniderable, than to hazard all, by graping at too much. Having therefore loaden themelves with what was mot pretious, they left the Furnaces, and the Alembicks, made the Philoopher's tone at the cot of the abent Merchant, and took Hore while the people of the Houe were fat aleep. They took their way towards Malaga, and travell'd all night, having about them above ix thouand Crowns in Money and Jewels, and left, upon a Table near the Furnaces, a paper of Veres, to haten the credulous Merchant to hang himelf.

Two days after their departure he returns home, very ill atisfy'd with his Journey, in that he had not done any thing in the buines which occaion'd it. All the hope he now had was in his Uncle, Garay, imagining, by his means, he hould yet be able to hew his head, and not onely keep up his Reputation, but alo be Richer than ever he had been, uch a trange Mit had the Witchcraft of Chymitry cat before his Eyes.

He came not to his Country-houe till after Night, where he found the Servant whom he had left with Garay and Rufina, for the ret of his people were in the City. The Servant receiv'd him with a ad countenance, and being got up tairs, he ask'd him (fearing omewhat were amis) where his Guets were, of whom the Servant could give him no account, as having not een them when they went out, and could onely ay, that, two Nights before, they had lock'd him into the Room where he lay, which
he had been forc'd to break open, becaue he could not otherwie get out. They earch'd up and down, and found that the Chets had been opened, and all the Money convey'd away. This was not the wort the Merchant feared, but that they had alo been with him, in whoe cutody he had greater umms of Money, and the mot pretious of his Houhold-tuff. It being too late to make any enquiry that Night, he thought it his bet coure to go to Bed; but deirous to viit the Furnaces once more, he finds on the Table the Paper, left there by Garay, which having open'd, he found in it thee Lines.

body.p:
IT is the just reward of thoe who attempt things impoible, to be hamefully diappointed. Many of your Profeion have been ruin'd by their Faith, in things relating to their Trade; it was therefore but fit you hould repent your Credulity, in a buines you understood not. It was indeed impardonable, to expect to ee that done by any Man, in a few days, which the Sun, who hath a greater power over the Metal you were o covetous of, cannot perfect under four or five hundred years. Your los, I must confes is great, but you have this comfortable conideration, that you may now defie Chymistry, and all its cheating Profeors, to hew you uch another trick as we have done. But, to avoid all future Temptation, take
this hearty advice from two dear Friends of yours; put all the fine Treaties you have of that pernicious Art into your Furnaces, and, having et Fire to them and your Houe together, fairly run away by the light of it.

div.p:
The poor Merchant had no ooner read them, ere he was convinc'd, they were his kind Guets who had robb'd him, and extracted what he had in his Chets and Cabinets with more eae than he had infus'd it into them. How he pent the Night, is onely to be imagin'd, being jut upon the point of Breaking, and not knowing any means to remedy it. All the hope he had, was, that the Money and Jewels which he had left in a friend's hands, were afe enough; nay he depair'd not to find out thoe, who had done him the michief. He turn'd himelf from one ide to another, not out of any diturbance, occaion'd by his Love to the ubtle Rufina, (for that was abolutely lot with his Money) but that he had been o baely trapan'd by a beggarly Racal. Then did he begin to cure Chymitry, and all the Authors that ever writ of it, whereas he hould rather have given God thanks, who, by the cheat which was put upon him, had prevented the proecution of his deign, which might have abolutely ruin'd him. As oon as he perceiv'd any appearance of Day, he got up, and went into the City, to his Houe, whom he had entruted with the keeping of his Money and other things. He ask'd him whether Garay had been with him? the other anwered that he had, and had taken away whatever he had in his cutody, and that
therein he had follow'd his own orders. That word truck him almot Dead; nay the reentments he expres'd of that los were o great, that if the other had not known the caue of it, he would have thought him out of his wits. He comforted him the bet he could, and told him, that his onely coure was to make a peedy earch for the Robbers. He did all he could to that purpoe, ending Officers and others everal ways; but that which Garay and Rufina had taken was o extraordinary, that they could never meet with them. So they return'd to Corduba, to be paid for their fruitles puruit, by him who had ent them, which, as his affairs tood then, added not a little to his affliction. This adventure was oon known all over the City; and the Genoee, not able to accept of another Bill of exchange that had been ent him, was forc'd to abent himelf, and to return to Genua, with what he could make by the ale of his Goods. By this means he turn'd Bankrupt, and defy'd his Creditors, who could not find any thing he had left behind him. The ame thing happens many times to thoe, who, with mall Etates, engage themelves in too great affairs, preuming upon this, that, if it comes to the wort, they can ecure themelves by an ecape.
div.trailer: The end of the econd Book.

div.head: LA PICARA, OR The Triumphs of Female Subtilty.
The Third Book.
div.p:
GAray and Rufina rode on a good round pace, but kept in obcure ways, and, in four Nights, they would not take up their Lodging in any Town or Village, but in open Fields, for fear of being urpriz'd by the Officers, whom they doubted not but the Genoee had ent to enquire after them. They had hifted their Cloaths, and having diguis'd themelves as well as they could, they carefully avoided all thoe places where they had the leat apprehenion they might be known. It
was Garay's charge to provide Victuals; and being about the beginning of the Spring, they found it no great inconvenience, to lye abroad in the open air. They got into a thick Wood jut as the Sun was ready to et, and fearing that a thick Cloud, under which they were, might break upon them with too great violence, as there was ome likelihood, by reaon of the great Thunder and Lightning that had gone before, they went into the thicket part of it, the better to ecure themelves. Other Travellers, upon the ame apprehenion, had taken refuge at a place, near that where Garay and Rufina were. The noie they made in dicouring, rais'd in Garay a curioity to come and over-hear what they aid; and through the means of thick Buhes, being come near them, he perceiv'd they were three Men, one whereof, peaking to the others, aid; If this Tempet lats all night, I doubt we hall be diappointed of our deign. I fear me o too, replies another, and no doubt but the Hermit of la Serre will be out of all patience that he hath expected us o long. O that Brother Cripin is an excellent fellow, ays another of them: his Religious frock covers a great deal of michief, and he is o ininuating in his behaviour, that he is very much in their favour, who betow'd the Hermitage upon him. He is o trancendent an Hypocrite, replies another, that he is able to blind all the World: he hath the reputation of a virtuous peron all over the Country, and there is not within twenty Leagues about a more conummate Villain than he is. I have been acquainted with him thee twelve years, ays the Second, and his profeion
hath been to receive Thieves, and their Booties; and he hath been o fortunate as never to be upected Guilty of any crime of that kind, whereas o many other poor Rogues have been taken and trus'd up, at the firt falling into the hands of Jutice. It mut needs be acknowledg'd, ays another, that his Hermitage is a very convenient place for perons of our profeion, and the Cellar he hath made under it, is uch a place, as the Divel himelf would never find out. We could never have met with a more ecure place, to put up the fifteen hundred Crowns we yeterday disburthen'd the Merchant of. 'Twas the mot coniderable Robbery that hath been committed in this Country of a long time. If it would but hold up a little, ays he who had poken firt, I hope to make as good a Prey, yet before it be Day.They thereupon advied concerning the means how to execute their deign. Garay mis'd not a word of all they had poken; the Country he was acquainted with as well as if he had been Born in it, and very well knew the Hermit, whom, till then, he had accounted a peron of great anctity, o far was he from imagining, that he drove uch a Trade, and that his Hermitage had, for o many years, been the refuge of High-way-beaters, and Houe-breakers.

Having made this trange dicovery, he returns to the place where he had left Rufina, and gave her an accompt of what he had heard from thoe Robbers. They continu'd there without making any noie, they and their Hores, till uch time as the others were gone, conidering with themelves how they might make their advantage of that unexpected adventure:
And taking their way to a blind Inn, not far thence, they tay'd there the remainder of that Night, and all the next Day. Having, in that time, conider'd what they had to do, they went both towards the Hermitage, where Brother Crispin (o was the Hermite named) lived, and being got within a mall ditance of it, Garay bound Rufina to a Tree, upon which he cries out as loud as he could, Is there no body to relieve a wretched Woman, ready to be Murther'd here? O Heaven, revenge the injury done to my innocence. On the other ide, Garay acted his part, aying, 'Tis in vain for thee to call any body to thy relief; thou hat not long to live, and therefore recommend thy elf to God, for thou halt not ecape out of my hands; as oon as I have bound thee to this Tree, I will dipatch thy Soul into the other World.

At the firt noie of her crying out, Crispin hears her, and being all alone in the Hermitage, a thing eldome happened, for, mot nights, he had the company of ome of the tribe, who though guilty of much watching, were not much either of anctity or miracles. The Hermit came out with two good Pocket-pitols, and being got near the place, whence he had heard the noie, he dicharg'd one of them, which happen'd very luckily for Garay. For it being reolv'd upon the quetion between him and Rufina, that he hould run away as oon as any came near them, it might be conceiv'd, the dicharging of the Pitol had frightned him. He preently mounted one of the Hores; and leading away the other, he rid away with all the peed he could. Crispin comes
near the Tree, and, by the light of the Moon, perceiv'd Rufina, weeping mot bitterly, and eeming to be atonih'd, through that fright he was in. Seeing the Hermite coming towards her, What art thou return'd Traitor, aid he? will nothing deter thee from executing thy cruel deign? Come, take away my Life, and put me out of further trouble, and doubt not but one time or other, Heaven, ince it will not recue, will revenge my innocence.The frock'd Hypocrite, hearing this dicoure, and perceiving thereby that he mitook him, made her this Anwer, Madam, I am not the peron you think me to be, but one who comes to relieve you in this extremity, and to ave your Life. What is become of the Villain, who would have taken it from you, and hath oblig'd me, contrary to the rules of my Profeion, to take Fire-arms to purue him, not doubting but what I do will be accompted an act of meritorious charity in the ight of God?

Having thereupon unbound her, Rufina cat her elf at his feet, aying, It mut needs be, Brother Crispin, (for he knew his name) that you had ome revelation from Heaven, of the violence intended me, ince you came o miraculouly to my relief, and that with Arms o contrary to your Profeion. Heaven reward you for the charitable aitance you have afforded an innocent Woman. I cannot expres the reentment I have of the kindnes you have done me, otherwie than by ubmiions and vows, as being oblig'd to you for no les than my Life, which the fury of a Brother
was jut going to deprive me of.

Crispin was extreamly taken with the Woman, (nay notwithtanding his vow of chatity, he had a kindnes for the whole Sex) but he was yet mater of o much modety and reerv'dnes, that he orbore all dicoure of Love and Familiarity; and continuing in his counterfeit anctity, My dear Siter, in the Lord, aid he to her, I think my elf far from deerving all the favours it pleaes God to do me: but I endeavour all lies in my power to Live virtuouly, erving my Creator in this olitary place, where it hath been the pleaure of his divine Majety, that I hould be a means to ave your Life: I heartily thank him for it, and am extreamly glad, that what is done is to your atisfaction. For this night, I can onely proffer you uch a reception as a poor Cell can afford, where you may continue, till you have accommodated your affairs, and reconcil'd your elf to your Brother. I aure you it is abolutely at your ervice, and I offer it you with uch a cordial affection, as a good Chritian ought to have for his Neighbour, for I had not put my elf into this habit, were it not to exercie uch charities as thee.

Rufina renew'd her thanks to him for the civil proffers he made her, burting forth afreh into feigned tears, a thing ome Women can do when they pleae, but this had the knack of it beyond any. She gladly accepted of his kindnes, as what conduced very much to the compaing of her deign. They thereupon took their way towards the Hermitage, and Brother Crispin, eeing Rufina was omewhat
weary, endeavour'd to comfort her with all the kind words he could think of, and at lat took her by the arm, to help her forward. He open'd the door of the Hermitage, and when they were got in, Rufina was not a little atonih'd, to ee a rough Plank, which he pretended was his Bed, with a Crucifix at the head of it, and on one ide, hanging up by a Nail, an Intrument made of good Whip-cord; wherewith his credulous Zealots believ'd that he diciplin'd himelf: all the other furniture of the Room conited in a little rotten Table, which, by much travelling and removing from place to place, had brought four feet to three.

Rufina finding the room o poorly furnih'd, and the peron who made his aboad in it o mortify'd and reerv'd in his behaviour, began to repent her elf, that he ever came thither, and imagin'd that Garay had mi-undertood the conference of the Robbers in the Wood. But the devout Hermit put her out of her dumps, for taking notice of her looking a little trangely on the accommodations of his Houe, he aid to her, My dear Siter, you may haply think this a very poor Lodging, and that you will have but an ill Nights ret; be not troubled, I will Lodge you much better than you imagine. 'Twas your happines to come hither at this time, now that there are not any here upon their piritual retreats, which ome devout ouls of your Sex are wont to make at this Hermitage, ometimes for eight or ten days together. Some of thee, for the greater conveniency of their devotion, have ent hither Beds, and ome other Houhold-tuff.
Incomparable Hypocrite! Having asked her whether he liv'd at Malaga, and he telling him that he was a tranger in thoe parts, he would have peruaded her, that there were Beds in the Hermitage for uch as came to make their piritual retreats there, which was a damnable lie: but the truth of it was, that he, for his own eae, had very good Quilts, and other necearies for a bed or two, for the entertainment of the ecret camerades who came often to viit him. Thee conveniences were dipos'd into a low room, which was alo the Treaury, where thoe birds of prey, put up uch things as the true owners of them never intended hould be acquainted with the place. He thereupon deir'd her to have a little patience, till he went down to fetch ome bedcloaths, which having brought, he made her a bed in a little Cell, at a mall ditance from his own. They had a better upper then Rufina expected, there was ome boil'd meat and broth, and a cold Rabbet, which Cripin pretended had been let at the Hermitage by one of his Penitents, a very devout old Gentlewoman, whom he was infinitely oblig'd to; and to cloe their tomachs, they had ome excellent fruits, according to the eaon.

Rufina was a woman much inclin'd to mirth, but at this time, doing her natural dipoition ome violence, he eem'd to be very melancholly and reerv'd, and o continu'd all the time they were at upper, eating very little, the better to expres her wearines, and being troubled at the accident, which had befallen her. The Hermit in like manner pretended he had no great tomach, whether the meat
was not dres'd to his mind, or that he did it out of a compliance with his fair guet, whom he look'd on o attentively all the time they were at upper, as if he had been to read a Lecture of her Phyiognomy. At lat, having taken away the meat and cloth, the Hermit, deirous to know of Rufina, the caue why her own Brother would have taken away her life, entreated her to atisfie him, which he did in this hort account of her elf.

Though it cannot but add very much to my affliction, to make a rebearal of the occaion of it, yet the kindnes you have done me, my dear Brother, being o trancendent, I hould be a very ungrateful peron, to deny you the atisfaction of ome account of her whom you have o highly oblig'd. I was born, aid he, in the City of Almeria, of noble Parents, my Ancetors having been famous there for everal ages. All the children they had were onely my elf, and a Brother, who is a year older then I am. My Father and Mother left this world, and me in it a little before I was fully arriv'd to the fifteenth year of my age. There were thoe who thought the face you now ee not unhandome, that is in other words, everal perons courted me in order to marriage, but my Brother oppos'd it as much as lay in his power, charging my Sutors with ome defects or other, in their etates or extraction, o that not any one of them obtain'd what they o much deir'd. I believe the true caue of my Brother's refuals proceeded from a deire he had that I hould go into a Nunnery, where I had two Aunts, and he get to himelf
omewhat of the fortune my Father had left me. I dicover'd his deign, by their continual preing of me to become a Nun. But I never had any inclination to that kind of life, and o my Anwer to them was utable thereto; which incens'd my Brother o much againt me, that he never look'd kindly on me ince.

q.p:
While thee things were in agitation, a young Gentleman, who had left Almeria ere he was ten years of age, return'd from Flanders, where, for the good ervices he had done his Majety, he had been advanc'd to the command of a Company of Foot and a Troop of Hore. He came accordingly in a very good equipage, both as to Cloaths and Hores. He had a pretty coniderable etate, and had not receiv'd any thing from it ince his departure from Almeria, o that there was a good umm lay ready for him. He one day chanc'd to ee me at Church, and lik'd me o well, that he enquir'd who I was. Some gave him an account of me, and oon after, he began to make his addrees to me, and to court me by Letters and other ways. To make my tale hort, I was not inenible of his affection, but conidering with my elf the equality there was between us as to birth, and the excellent endowments he was Mater of, I comply'd with his love, and admitted him to come into the houe, but upon the aurance he gave me, that his courthip was really in order to marriage. He viited me with much freedom, for my Brother was then ick of a dieae, which had brought him almot to death's door, (I would it had carried him
quite into that cold room, my condition would not be o ad as it is at the preent.) One of my former Sutors, being not a little troubled to ee a Newcomer o highly advanc'd in my favour, began to watch him, and in a hort time aw him let in and coming out of our houe, at an uneaonable time of the night. He made a very ungentlemanlike advantage of that dicovery; for, envying any other hould have what he could not obtain, he gave my Brother an account of what was done in his houe. One day coming to viit him, and being all alone with him, he told him what he had een. My Brother, who had recover'd a little of his trength, began to get up, and by his own obervation was confirm'd in what the other had told him. Yet could he not be reveng'd of me, by reaon of his weaknes, and put it off to ome other opportunity. He eem'd to be extremely troubled that I had engag'd my affection to that Captain, and proteted that he would have been much les, had I made choice of any other, for he had had ome difference with his elder Brother, and ever ince, they had never been good friends.

At lat, my Brother recover'd his former health, and finding the Captain gone from Almeria, he told me, that he would carry me to ee an Aunt of ours at Malaga, who was a Nun of the Order intituted by St. Bernard. I believ'd him, and not imagining he knew anything of the correpondence between the Captain and my elf, I was very glad of the opportunity to ee that Aunt, whom I was much oblig'd to, for everal things he had ent
me of her own working. We prepar'd our elves for the journey, and rode each of us on a hore, with two ervants on two others to wait on us. Being come into the wood near this place, he ordered the two ervants to go before, to prepare a lodging for us, and being come to the place where you found me, jut as day was taking its lat leave, he threw me off my hore, and put me into the condition you found me in, wherein no doubt I had perih'd, had not you fortunately reliev'd me, for the dicharging of the Pitol made him get away before he had done the work he intended. May God, the requiter of all good turns, remember the charitable aitance you did me, which was o trange, that I hall never forget it as long as I live.

div.p: The Hermit having heard this tory, took occaion to comfort her the bet he could, and promis'd her to do any thing that lay in his power; whereupon they parted for that time, and went to their everal Beds; he, to that which had been prepar'd for her, and he, to another, that lay in a ecret place, very well furnih'd; for, however he blinded the world with an apparent auterity, he was a peron who lov'd his eae as well as any other. He was deeply fallen in love with Rufina, and mighty deirous to acquaint her with his paion; but the fear of candal made him a a little reerv'd. He pent the whole night without any ret, contriving how he might bet make a dicovery of his love to her.

As oon as it began to dawn, he got up and oon after him Rufina, who going into the Church belonging
to the Hermitage, found him on his knees before the Altar, which oblig'd her to do the like, at a little ditance from him. He thought fit to continue his devotion a while, but not without much ditraction, for he could not forbear looking on her, to uch a height was his love grown in one night. On the other ide, Rufina, who was as well read in Hypocriie as the Hermit, was reolv'd to outvy him at kneeling, in which poture he continued omewhat longer than he could have wih'd. At lat perceiving that Cripin had done his prayers, he alo ended hers. Whereupon the holy Brother comes to her, and aid to her, Bleed be the great Preerver of Mankind, my dear Siter in Chrit, for his infinite mercies; be it his good pleaure that you may live happily all the ret of your days, and have all thoe enjoyments of body and mind you can your elf deire. I pray tell me, excellent creature of God, how you reted this night. Very well, my beloved Brother, repli'd he, I thank your kindnes, though the trouble I am in uffers me not to be quite free from diquiet. There is nothing more argues a devout Soul, ays Cripin, than a weet and humble compliance with the will of Heaven; put your confidence in him who hath numbred the hairs of your head, and doubt not but this heavines will be turned into joy. If it be his bleed will, it hall be o, aid he, though we ee not the means how it will be effected. O excellent creature! cries out the amorous Hermit, how highly meritorious in the ight of God is this holy acquiecence and reignation?

Having o aid, he brought her into a little room, out of which they had the propect of the fields, where being both ate down, Cripin began to open himelf to her in this dicoure.
