When I eriouly conider, Madam, the trange effects of beauty, how the puruance of it forces men into diturbances, and in a manner tranports them out of themelves, I cannot chue but pity and excue them, becaue the frailer part of man endeavours its own atisfaction, and the heart is naturally enclin'd to deire that which the eye contemplates with a certain pleaure, epecially having for its object the mot delightful thing that God ever fram'd. You may hence take occaion to imagine, Siter, what reflections we hould make on the celetial beauties, and thoe upernatural miracles which trancend the reach of our enes. When I left the world, which was in an age not much acquainted with the wickednes of it, I propos'd to my elf, as far as I could with a repect to humanity, to keep my elf at as great a ditance as I could from the ight of that admirable ex, which is not undeervedly called, the fairer half of the world; inamuch as I have already put away childihnes, and began to entertain thoughts utable to manhood, and apprehended, that to be exempted from the charms of women, was a privilege wholly angelical. I am at the preent much more atisfied as to that particular, than I could have been in that tate of innocence, and I find there is an abolute neceity I hould keep out of your ight, or fall into the nare I ee the devil laying
for me. The umme of this dicoure, Madam, is to hew you, that beautiful faces are very dangerous, and that, ince my firt ight of yours, I feel my Soul in a very great hazard. Be not tartled, I beeech you, to hear me talk after this rate; this dicoure, I mut confes, is very dicononant to the habit I have on, and the propoition I have embrac'd: but thee have not unmann'd me, and conequently not exempted me from humane infirmities.

With thee words there might be een preading over his face a certain bluh, as if he could not make the firt overture of uch a thing without expreing omewhat he was never truly acquainted with, Shame. Rufina, with a counterfeit modety, eem'd to do as much as he had: but Occaion preenting her fore-lock, and telling her that that was the mot likely way to bring about her deign, he would not give him an abolute denial, but made him this Anwer. Though I know my elf not to be of their number, who, by their beauty, may engage men into any diquiet, yet mut I acknowledge, Brother Cripin, that, as to this point, I am of your opinion; for the attractions of Beauty are o powerful, that I my elf, though a woman, am carried away therewith, as well as others, and know not a greater pleaure, than that of eeing a handome face, and admiring the effects of it. And therefore I wonder not at all, that men are reduc'd to ome extremities, when they are paionately in love, ince it is to be imagin'd, that the force of beauty operates with
an extraordinary influence. Nor do I think any more worth my admiration, to ee it hath its effects as well on thoe who are retir'd out of the world, as on thoe whoe affections are mot inclin'd thereto, inamuch as they have not attain'd a degree of perfection purifi'd from the dros of all humane enjoyments: And therefore, I have reaon to think my elf the more oblig'd to the charity you have hewn me, ince I undertand, that your exerciing of it is not without the Ios of your quiet, and omewhat of candal. I could wih with all my heart, that I were not the caue of o much trouble in the world; but in regard you are not heard by any but my elf, you need fear nothing as to that particular. You were deirous to know the Hitory of my Adventures, I am no les to be acquainted with yours, and particularly to undertand what might have oblig'd you to leave the world o oon, to live in this olitary place, and with o great auterity. For though I doubt not but you did it in order to the alvation of your own oul, yet me-thinks I perceive in you thoe excellent endowments, for which you might have been eteem'd in your youth, and put off the execution of o hard a penance till another time.

Rufina's dicoure was as the counterfeit Hermite could have wih'd it, and thereupon being tranported with joy, he came more home to his purpoe, and told her in plain tearms, that the charms of her beauty had o inchanted him, that, from the minute he firt came into his houe, he had
not had any ret, he loving her as paionately as man could be imagin'd to love woman. Rufina, who minded her own work, entertain'd the dicoure with omewhat of kindnes, excuing it upon the account of humane frailty: o that giving him ome hope, that he hould obtain his deires, he eem'd to be the mot atisfi'd peron in world. Rufina pretended indipoition, and for two days together kept her bed, where he was treated by her charitable Entertainer, with the bet meat could be had for mony, which was brought to the Hermitage in the night time, by his Camerades.

It may eem omewhat trange, that Rufina hould have the confidence to continue all alone in that olitary place, with a peron of whoe wickednes he had a ufficient knowledge: but he knew withal the paion he had for her, and inferr'd thence, that a real Love never being without repect, he could not imagine he would ever injure her. What further aur'd her, was the hope he had put him in to treat him more kindly, when he had certain notice brought her, that her Brother had left Malaga; beides, that the apprehenion he had let he might be dicover'd, kept her from requiting, as he thought her elf oblig'd, the extraordinary kindnes he had hewn her. Thus he drew in by degrees the Rampant Hermit, who, to further on the work, promis'd her to make a diligent enquiry, by the means of his friends, whether her Brother were at Malaga.

That night, Cripin's three intimate friends
came to the Hermitage, bringing along with them above two thouand Crowns in gold. This was the robbery they were engag'd upon, when Garay over-heard their dicoure in the wood. The dicovery had been made by Cripin, in a houe of the City, where he was wont to receive alms, and the rain having prevented the execution of the deigne that night, they had now done their work, by thruting a little boy into the houe where the mony was, who made a hift about mid-night to open the door for them.

The three Robbers brought the mony that very night to the Hermitage. Cripin, who was unwilling they hould ee what female-company he had in the houe, receiv'd them in his own chamber, and treated them with a Supper. As they upp'd, they dicours'd of divers things. There was among them one, who having quitted his Studies, had engag'd himelf in that infamous kind of life, not regarding his extraction, nor his endowments, which were much beyond ordinary. This peron furnih'd them with dicoure upon all occaions; whence it came that Cripin deir'd him to divert them a little, and, to drive away the time a while after upper, to entertain them with ome Hitory or Novel, for he had abundance of them. He pres'd him the more earnetly, that Rufina might alo participate of the diverion, who, from the room where he was, might hear all their dicoure. She was very glad, to find, that Cripin was the ecret entertainer of o virtuous a Society, and immediately concluded
by their dicoures, that they were the ame perons, whom Garay had over-heard in the wood. The young man, whom the Hermite had intreated to tell them ome tory, diplay'd the excellency of his wit and memory, in the relation of the enuing Novel.

div.head: THE SECOND NOVEL.
The Knight of the Noble Order of the Marigold.
div.p:
DOn Pedro Oorio, a Gentleman of very high Quality, was born at Ville-Franche de Vierco, an ancient City, upon the confines of Galicia. He was decended from a very noble Family, and was brought up in his own Country, with his elder Brother Don Fernand Oorio, and a Siter called Donna
Contantia: but his Father and Mother leaving this World ere he was full fifteen years of Age, he was forc'd into that coure of Life, which is commonly taken by the younger Brothers of Noble Houes, who have not much left them, and with the little Money he could get together, he went to trail a Pike in Flanders. He behav'd himelf o gallantly there upon everal occaions, that he got the Colours of a Company of Foot, and after other uccesful encounters againt the Dutch, he was advanc'd to the Command of the ame Company. Having afterwards in that Charge made yet greater demontrations of his Conduct and Valour, his mot Serene Highnes the Arch-Duke Albert prevail'd with his Majety to betow on him the Order of the Knights of Alcantara, with an aurance of the firt Commandery, that hould be void, belonging to that Order. Having obtain'd that, he till continu'd his Military employments, till uch time as there was a Ceation of Arms made between the King and his Enemies of the Low-countries, to lat a year and a day. This opportunity, together with the news he receiv'd out of Spain, of his Elder Brother's Death, oblig'd him to deire leave to make a journey into his Country, where two Children his Brother had left, and his own Siter, tood in need of his preence; the former, to be protected by him; the latter, to be dipos'd of in marriage. Don Pedro arriv'd at Ville-Franche, fifteen days after his Siter's departure thence for Vailladolid, where the Court was then, with an Aunt of his, a Widdow, his Father's Siter, who would needs have her along with her; this old Lady, who had a great kindnes for
her, having reolv'd to leave her all he had at her Death, in hopes he might with thoe advantages meet with a better match.

As oon as Don Pedro was come into his Country, he took order about his Brother's Etate, and the Tuition of his Nephews, whom he left in the cutody of an antient Kinman of his, whom having entruted with the care of their education and maintenance, he reolv'd to go and viit his Siter at Vailladolid. As he was etting things in order for that Journey, paing through the broad place of Ville-Franche, he aw abundance of people, going towards an Inn, which was at the end of it, accompanying two Litters, in one whereof there was an old Gentleman, and, in that which follow'd, a young Lady, whoe trancendent Beauty, heightned by the umptuounes of her attire, ravihed the eyes and hearts of all that aw her, but above all thoe of Don Pedro. He was o enflam'd by that tranient ight of her, that, covering with his Cloak the Order he was of, he follow'd the Litter, o tranported out of himelf, that he reflected not on what thoe who oberv'd him might ay of his demeanour. He aw her lighting at the Inn-gate; and if he was before rais'd into a kind of atonihment at the beauty of her Face, he was now no les, at the handomenes of her Body, the magnificence of her Cloathing, and the weetnes of her Complexion. In a word, he was reduc'd to uch an extremity by the paion he immediately felt in himelf for her, that he made enquiry, and et himelf to find out, who that miracle of perfections might be, which had o of a udden urpriz'd his Heart, and attain'd o abolute a dipoal of his Liberty.
He was oon atisfy'd as to that particular, for, meeting with one of her Servants going from the Inn towards the Market-place, he with much civility ask'd him, who that old Gentleman was, and whither he was then going? The other, who undertood civility well enough, return'd him this Anwer, The Gentleman, whoe name you are o deirous to know, and who is my Mater, is called the Marques Rodolfo, a peron of the highet Rank next to Soveraign Princes, who comes into Spain, an Ordinary Ambaadour, from the Emperour of Germany, to his mot Catholick Majety the King of Spain. He brings along with him his beautiful Daughter, the Lady Margaret, to be married to Leopoldus, his Excellency's Nephew, who is at the preent at Vailladolid, a Gentleman of extraordinary worth, who in the flower of his Youth left Germany, to go and ee foreign Countries, attended onely by four Servants. He has travell'd over all France, England, and Italy, and is now reolv'd to make his aboad in Spain, having already continu'd ome time at the Court, with a very great Train. He hath a Houe magnificently furnih'd, and is very highly in favour with his Catholick Majety, and well repected by all the Nobility about the Court; nay his generoity and excellent converation have acquir'd him the eteem of all the greatet perons in this Country. This marriage of Signor Leopoldus had been treated of in Germany, with this Lady Margaret, the onely Daughter of my Mater, who leaving his Country upon his being honour'd by the Emperour with the preent Embay, hath ollicited the buines with greater
earnetnes; o that his Imperial Majety eems deirous that this Match hould go forward. We came by Sea, but had uch ditres of Weather, that we were like to be cat away everal times. While we were in that danger, my Mater, a Gentleman much inclin'd to Devotion, made a Vow that if he ecaped, through the interceion of the glorious Patron of Spain, (for whom he hath a particular Devotion) he would viit the place where his acred Body lies buried, o well known all over the World for the great Miracles daily done there. Being come to Vailladolid, my Mater continu'd there fifteen days, during which time all things were agreed upon in order to the Marriage. That great affair being concluded, he would needs perform his Vow, and go to Saint James's. His Nephew Leopoldus is not come along with him, but tays at Vailladolid, to end to Rome for the Dipenation, for the Lady Margaret and Signor Leopoldus are Couin-Germans. Thus Sir, I think I have atisfy'd your deire, as to the quetion you put to me.

Don Pedro gave the Servant very great thanks for the accompt he had given him of his Mater, and aur'd him he would requite his kindnes, if it lay in his power, and o took leave. This dicoure happen'd after night, as they walk'd over the Market-place, it being o dark as that the Marques's Servant could not take any particular notice of Don Pedro, who did all he could to avoid being dicover'd. The accompt he had receiv'd, that the Beauty, which had tollen away his heart at the firt ight, was already engag'd, and, within a hort time to be married,
caus'd him to return home a much adder Man than he had left it. This affliction, with the love which he already had for her, bereav'd him of all ret. That very night, he would needs go and ee the Marques and his Daughter at Supper, yet o as that he might not be perceiv'd by them. The mater of the Houe plac'd him o as that be might ee all at his eae, yet not be een himelf; and this was to leap out of the frying-pan into the fire. The next day, the Marques went thence, o as that Don Pedro aw not the Lady Margaret any more that time: nor was he much troubled at it, for having in the night advis'd with his pillow, to find out ome remedy for his diquier, he found it neceary, that he hould not be een, either by the Marques, or his Daughter, or any one belonging to them, that he might the better compas a deign which onely Love could inpire him withall.

The Kingdom of Galicia is very full of mountains, and conequently the way to Saint James's mut be troubleome to travel, o that the Marques could make but hort Journeys, whence Don Pedro inferr'd, that he could not be back in les than twenty days; preuming he would make ome aboad at Compotella, to do his devotions, and refreh himelf, ere he et out for his return. Accordingly, be dipos'd of his affairs in order to the deign he had bethought himelf of, and, taking leave of all his acquaintance, he went to Pont-ferrada, a Town which lay four Leagues further from the Court than Ville-Franche. He took up his Quarters at an Inn, whence he tirr'd not in the day-time, but onely took the air a little in the night, yet with uch a caution not to be
known to any, that he dicover'd himelf to none of the Inhabitants, but onely his Land-lord, whom he acquainted with his quality, and the deign had brought him thither. He was attended onely by one Servant, whoe fidelity and courage he had many years experienc'd, for he had erv'd him as a Soldier, and waited on him, from the time of his firt departure from Ville-Franche. Felician (o was this faithful Servant named) perceiving his Mater more melancholy than he had been wont to be, and that omewhat kept him from reting in the night, for he heard him diquietly turning in his bed, and ighing ever and anon, he imagin'd that the caue of his diturbance was not at Pontferrada, inamuch as if it had been, he would not have fail'd, night or day, to dicover by his viits, what could not be known by his diquiets and ighs. Thus this dicreet Lover not dicovering any thing of his ecret paion, Felician could not ghes at the occaions which bred uch a ditraction in his mind: nay though he did all lay in his power to pry into it, yet could he never meet with any atisfaction. One day, finding his Mater all alone, and not able to endure that reerv'dnes in him any longer, he thus poke to him.

p.q:
I hould never have imagin'd, Sir, that you could be guilty of o great a cloenes towards a ervant, whom you have ever found faithful, and to love you even beyond his own life. You have heretofore thought me worthy the knowledge of your mot important ecrets; pardon me, if I preume to tell you, that your ilence now gives me jut caue to conceive, that you have not the ame thoughts of me, and that I mut be guilty of ome
crime, whereof I have not my elf the leat apprehenion. Wherein, I pray, Sir, may I have offended you? You mut needs harbour ome ill thoughts of me, ince you conceal from me the diquiets which deprive you of all appetite to meat or ret. Sure they proceed from Love, or I am mightily mitaken. You cloe not your eyes all night, and pend the day in retirement, avoiding all ociety, and giving your elf up to perpetual olitude, and melancholy; which I am extremely troubled to ee. You have left your Country, telling your friends that you were going to Court; whereas you continue in an obcure place, where you are afraid to be known. 'Tis impoible for me to forbear grieving at it, as long as I am ignorant of the caue thereof. Pardon my curioity, Sir, which however impertinent, is an argument of my faith and readines to erve you. I know it to be the duty of a good and faithful Servant, punctually and implicitly to obey the commands of his Mater, without ininuating himelf further into his ecrets, than he is willing he hould be acquainted therewith. I have hitherto kept my elf within thoe bounds, and have o liv'd with you as that I fear not any reproach you can make me. But now at lat, my ancient fidelity gives me the boldnes to ask you, what buines may have brought you to this place; what occaions your diquiet, and what you intend to do in this obcure Inn, where you admit not of any enjoyments? Have you a greater confidence of the happy Mater of this Houe, whom you have known but within thee four days, than of an old Servant, of whoe zeal and fidelity
you have had o many experiences? You have heretofore thought my advice worth the asking, nay have follow'd it, in things, for ought I know, of as great importance as this is.

div.p:
Felician having thus ended his complaint, his Mater conceiv'd himelf oblig'd to make him ome Anwer, which was this. Felician, I mut confes, I have look'd on thee, and that jutly, as my friend, a title I may well allow one who hath har'd with me, in war, the dangers, in peace, the enjoyments I have been engag'd in. It is a very hard thing, not to ay impoible, that any man hould, in the dipoal of himelf, take a coure contrary to that intended him by Heaven; though it be aid, that a wie man hall have dominion over the Stars, that is (as Atrologers expound it) humane Prudence hall elude the decrees of Fate. I am born to love a Beauty, which urpriing my heart, hath withall poes'd it elf of all the faculties of my Soul. I find my elf no longer Mater of my own liberty, that I am not able to make the leat dipoal of my will, and o it were a madnes for me, to oppoe the inclination, whereto the overeign Powers have made me ubject. I uffer my elf to be foolihly carri'd away by my paion, though I know well enough that I attempt a thing abolutely impoible, and beyond my trength. This is the caue of my diquiet, muing, and melancholy, pending the nights without ret, and the day in olitude, uffering a thouand aflictions which I cannot expres, and loving where I am not to hope the leat return of Love, by reaon of an invincible obtacle that lies in my way. This is that detroys my enjoyments,
and poions all my joy. I have een that divine Beauty, that mortal Angel, that prodigy of miracles, who pas'd through our Town with her Father the Marques Rodolfo: the excellent endowments he is Mitris of, and which thou mait have admir'd as well as my elf, are all the excue I can alledge for the blindnes of my paion; but they feed it not with any hope. There is an obtacle lies between me and the poeion of her, which I hall find it impoible to remove. This trancendent Beauty is already made ure to a Gentleman of great worth, who is her Couin-germane, named Leopoldus, and me-thinks I ee her ready to join hands with him. I hear uch high commendations of his excellent parts, that I find the little hope I had ready to leave me. I love her, or to ay better, I adore her, and if I may judge by the preent agitations of my heart, I may ay, it will never be diengag'd from the paion I have for her. I know it is madnes in me to think of her, and that I cannot, without extravagance, ever hope he may be mine, to the diappointment of a young Lord, who, with the advantages of bloud, hath all thoe of nature. Nay I think it almot impoible to find out ome means to acquaint her with my Love, and to get a Letter convey'd to her. I know that the houes of Oorio, Toledo, Astorga, and Ville-Franche, whence I derive my extraction, are not inferiour to thoe of Rodolfo or Leopoldus, and conequently that I am as nobly decended as he is; that would not be the greatet obtacle, if I could but make my elf known at Court. I hear that he intends thither, when he
returns from her pilgrimage; I have but three months to carry on this buines, which is the time requiite to get the dipenation from Rome. I have a long time conider'd with my elf of the means, how I might get acces to her, and that I conceive the mot likely to take, is to counterfeit, what indeed is but too real, a certain ditraction of mind. By acting the mad-man's part, I might o diguie my extravagancies, as that the Father, pleas'd with my humour, may haply carry me along with him to the Court. This certainly is a deign fantatick enough, and not onely contrary to my quality, but abolutely oppoite to the opinion I hould endeavour to raie my elf in the world. I have a certain confidence, that at Court I hall be known to very few, becaue I have been a long time out of Spain. Beides thee coniderations, the habit I will put on, being altogether extravagant, I hall be o diguis'd, that my nearet friends and relations will hardly know me. If, by this means, I can get into the Marques's houe, I hall hope the plot will take. For I have heard this Lady is not fully atisfi'd with the marriage, having undertood that her Couin is a peron of a debauch'd life, and inclin'd to Women; and that he admits of his addrees onely out of obedience to her Father. I have communicated my deign to the Mater of the houe, as being a dicreet peron, who may erve me, and puts me in hope to get me into the Marques's ervice, when he comes to give him an account of my pleaant extravagancies, as we have already agreed together. Thus, my dear Felician, have I given thee a faithful character
of my elf, thou know't now as much as I do, as well of my affliction, as my love; mitrut not the confidence I have of thee, and ait me with all thy wit and indutry, or expect ere long to be a witnes of my departure out of this world.

Felician, out of compliance with his Mater, approved of the project, though he doubted much the ucces of it. He aw his Mater was too far tranported to receive any prudent advice; o that he promis'd to ait him according to the deign he had laid to get acces to his Mitres, and troubled not his thoughts with any thing but how to compas it. It was his buines therefore to get cloaths made for Don Pedro, utable to his extravagance. He put him into a Caock after the old fahion, with puffs at the leeves of green cloth, and large skirts, a Cloak omewhat like a Rocket, very hort, and a Milan Cap, of green Pluh. Being thus diguis'd, he chang'd his quarters, and went to the Hot's Brother's houe, who alo mut of neceity be acquainted with the ecret. All this could not be done without ome yellow pieces, whereof he had brought good tore out of Flanders, with ome Jewels of value he had gotten by gaming, at which he was very fortunate.

About this time the Marques, with the beautiful Lady his Daughter, were upon their return from their pilgrimage. Before they got to Pontferrada, the beams of his Litter broke, o that he was forc'd to come to the Town on hore-back, and to tay there two days, while the Litter was mended. The Marques took up the ame Inn where Don Pedro had lodg'd, as being the bet in the Town. The Hot being taught what he had to ay to the Marques, for
the furtherance of Don Pedro's deign, oon met with an opportunity to do it. For, as mot perons of Quality, when they travel, are very inquiitive to know what is rare or remarkable at the places through which they pas, the Marques deirous to hear what there might be at Pontferrada, call'd for the Hot. Having travell'd everal times before into Spain, he poke the Language very well, was a very ociable peron, and glad of company.

The Hot being come into the room, he began to ask him concerning the Antiquities of the Town, the illutrious Families had liv'd in it, the dipoitions of the Inhabitants, the beauty of the Ladies, and uch particulars: wherein the Hot atisfy'd him, giving him a very exact account of all he knew. Among the antiquities and remarkable things of the Town, he came to peak of Don Pedro, telling uch tories of him as might raie a deire in the Marques to ee him. There is come, aid he to him, within thee fifteen days, a very rare peron to this Town, fantatically clad in a green tuff; but there is a greater extravagance in his behaviour than there is in his cloaths, and yet in the height of his ditraction, there may be oberv'd certain hadows of undertanding and taiednes which render him excellent good company. Being asked by ome of our Inhabitants, who he was, I am, aid he, Son to the River Sil, which paes by the walls of this Town, and decended from one of the mot illutrious Families of Galicia. He expects to be treated with your Honour, and your Lordhip, in dicoure, though he is known by the title of Knight of the Noble Order of the Marigold. The fooleries he tells
to make good the title he aumes, are o ridiculous, that they force Laughter from the mot melancholy. He eldome comes out of his Lodging, feeds high, and we cannot imagine whence he hould have means to live at that rate. He hath a Servant to wait on him, who knows the length of his foot, and complies with him in his madnes, either for his advantage, or that he hath a oft place in his Head, as well as his Mater; and I think them both very well worth your notice. I wonder the Knight hath not been yet to wait on your Excellency; for he is mighty deirous to convere with Strangers, and finds them out as oon as he hears of their arrival.

The Marques was much pleas'd with this Relation of the Hot, and deir'd him to bring him acquainted with that noble Knight. The fair Lady Margaret expres'd alo a deire to ee him, for he had been preent at the Hot's dicoure. He gladly atisfy'd them, being over-joy'd the Prologue of the deign had taken o well. He went to his Brother's to fetch him, having before told the Ambaadour, that he mut treat him honourably, if he expected to make any port with him; inamuch as, being extreamly elf-conceited in his madnes, he would be put out of all humour, if he were entertain'd with any di-repect, or indifference.

The Marques, who was a peron naturally inclin'd to mirth and civility, promis'd him he would oberve his directions. Whereupon the Hot marches away for Don Pedro, who came into the room very humorouly in his fool's coat, making wry mouths, and ome fantatick getures, the introduction to his future
extravagance. The Ambaadour, how erious oever he would appear, as being oblig'd by his quality to diemble, could not forbear Laughing, to ee him in that equipage, attended by Felician, who, on the other ide, acted very well the part had been given him. He went to receive him at the Chamber-door, with this complement; Welcome to the noblet piece of Gallantry that ever Spain aw; welcome the mirrour of all the brave Knights that ever were celebrated for their heroick Actions. The News your Excellency tells me, replies Don Pedro, deerves not the reward may be expected for it: you are extreamly mitaken, if you think your elf the firt of thoe who have admir'd Nature's prodigality towards me in excellent parts and endowments. Give me the favour at leat, anwers the Marques, to be one of the mot faithful witnees thereof, which no doubt I hall, if you pleae but to honour me a while with your weet company. For as a rich Diamond pleaes all the world, o the attractions of your countenance, and the trancendent ininuation of your behaviour forces the admiration of all that ee you.

Don Pedro was by this time got near the fair Lady Margaret, whereupon looking with a certain atonihment on her miraculous Beauty, My Lord Marques, aid he to him, I beeech you forbear at preent the praies you are pleas'd to give me, for it were to profane thoe which are due to this excellent creature. I pray let me know whether he be your Daughter, for if he be, you will be much concern'd in the Elogies I hall give this—this—this—(well) Miracle. Her coming into the
world was to embellih our Hemiphere, to upply Cupid with freh Darts, to become the Load-tone of Hearts, the delight of the Eyes, the atonihment of the Univere, the mater-piece of Heaven, and the miracle of Nature. By the Noble Order of Knight-wood I am of, I wear, that the very minute I firt cat my Eye on this accomplih'd Beauty, I found my heart was grown rebellious, and no longer mine; my will bereay'd of all freedome; and my oul become abolutely her Slave. In a word, Sir, I think my elf omewhat different from what I was before, and the more I feel my elf, the more I am atonih'd at the trange Metamorphois. The commendations you give me, renowned Knight, replies the Lady, mell too much of lattery: I am confident you do not your elf believe one half of what you have aid, and therefore it will be hard for you to peruade me to it. You conider not that you act againt your own Sentiment, when you peak againt your Concience. I hould never advie a Gallant, who would raie himelf an eteem with the Ladies, to hazard his own diappointment by o ill a Prologue; for to give undeerved praies breeds a upition of imperfections; and to be forc'd to the belief of falhood brings truth into quetion. The truth, I tell you, replies the amorous Extravagant, is uch, o pure, o clear, and o far from all upition of being otherwie, that you hall ever find it as plainly in my Mouth as in your own Looking-glas. Be not o haty, honourable Knight, ays the Lady to him, be pleas'd to take a Chair, for we deire to dicoure with you at leiure. Were it Heaven's
pleaure, Madam, ays Don Pedro, as oon as he was ate, that I might ever continue near you: but I ee the honour you are pleas'd to do me will be but hort, and my joy oon be over, for I undertand, that within two days you leave this place, and if you go without me, I hall dye out of pure grief. In the mean time, give me leave to look on this manion as the Empyreal heaven, ince o great a Deity hath honour'd it with her preence. We forget all civility, ays the Marques, when we fall into other dicoure, before you have firt entertain'd us with your own noble adventures, that we may thereby know what repects we ought to pay your worth. There is not any due to me Sir, replies the diguiz'd Cavalier; but that the ervice, I have vow'd you, may be the better receiv'd, I will give you an account of my extraction, and relate you the perfect hitory of my Life hitherto: be pleas'd to afford your attention to what I hall ay.

q.p:
The Kingdome of Galicia was heretofore govern'd by Counts, and afterwards by Kings. Gondomar reign'd in that time, and continu'd a Widdower after the burial of his firt Wife, by whom he had no other Children but the Infanta, Theodomira, who coming to reign after him was called the VVenching-Queen. She fell in love with the Gallant Ricaredo, one of the richet and prope et perons in the Kingdome. He ever kept about the Court, and was a Kinman, though omewhat afar off, to the King, but his principal Favourite, by which means he had acces into the Queen's chamber, and got of her that favour whereby Mankind
is propagated. I prov'd to be the iue of that amorous Union, and the good hour of my birth happen'd at a time that the King chanc'd to be at his Daughter's lodging. The pains of Child-birth urpriz'd her, and being a Novice in uch adventures, he could not diemble her Labour, even in the preence of her Father, who imagin'd it was ome other accident had happen'd to her. Her VVomen holp her to Bed, not knowing the dieae that troubled her; but not long after I came into the world, it eems, to run through all the misfortunes that have happened to me ince. Being receiv'd into the world by a faithful Servant, who knew of my Mother's Loves, he took me in her Lap, to be deliver'd to a Brother of hers, who was alo acquainted with the buines. As he went out of the Infanta's Lodgings, he meets with the King, going to viit his Daughter. She was affraid his curioity would have egg'd him on to examine what he had in her Lap; which made her turn back of a udden, and, by a ecret pair of tairs, go down into the Garden, where having dipos'd me into a little wicker Basket, he put me into the River Sil, which ran by the wall thereof, and told the Infanta that he had deliver'd me to her Brother, as they had reolv'd. I was carry'd awhile on the Chrytal waves of that clear River, but at lat, the water growing omewhat rough, I unk, and was receiv'd into the arms of the God of that River, who encompas'd by his fair Nymphs, conducted me into his own Chrytal palace. You may haply imagine this dicoure a feign'd tory taken out of the inventions of the Poets; but give
me leave to aure you, that the buines happen'd no otherwie than as I tell you.

I was brought up by the Nymphs in that ecret Manion, and intructed by the God of the River, who wih'd I might prove worthy o noble an education. He caus'd me to be intructed in all manner of Sciences, and par'd no pains to make me an accomplih'd peron. I learnt three or four Languages, but particularly the Latin above any of the other. Being arriv'd to the twentieth year of my Age, Love, to hew his omnipotency, and that all places are under his juridiction, caus'd his flames to faten on me even through the water. In that Virginal company of Nymphs, there was one, for whom the God of that watery habitation had a particular eteem; and he deerv'd it, for he very much excell'd all her Companions; her name was Anacaria. Her endowments were extraordinary, and her beauty beyond all comparion. In complexion and tature he came omewhat near this fair Lady your Daughter, and had the ame advantage over the ret of the Nymphs, as the Delphick Torch hath over the other Planets. She play'd excellently well on all kinds of Intruments; to um up all in a word, he was a prodigy of all perfections. I fell o paionately in love with this beauty that I had not a minute's ret, from the time that little Deity had wounded my heart, with the mortal darts of her parkling Eyes. I found it a hard buines to dicover my love to her, in regard I could never meet her alone. She was perpetually haunted by ome of thoe who liv'd in that Chrytal palace; they follow'd her every
where, and would never be out of her ight. But one day, when all the other Nymphs were gone to a Muick-meeting, at which were alo to be read certain Lectures of Poeie, being the ordinary divertiements of the God of that River, the divine Anacaria purpoely pretended ome indipoition, to give me an opportunity to peak with her. She ent me notice of it, by one who came to tell me from her, that he kept her Bed onely for my ake, than which I could not have expected a kinder complement from one of her Sex. I went to her chamber, and found her carelesly laid on a Bed of Mos, exceeding in whitenes the fine Sheets he lay on, and diputing as to plendor and light, with the Sun, who then beheld her. I was tartled at the ight of o many charms, and was upon the point of loing all Sentiment, an effect natural enough in thoe who are truly touch'd with love. But recovering my elf a while after, though till much troubled, and my tongue but as it were newly looned, I took the confidence to make this dicoure to her.

Adorable Nymph, the glory of thee deep Habitations, but the unavoidable Rack of thoe hearts, which are captivated by your Beauty, my oul, ince the firt time I aw you, is abolutely dipos'd to erve you; I have no further power over her, he is wholly yours, and glories in her lavery. Treat her as a thing belongs to you, and as I have vow'd her to you with an inviolable fidelity. You have done me an extraordinary favour in allowing me to declare the amorous paion I have for you: may I further hope that you will
allay it, and if I hould be admitted to that degree of felicity, hould I not be the happiet and the mot glorious of all men?

The fair Anacaria infinitely pleas'd with o obliging a dicoure, and the worth he oberv'd in me, highly honour'd me with her affection, and compli'd with my amorous deires, in uch weet and melting expreions, as put me in hopes of the happy accomplihment of my Love. But it was not long ere our dicoure was interrupted by the God of the River, who finding neither of us at the Meeting, came treight to her Chamber, and lunk in o oftly, that he over-heard ome part of our amorous conference; which o incens'd him againt me, that he immediately reolv'd to give a check to my preumption. He laid iege, with his clear waters, to the chamber of Anacaria, and ere he had quite damm'd up the door, he cat me out with uch violence, that I was got to the bank of the River. I preently heard a voice aying unto me, Guadomarus, thou art decended from Kings, though it be a long time ince they have had Scepters in their hands; Princes of another Family have diplac'd them. Thou art born a Pagan, chooe what Law thou thinket bet; if thou wilt follow my advice, thou wilt take that which is oberv'd in this Kingdom, under which lived thy illutrious Ancetors. I have jutly banih'd thee out of my dominions, becaue it was not fit I hould uffer profane love to be made to a Nymph who had vow'd her chatity to me, as I had mine to her. I have promis'd her my protection and aitance in all things. Keep henceforward within thy Kingdom,
and aure thy elf I wih thy good and advancement, o far am I from doing thee any dicourteie. Whitheroever Fortune hall dipoe of thee, be confident, thou wilt not be out of the reach of my care.

With thoe words the waters of the River eem'd to tir themelves into a gentle curl, which being preently laid, it became as mooth as it had been before. I immediately found my elf (by what adventure I know not) in a Kitchin-garden, in the midt of a bed of Marigolds, which I look'd on as a good Omen, and thought my elf oblig'd to derive my name thence. Afterwards, at my baptim, I took the name of Peter Gil of Galicia, taking the urname from the Kingdom which had been heretofore in the poeion of my Predeceors, who have been dead thee four hundred years, as I have found in Hitory. Beides that name I have taken as an additional title, that of Knight of the noble Order of the Marigold; I have aum'd it my elf, for an illutrious Hero, as I am, may be his own Herald, and by what appellations he pleaes raie himelf above the phere of the common ort of people.

Thus have I given your Excellence an accompt who I am, and dicover'd to you my true Original. If the qualities and endowments I own, deerve the Honour to be receiv'd into your alliance, give me leave, O mot illutrious Marques, to make my addrees to this uper-celetial Beauty, this Miracle of our age, whom Nature was humorouly pleas'd to frame for the delight of the eyes, and torment of hearts. I onely expect your good will, give it
me, I beeech you, and thereby atisfie my extraordinary paion. I think you o generous, that you will not deny it me, if you conider, that granting it not, you bereave me of my life, which you know is the mot illutrious of any in Europe; and are conequently atisfi'd, that the world, loing in me, the mot renowned Knight it ever had, mut withall loe the worthiet Kinman of his Catholick Majety King Philip.

div.p: He deliver'd thee lat words with uch pleaant getures, the better to expres the violence of his paion, that both the Marques and his Daughter had much ado to forbear laughing. Felician was atonih'd to ee the force of that paion, which, of an accomplih'd Gentleman, made a ridiculous laughing-tock; and could turn a peron of eminent parts and judgment, one not long before conulted in Flanders as an Oracle, into a counterfeit Extravagant. For if he had not pretended the los of his wits, he had lot all the hopes of his love; and he could not have gotten near o fair a Lady upon any account but that of madnes.

The Marques compoing his countenance to more eriounes, return'd him this Anwer. Signor Don Pedro Gill, the mot illutrious, and onely Knight of the Noble Order of the Marigold, I am extremely pleas'd with the knowledge you have given me of your peron, and the accompt you have entertain'd me with of your miraculous birth and noble education. Had a peron, les illutrious than your elf, acquainted me therewith, I hould have mitruted his dicoure, and imagin'd he told me fables: but a peron of your worth and quality ought
to be credited in all things. What further confirms me in the truth thereof is, that, he is no les then a Prince who peaks to me. Believe me, I have a great repect for your rare Qualities, and uch an honour for your peron, that I would aure you my own is wholly at your ervice. I have that eteem for your friendhip, that I hall endeavour the continuance of it while I live. I wih my elf a natural Inhabitant of this Kingdom, that I might have the greater opportunities to further your atisfaction. I hall tay here but till uch time as his Imperial Majety hall end order for my return; but during the abode I hall make here, command me in any thing lies in my power. As for the permiion you deire to make your addrees to my Daughter, I from this time give it you, and I allow her to accept of it, and to entertain you kindly: but he is already made ure to a Couin of hers, and I have ent to Rome for a Dipenation, which once come, the Marriage will be concluded. This obtacle lies in your way, and you will find it a hard matter to remove it. I am orry I had not the happines of your acquaintance before; for how gladly would I have embrac'd the honour of having a Son-in-law of your worth and quality, and to ee my Family alli'd to the Blood-Royal of Galicia? The end of mot Courthips is Marriage; of yours you ee it cannot be. To addres your elf to my Daughter upon any other account, I know you would not; the husband he expects is a peron of o much gallantry, as not to receive any uch affront.

The diguis'd Extravagant broke forth into great
reentments upon his obliging dicoure, which made excellent port for all that were preent. But having laugh'd their fill, the Marques and his Daughter could not forbear making charitable reflections on that trange kind of ditraction. It pitied them to ee a Gentleman every way o accomplih'd, fall'n into uch unheard of extravagancies, as to alledge himelf decended from a River, and brought up in it, five hundred years before. While ome that were preent, purpoely to urge him to peak, oppos'd the tories he had told them, and he endeavour'd to give them atisfaction, the Marques acquainted his Daughter with a thing had come into his mind, which was to carry Don Pedro along with them to the Court, it being likely he would find them excellent port by the way. They reolv'd to treat him as a Peron of eminent quality, having undertood by his Servant, that he was really uch, and that upon his recovery out of a great icknes, that madnes had eiz'd him. The Lady Margaret was very well content, leaving it to ome other time to acquaint him therewith. Don Pedro Gil coming to take his leave of the Marques aid to him, That ince he was o unhappy as not to deerve his fair Daughter's hand, in the quality of a Husband, he would allow him to love her with a vertuous Love, uch as even her Husband hould not diapprove. The Marques gave way, deiring him to honour him with his company at upper that night, for that he had omewhat to communicate unto him. Don Pedro gladly accepted the proffer, and thereupon they parted.

The Marques and his people talked very much of Don Pedro, wondring at the trange kind of madnes
he was fallen into. He acquainted them with the deign he had to take him along to the Court. The Mater of the houe where he was lodg'd happening to be then preent, told him, that he doubted Don Pedro Gill would hardly be peruaded thereto, if the Marques treated him as an inferiour; for he was mighty elf-conceited, and tood much upon his honour; but if he were willing, there would arie another difficulty in the manner of his travelling; in regard, aid he to him, your Excellency going by Litter, I think he would be loath to go by hore. We'l find an expedient for that, ays the Marques, which is, that my Daughter, as his Mitres, hall command him to entertain her at the ide of her Litter; for if his love continues, he will be glad of the opportunity; and he hall have an excellent hore, richly harnas'd, which I have led after me, to ride on when I am weary of the Litter.

Don Pedro, who had been acquainted with all thee dicoures, fail'd not to come to upper, to which he had been invited. The Marques receiv'd him very civilly, and caus'd a chair to be et for him, near his Daughter, which he thought a very ignal favour. They talk'd of divers things, the Marques finding he had an excellent wit in his intervals, which ever clos'd with ome pleaant extravagance. They were very merry at upper, and were oblig'd for their diverion to the merry dicoures of Don Pedro. At lat, the cloth being taken away, the Marques broke his mind to him in thee words.

p.q:
'Tis a thouand pities, mot renowned Knight, that a peron o accomplih'd as you are, and one furnih'd with all the excellent endowments that
recommend men to the favour and eteem of Princes, hould as it were defie their Courts, and pend your time and talents in uch an obcure place as this is. I have heard that the reaon of this your retirement is, that you have not means to live utably to your condition and the rank you hould maintain. If it be o, give me leave to propoe an expedient to you, out of the particular eteem I have for your Signory. I hall take it for a very great favour, if you will be pleaed to go along with me to Valladolid, where you hall be treated, in my Quarters, with all the ubmiions and repects due to a peron of your quality, yet o as that it hall not cot you any thing. By this means coming to be known, and your worth preading it elf, you may meet with a rich wife, of ome illutrious Family; wherein my Daughter may do you a kindnes, in regard he, having occaion to ee many of them, will advance you into her favour, for whom you have mot inclination. Let me obtain of your Knight-hood the favour I deire of you; live freely with us, ince you would have me believe, that the love you bear my Daughter is pure and incere; I will undertake it hall be kindly taken by the Husband he hopes to have. I expect your Anwer to this particular, and I deire it may be cononant to the eteem I have for your worth.

div.p:
Don Pedro was extremely atisfi'd, that the Impoture had taken o well, and immediately apprehended, that, living in the houe with the Marques, he hould be near her whom he ador'd, which was the main end of his deires; whereupon he return'd him
this Anwer. No temptation in the world hould have forc'd my removal from this place, but the extraordinary Civilities I have receiv'd from your Excellency. I had reolv'd to pend the ret of my days in this retirement, as conceiving it the bet coure for a peron of my Quality, whoe Revenues are much below his Honour, to confine himelf to ome place, where he is not much known, and o avoid the charge of Servants and Cloaths. But the repects you are pleas'd to have for me, together with this trancendent Beauty, who, by the forcible attractions of her divine countenance, draws hearts after her, as the Thracian Orpheus did living creatures, tones and plants, by the harmonious ound of his Harp, have made me wholly at your ervice. I hall not trouble either you or my elf to tell you how perons of my Quality ought to be treated, as thinking it enough, that I have already acquainted you with my Titles, and particularly that I am of the Blood-Royal. The greatet favour you can ever do me, is, that you command me to wait on your Daughter, which if you do, I hall the more willingly accept of the proffer you are pleas'd to make me.

The Marques finding him willing to go along with them, all that remain'd to be done was to peruade him to do it on hore-back, which he was content to do, that he might the better entertain his Mitres at the ide of her Litter. Don Pedro help'd the Lady into her Litter, being proud in his mind at that introduction of his ervice to her, and that he had the happines to take her by the fair hand, continuing his attendance on her from their departure
from Pontferrada, till they came to Valladolid. All the way along, he entertain'd her with pleaant dicoures, intermixt with amorous expreions, and at every Inn they came to, he fail'd not to give her Father an account of the divertive dicoures he had had with Don Pedro.

The lat day of their Journey, Don Pedro would needs feel the pule of his Mitres as to her intended Marriage, and endeavour'd to dicover how he was inclin'd thereto. He brought the buines upon the Stage, o dexterouly, as that he might not upect him guilty of any impertinent curioity. It is commonly oberv'd that perons any way afflicted are apt to break their minds to any people, but epecially to thoe with whom they are familiarly acquainted. Accordingly, to eae her own thoughts, and atisfie Don Pedro, he made him this Anwer. Worthy Knight of the mot honourable Order of the Marigold, I mut needs acknowledge, that my Couin Leopoldus is a peron endow'd with all the Qualities, capable to raie a Woman's Love to the highet pitch, but I have withall dicover'd him to be o fickle, and one o naturally inclin'd to addres himelf to all orts of Women, not regarding whether they be nobly or meanly decended, that it very much cools my affection towards him, and makes me fear his alliance, though I find my elf ufficiently inclin'd thereto, could I perceive any likelihood of his reforming himelf of that inufferable humour. But, far from that, ince my coming into Spain, when he hould have endeavour'd to give me greater aurances of his affection, I find him as indifferent as to my atisfaction
as ever: and God knows with what apprehenions I am induc'd to condecend to this Match. For if I am now frightned at the thoughts of his mi-carriages, what mut I not fear, when he hall become my Mater? The obedience I owe my Father, and the neceity I find that this Marriage hould be concluded, for the compoure of ome differences in our Family, make me wholly paive in the buines, and o content it hould go forward. I admit of his Addrees not without ome violence to my own inclination, and all I can do, is to pray Heaven, that it would inpire him with better reolutions.

Don Pedro could have wih'd that he had not been o reolute, as he eem'd to be. He therefore, though then peronating a Fool, anwer'd her as a wie Man, and advis'd her to bear a while with the failings of her Couin. Depair not, Madam, aid he to her, but Don Leopoldus may become another Man, and that if he be uch as you decribe him now, that volatile humour will be fix'd in him, when he hall come to be poes'd of o fair and accomplih'd a Lady. But he reolv'd, upon the firt opportunity hould preent it elf, to expres his mind to her in other tearms, and to make a full dicovery of himelf to his Mitres.

They came that day to Valladolid, and Leopoldus met them half a days Journey hort of it. He was very kindly receiv'd both of the Marques and his Daughter, whereat the diguis'd Don Pedro was not a little troubled: for finding Don Leopoldus a very graceful peron, he began to entertain ome doubts of the ucces of his enterprize. The Marques
thought fit to make him acquainted with Don Pedro, that, by the Character he gave him, he might accordingly treat him. Nephew, aid he to him, I pray take notice of this noble Cavalier, who hath honoured us with his company from Galicia, for his peron, and the rare qualities he is Mater of are uch as deerve the highet eteem. I deire you to repect him accordingly, and aure your elf all you do will be below his merit, not onely upon the accompt of the Royal Blood from which he is decended, but alo the Romantick title he aumes to himelf, of Knight of the honourable Order of the Marigold. He pretends a juridiction over all thoe places where ever any of that Herb grows, and never ees it, but he thinks of the complexion of a Mitres he once had, who pent mot of her time in Kitchin-Gardens, in one whereof it was Love's pleaure to make him a Captive to her Beauty, as he was gathering ome Marigolds.

This decription made Don Leopoldus take a particular notice of Don Pedro, and he doubted not, as well by his accoutrements, as by the fantatick title he had taken to himelf, to conclude him a mot trancendent Extravagant, and that, as uch, they had entertain'd him into their Company. Accordingly, to comply with his Uncle, he made this complement to Don Pedro. Mot honourable Knight of the Marigold, I hall receive your acquaintance with as great atisfaction as I hould do that of the greatet Monarch in the world, and think my elf infinitely oblig'd to you, that, being a peron of uch extraordinary parts, you were pleas'd to honour the Marques my Uncle, and my Couin, with
your company o far out of your own territories. In acknowledgement of that noble favour, be pleas'd to accept the proffer I make to you of ever being your mot affectionate and mot humble Servant, than which I cannot expect a higher relation to you, when I conider the character my Uncle hath been pleas'd to give you.

Don Pedro return'd him his mot humble thanks, and aid to him, I have o high an eteem for whatoever this fair Lady is concern'd in, that I hall make it my buines to acrifice all you think mot excellent in me to her atisfaction and yours, as long as it hall pleae his Excellency to give me leave to be of his retinue. How, replies Leopoldus, may we expect that further happines as to enjoy your company for ome time? I ee no reaon you have to be o glad of it, replies the Marques, for you are to know, that Don Pedro Gil is fallen deeply in love with your Couin, and that it is his affection hath occaion'd this acquaintance, though he hath aur'd me, that, ince he undertood he was deign'd for you, that Love is turn'd into a pure fraternal friendhip, and under that innocent paion he endeavours to oblige her what lies in his power. Be pleas'd to take my further aurance of it, ays Don Pedro, that no thought of that may break your ret; for that conideration laid aide, I hould think my elf capable to raie a jealouie even in Narcius himelf, were he now alive: for I dare, without any vanity, affirm it, that there is not a peron in the world may be compar'd to me either as to gracefulnes of body; or accomplihments of mind. I am ufficiently
convinc'd of the truth of what you ay, ays Leopoldus, though I have not known you long: and therefore wholly relying on the promie you make me, I hall fear nothing as to your pretenions, which were they any other Man's, I hould not be guilty of o great an indifference.

With thee dicoures, they got to the Court, and the Ambaadour being alighted at his Houe, he there found many Ladies, impatiently expecting the arrival of the fair Lady Margaret, who was receiv'd out of her Litter into the arms of her deign'd Husband, whereat Don Pedro could do no les than conceive a little jealouie. Leopoldus, to begin the demontrations of his Love, had prepar'd a magnificent Supper, to which were invited all thoe, of both Sexes, who were come thither to receive the Ambaadour and his Daughter.

Don Pedro went to Bed preently after Supper, extreamly troubled in mind, that he had engag'd himelf in an enterprize, wherein he found o great difficulties. He could not imagine any means to bring it about, o as that he might come off with credit; he met with too many Obtacles, and what afflicted him mot of all, was, the reolution the Lady had taken to atisfie her Father's deire, who was deirous the marriage hould be concluded with Leopoldus, though he had been acquainted, as well as he, with him mi-carriages. Felician could not forbear grumbling at the reolution of his Mater, which mut have ended amidt thoe difficulties. He expos'd himelf as an Extravagant peron in a Court where he might have rais'd himelf into eteem, and out of a hope not likely to be brought to any effect,
he ran himelf daily into new inconveniences. The Mater and Servant pent ome part of the night in dicouring about the buines, till at lat Don Pedro fell aleep, with a reolution to dicover himelf to his Mitres, and, if his addrees were not well entertain'd by her, to return immediately into Galicia.

The viits of the Cavaliers and Ladies, continu'd ix days, during which time the Marques and his Daughter were often een, both of them taking much pleaure in the pleaant demeanour of Don Pedro, who acted the part he had undertaken o admirably well, that his Extravagancies became the dicoure of the whole Court, all peaking of him as one of the mot humorous Fools that had come upon the Stage of a long time; inomuch that ome advis'd the Ambaadour to bring him to the Palace, auring him the King would be much pleas'd with his behaviour. Don Pedro coming to hear of it, eem'd to be very angry, and excus'd himelf, out of a fear his Majety might not entertain him, uitably to his quality and extraction; that he would not run the hazard of receiving an affront, and that the leat di-repect hewn him would force him to violent reentments thereof. The Ambaadour pres'd him no further, let he might put him out of humour, perceiving he lik'd not the propoal, and put it off to ome other time, when haply he might find him more inclin'd to compliance.

Leopoldus, who was alo Lodg'd in the Ambaadour's houe, had onely two Servants to wait on him, whom he truted with the knowledge of all his Loveadventures. It happen'd that both thee fell Sick
at the ame time, a time when he hould have hewn more reerv'dnes in his Amours, to raie himelf into a better eteem with his Mitres; but he, on the contrary, minded his own enjoyments above all things, and never conidering the preent poture of his affairs, he continu'd his Night-viits, as he was wont to do before her arrival. Being thus diappointed of their attendance, who were bet acquainted with his humours, he conceiv'd he could not pitch on a fitter peron to accompany him than Felician, who, with the leave of his Mater Don Pedro, went along with him. Finding him a ubtle fellow, and experienc'd in uch affairs, he thought him a peron fit for his purpoe, and accordingly that he might trut him with any thing. He took him along with him three or four nights together to a certain Houe, out of which he came at a very uneaonable hour. Though Felician went in with him, yet durt he not be o impertinently inquiitive, as to ask who was the Mitres of the Houe, till the third or fourth night that he had accompany'd him thither; and then being alone with a Servant-maid (who taking example by her Mitres began to expres ome kindnes towards Felician) he ask'd her whoe Houe that was, and to whom Leopoldus made his Viits. Love and Secrecy are eldome found in the ame Lodging. She was a Servant, and in love with Felician; there needs no more be aid, to make it apppear, that he atisfy'd him in whatever he deir'd to know. Felician undertood from her, that that Houe belong'd to his Mater's Aunt, and that his own Siter was the Peron whom Leopoldus had at rack and manger, upon a promie of Marriage he
had gotten from him a little before under his hand, he, by reaon of her retirednes, being innocently ignorant of the treaty of marriage between him and his Couin the Lady Margaret.

Felician, having pump'd out all thee particulars, fail'd not to give his Mater an account thereof the next day. Don Pedro was extreamly urpris'd thereat; not without indignation againt his Siter, though that procedure of Leopold rais'd him into ome hope of effecting his deign, preuming the more upon it, in that being equal, as to birth, to Leopold, he was reolv'd ne hould never marry any other, than her whom he had o highly dihonour'd. He thereupon commanded Felician to acquaint the Maid who had made thoe dicoveries to him, that the marriage of Leopoldus and his Couin was agreed upon, and that a Meenger was ent to Rome for the Dipenation, not forgetting the rare accomplihmen • s of the Lady Margaret; to the end he might acquaint his Siter therewith, to ee what coure he would take, and how he would remedy the affront intended her. He punctually executed the orders he had receiv'd from Don Pedro, o that the night following Donna Blanca (o was Don Pedro's Siter called) was acquainted with the whole buines. She thereupon had a great contetation with Don Leopold, who impudently deny'd that he had any thing to do, as to marriage with his Couin. In fine having done all he could to vindicate himelf, and appeae Donna Blanca, he pretended to be atisfy'd with him, provided he more fully jutify'd his innocence the next morning. So he dimis'd Leopold, who went away well atisfy'd, imagining her to be o too: but reolving with himelf
not to give her any viit a while, he pretended ome indipoition. Don Pedro undertood that night from Felician all that had pas'd between Don Leopold and his Siter, and was extremely incens'd againt her that he had given credit to the deceitful words of a perfidious man. However he thought fit to let pas two days, to ee what coure his Siter would take in that time, commanding Felician to proecute his dicoveries.

The next day, Don Leopold not coming to clear himelf, as he had promis'd, Donna Blanca was o enrag'd, that he would tay no longer, but reolv'd to be atisfi'd from the mouth the Ambaador, of the affront intended to be done her. She took a Coach, and veiling her face, came to his houe, but at uch an unfortunate time, that he met Don Leopold at the door, who, dicovering who he was, preently imagin'd what might occaion that viit, and that her coming thither was to acquaint the Ambaador how he was engag'd to her, and to hew him the promie of marriage. Don Leopold receiv'd her with extraordinary kindnes, which he taking otherwie than he expected, added the more to his upicion. He told her, he had omething particular to acquaint her with, and entreated her to go along with him to a room at ome ditance from his Uncle's lodgings. Donna Blanca would not be peruaded a good while to give him that atisfaction, telling him, that he mut firt peak with the Ambaador, and that afterwards he hould talk with her as long as he pleas'd. That Don Leopold endeavour'd to prevent, auring her, that he was at that time very buie, looking over a Pacquet of Letters he had receiv'd from
the Emperor. He was o importunate with her, that he would hear him before he poke with the Ambaador, that at lat he prevail'd. Whereupon conducting her to Don Pedro's chamber, he entreated him to keep her company, till he came back to peak with her.

Donna Blanca having her face veil'd all this time, Don Pedro knew her not, but by the dicoveries he had receiv'd, he upected her to be his Siter. On the other ide, he was o transform'd by the extravagance of his cloaths, and, what added much to his diguie, his perpetual wearing of Spectacles, that he could not have the leat imagination of his being her Brother. Don Pedro kept her company a while, without enquiring into the occaion of her coming thither, and at lat, leaving her lock'd up in the room, he went to look for Don Leopold, to know how he would have him dipoe of her. He was then buie with his Uncle, ent one to deire Don Pedro, to entertain that Lady a while, with this excue, that, as oon as he could, he would come and dipatch her. Don Pedro returning to his Chamber, immediately lock'd the door.

In the mean time, the Lady Margaret had undertood, that her Couin had poken to a Woman with her face veil'd, in one of the walks leading to the Ambaador's houe, and deit'd Don Pedro to conduct her to his chamber. The jealouie he conceiv'd thereat rais'd in her a deire to know who he might be, which he might eaily dicover, by reaon there was a paage from her lodgings to Don Pedro's chamber, and at the end of it a door, whereof he had the key. She open'd it very oftly, let he might be
perceiv'd, and that jut as Don Pedro, coming into the room, found his Siter with her face unveil'd, expecting to be een onely by Don Leopold, whom onely he taid for. As oon as he had taken a leight view of her, he made this dicoure to her.

p.q:
Ungracious and unhappy woman, unworthy the Houe out of which thou art decended, and that I hould call thee my Siter! Is it poible thou houldt be guilty of o trange an oblivion of thy elf, as, relying on the vain promies of a treacherous peron, to come into this houe to eek him who hath abus'd thee, and to whom thou hat impudently protituted thy elf? Comet thou to importune a man that hath forgotten thee, and to court him who hath o palpably deceiv'd thee? If, beotted with a fond love, it be thy deign to be married to him, thou hat friends to whom thou might't have communicated thy deires, rather than have abandon'd thy elf to a man who treats thee with o much contempt, and, notwithtanding all his carees, laughs at thee in his leeve. He is upon the point of marriage with his Couin; art thou o imple, as that thou onely houldt be ignorant of what is known all over the Court? Had I not a repect for the place where thou art, this word hould dipatch thy criminal Soul into the other world, that thou might't be an example to all uch imple Gulls as thou art. Hat thou o far forgotten the repect due to thy Aunt as to profane her houe, by aigning Leopold his nocturnal meetings in it? Thou houldt have bethought thy elf who thou art, that he is of no better Houe than thy elf, and that thy quality is as high as his. 'Tis
a great happines to thee, that an humour took me to come into this Court, though thou eet me in this ridiculous habit, to prevent, what lies in my power, Leopold's further abue of thee; which I will do with the hazard of my life. Tell me, infamous woman, what hath pas'd between you, that I may take ome coure therein, and diemble not the truth in any thing, for it concerns thee no les than honour and life.

div.p: The diconolate Donna Blanca heard this dicoure with her eyes fatned on the ground and flowing with tears, without giving him the leat interruption: but at lat, to obey her Brother, whoe indignation he aw jutly grounded, he told him, in few words, how Leopold had een her at a certain publick meeting, that he lik'd her, and, having enquir'd out her lodgings, he had ent her everal Letters; that having continu'd his addrees to her with great demontrations of affection, he had granted him entrance into the houe, and that upon a promie of marriage under his hand (which he had about her) he had permitted him to dipoe of her as he pleas'd. In fine, he gave him a particular account of all that had happened between them; whereupon he, to add no more to her affliction, put her in ome hope, that Leopold hould be forc'd to perform the promie he had made her.

The fair Lady Margaret had heard all this dicoure, at the door which was between her lodgings and Don Pedro's chamber, extremely atonih'd how a peron of quality (uch as he found Don Pedro to be by his dicoure) and one of uch an excellent wit, could put on a Fool's coat, and behave himelf as an
extravagant in their houe, and all about the Court. She was ignorant of the caues of that trange Metamorphois, and yet he had a certain upicion, that it might be upon her account. On the other ide, he reflected on the double treachery of her Couin Don Leopold, in treating of a marriage with her, having given a promie of the ame thing to another, and that a peron o highly qualifi'd as Donna Blanca eem'd to be.

Being fully atisfi'd as to thoe two things, he would not tand to hear them any longer, but ruh'd into the room o of a udden, as that he had not the time to put any thing over her face, nor he, to diemble his indignation. Seeing her coming towards them, Ah Madam, aid he to her, what mean thee Ambuhes? What's your deign therein, Sovereign Princes of my Soul, and abolute Directres of my inclinations? Do you ue uch a treachery againt thoe who could not o much as imagine you guilty of any uch thing? I wih o great a Beauty would not give me any more uch apprehenions, for another urprie of this nature would make me die out of pure joy, as it hath been the fortune of others to die out of an exces of grief. There is no diembling any longer, replies the Lady, for I am fully aur'd that you are not the peron you eem to us to be, and that the affliction you are in requires rather ecret and real reentments, than peronated extravagancies. My curioity heightned by a little jealouie, procur'd me the dicovery of more than you imagine; I have found the perfidiounes of my Couin Don Leopold, greater towards me than I could have expected,
conidering his pretended kindnees. I would fain be deliver'd out of the confuion I am in, and I earnetly intreat you to reolve me this riddle, for its obcurity perplexes me very much: but before you take that trouble upon you, give me leave to carry this Lady your Siter to my lodgings, and if my Couin comes in the mean time to enquire after her, you may tell him, that he went away much dipleas'd at his long tay, and leave the ret to me.

Having o aid, he took Donna Blanca along with her, auring her he would do all lay in her power to erve her, which put her in hope of a better ucces in her affairs, than he could have deriv'd from either her Brother's indignation or Leopold's treachery. The Lady Margaret left Donna Blanca among her Women, and returns to Don Pedro, who though at firt upriz'd at the ight of her, and the thought of her having over-heard the infamy of his Siter; yet was he withal glad of it, ince her jealouie and curioity had dicover'd his transformation, and the unhandome carriage of her Couin. Don Pedro therefore was very glad to ee his Mitres return'd, as might be een by the chearfulnes of his countenance. She deir'd him to take a chair, and doing the like her elf, he open'd her mind to him in thee words.

p.q:
I have been in an extraordinary confuion for ome days pat, and o incens'd againt my Couin Don Leopold, to ee the trangenes of his behaviour towards me, that I come to receive your advice how far I ought to reent it, and withal to be atisfi'd in ome things, whereof I mut yet acknowledge
my elf ignorant. One is, and that much raies my wonder, to ee you counterfeiting the Fool and Extravagant, in a Court, where you might rather act the part of a peron of Honour and Gallantry, as having the advantage of being Brother to o fair a Lady as Donna Blanca, who, beides the recommendation of beauty, eems to be Mitres of many other good qualities. You may infer from my dicoure, that being of the quality I uppoe you to be, you dihonour your elf in repreenting the Natural and ridiculous peron, as well in regard of the habit you have aum'd, as the extravagant actions wherewith you amue the world. Which ince I cannot imagine you would do but that there mut be ome great mytery in it, I am the more deirous to know your motives thereto, in that I conceive it will be a means to clear my mind of certain doubts which now lie omewhat heavy upon it.

div.p:
Having deliver'd this with the bet grace in the world, the fair Lady was ilent, and left Don Pedro the liberty to make her this reply. If you find me at any los, Madam, in atisfying your deires as to this particular, I quetion not but you will have the goodnes to attribute it, to that ditraction poor mortals are ubject to, when they addres themelves to the objects of their vows and adorations. You cannot be ignorant, (though you knew it not by experience) that Love is a powerful Divinity, to whom men acrifice all things; no impotures but he invents; no intrigues but he is author of; no difficulties but he overcomes, to compas his deignes. This premis'd, I am in the next place freely
to acknowledge, that the day you pas'd through Ville-Franche, which is the place of my birth, I found my elf wounded by the lightning of your fair eyes. I did all lay in my power to oppoe that paion; but it till prov'd predominant, and the engagement I knew there was between you and your Couin Don Leopold could not abate ought thereof. Nay though I knew all the particulars of that engagement, wherein you rather compli'd with the commands of a Father then your own inclinations, inamuch as you look'd on that too happy Kinman, as a fickle peron, unworthy your affection, a truth I have ince heard confirm'd by your elf; nay though I aw the marriage in a manner concluded, yet all could not break the reolution I had taken to diguie my elf as you have een to travere it, and fortune now eems to favour my deignes. I am not therefore, Madam, to repent me of the lurre I may have put upon my Bloud and the noble Houe from which I am decended, in acting the Fool's part in yours, into which it was my buines to introduce my elf by all means imaginable, ince the impoture hath prov'd o fortunate, and that I begin to conceive ome hope of attaining my deires. You know, Madam, that I durt not have preum'd to make you a real dicovery of my elf; for beides that I hould run the hazard of not finding credit with you, I came in at a time when your marriage was in too great forwardnes to be eaily cros'd by afterapplications. In fine, it was Heaven's pleaure, that a trange conjunction of my Siter's misfortune, and your own jut jealouies, hould give you
a dicovery of what, haply, I hould yet a while have kept from your knowledge. My true name is Don Pedro d' Oorio and Toledo, and conequently I may affirm my elf to be of the mot eminent Families of Spain, ince I am decended from the Seignors of Ville-Franche and Astorga. I have the honour to be Knight of the Order of Alcantara, and I have acquir'd it by ome years ervices done his Majety in Flanders, with hopes, ere long, to be gratify'd with an advantageous Commandery. I have given you an account of my Quality, and have not conceal'd from you my preumption. All I how now to Apologize for, is, my Love; and, I am the more confident of your pardon as to that, if you but ever o little conider the unavoidable influence of your own attractions. Nay I cannot but account it a happy offence, ince it hath prov'd the occaion of your being undeceiv'd; and when I make a joynt reflection on my own happines, and my Siter's credulity, I cannot repent me of a diguie, whereof the atisfaction infinitely exceeds the hame. For it is in your power to retore me the honour I have depriv'd my elf of, onely for your ake; and I hall force him, who hath cajoll'd my Siter out of her Honour, to perform the promie he hath made her, or it hall cot him his Life.

The fair Lady was ravih'd to hear thee words from her diguis'd Lover, and thought her elf oblig'd to make an extraordinary return to o extraordinary a demontration of affection. And being now fully undeceiv'd as to the Sycophancy of her Couin Don Leopold, he made him this Anwer. Signor Don
Pedro, That you have, upon o light a ground as the little beauty I can pretend to, engag'd your elf in an enterprize o prejudicial to your reputation and decent, I cannot but look on as a trancendent expreion of your Love; though I do not excue you as to this, that the noble accomplihments you are mater of might no doubt have more happily and more worthily been otherwie employ'd. I have reented, as I ought, the little repect my Couin expres'd towards me, and therefore it is but jut he hould not enjoy me, ince it may be inferr'd from the forwardnes of his matching with another, that he never truly intended it. It mut needs be an extraordinary joy to me, that I am undeceiv'd before we were joyn'd by that Tye which onely Death can diolve. I am atisfy'd as to the little affection he had for me, and I do yours but jutice, when I aure you, that I hall be o far from forgetting it, that I hall endeavour all lies in my power to requite it.

This was deliver'd with o obliging an accent, that the amorous Cavalier would have cat himelf at her feet, would he have permitted it. He return'd her his thanks with a thouand ubmiions for o extraordinary a favour, and the weet encouragement he was pleas'd to give his Love. It was not now a eaonable time to expatiate into Complements; Donna Blanca was left in the Lady Margaret's Lodgings, whoe return he expected, and Don Pedro look'd for Don Leopold, to enquire after the Lady he had recommended to his cutody. The Lady Margaret went to comfort her whom he had left among her
Women, and to put in execution what had been reolv'd, between her and Don Pedro. About half an hour after her departure thence comes Don Leopold to his Chamber, to look after the Lady he had left there. Don Pedro told him, that he could tay her no longer, that he was gone, thinking he would not have come to her again. Nay then, I am glad I taid o long, ays Leopold, ince my tay hath occaion'd her to do as I would have had her, which was that he might be gone out of the houe. This Woman plagues me extreamly, and it was no mall happines to me, that he met not with my Uncle, for I hould have been much troubled had he had any dicoure with him. Don Pedro ask'd him ome odd quetions, as he was wont to do, to ift omething further out of him, but Don Leopold would dicover no more. The other eaily apprehended, by the little had fallen from him, what coure he intended to take; and the indignation he conceiv'd at his lighting of his Siter was o great, that it was not without much violence done himelf, he forbore calling him to account for it.

In the mean time the Lady Margaret had viited Donna Blanca, of whom he had receiv'd a punctual relation of her Loves, which were but too much confirm'd to her by the promie of Marriage he had brought with her. And after he had entred into a econd admiration at the double perfidiounes of her Couin Don Leopold, he ent to deire her Father to come to her, who being alone with her, he made him this dicoure.

p.q:
It hath ever been a laudable cutom, that Fathers hould dipoe of their Daughters in Marriage,
as they either pleas'd themelves, or found mot convenient for their affairs, but with this caution, that it hould not be abolutely done contrary to their wills and inclinations.
