Many are yet willing to do o, out of a preumption, that Matrimony will change Men's humours: but it is eldome found to work that effect. Thoe therefore may be aid to do well, who, referring the ucces to the higher Powers, by an implicite obedience, comply with the dipoal of their Parents: but thoe, in my judgement do better, who ue ome precaution, and endeavour to prevent the inconveniences, which they mut otherwie fall into. I have ever been ready, Sir, to do whatever you commanded me, epecially in the buines now in agitation, though I have found my Couin Don Leopold to be of a dipoition o contrary to mine, that I promis'd my elf little atisfaction from our being joyned together in the ineparable etate you intended. I have endeavour'd to obey you, though with ome violence to my own inclinations, which directed my affection to other perons not inferiour to him, either in quality or etate. I conented to this Marriage becaue you eem'd o much to deire it. When it was fully concluded, there was a peron ent to Rome for the Dipenation; and even during that time, when I expected my Couin hould have expres'd mot Love to me, I have found he hath done quite contrary, ince he hath given a promie of Marriage to another Lady, whom you hall preently ee.

div.p:
She thereupon call'd for Donna Blanca, whom he had left in her own Chamber, and who immediately
came before the Ambaadour. Having dipos'd her into a Chair, the Lady Margaret continu'd her dicoure. This, Sir, is the Lady I poke of, to whom my Couin hath given a promie of Marriage under his hand, which he now hath about her, and you hall ee, how this perfidious peron became thereby mater of her Honour. Coming hither to peak with you, and complain of the affront intended her, he met him, who, giving her fair wo ds, lock'd her into Don Pedro's Chamber, under pretence that you were buie, and that it would be long ere you would be een by her. Some little curioity occaion'd my going to that door, which is between my Lodgings and his, and there I came to the knowledge of this buines, having over-heard ome part of their dicoure. I thought fit to bring this Lady to my Chamber, to give you further atisfaction of o preing a Truth. Her quality is great, ince he is of the Houe of Oorio and Toledo, two of the mot illutrious Families of Spain: She is reolv'd to make the cae known to her Friends, who are very noble, and of great credit in this Court, that they may oppoe my Marriage and prevent our common affront. I have hitherto obey'd you as a Father, I now appeal to you as my Judge, and I be eech you dicharge me of o unjut an obedience for the future: for I am reolv'd rather to confine my elf for the ret of my days, in the mot autere Monatery about this City, than ever be Wife to a Man o inenible of worth and honour.

The Ambaadour was extreamly atonih'd at both what he aw, and what he had heard. He examin'd
the promie made to Donna Blanca, and found, that that dicovery alone was ufficient to prevent his Daughter's marriage with Leopold. He immediately reolv'd to break all to pieces, and to dimis his Nephew, that there might be no more talk of the buines. He caus'd the Ladies to with-draw, and ent for his Nephew, whom he hew'd the chedule he had made to Donna Blanca, asking him whether he knew the hand. He not a little troubled, and changing colour, began to deny it: but the Ambaadour told him, that as he could not do it incerely, o it would be very unhandomely proffer'd, ince the truth would be prov'd by everal of his Letters written with the ame hand. At lat Don Leopold, not without extream confuion, acknowledg'd, that, blinded by Love, he had indeed made that promie, but he would loe his Life ere he perform'd it.

Don Pedro having quitted his Fool's coat, and put on a very Rich uit, with the Cros of Alcantara on the Caock, and the Cloak, heard this dicoure from a corner of the Room where he was dipos'd, and not able to endure any longer: Signor Leopold, aid he coming up to him, have a better care what you ay, and conider her quality whom you injure. Her birth is at leat as noble as yours. She is my Siter, and, as uch, I am oblig'd to vindicate and protect her: if you perform not the promie you have made her, I wear a Sword by my ide which hall force you to do it, if Honour will not. I have already conider'd what I am in duty oblig'd to, as to that point, replies Don Leopold, and no Man hall force me, by menaces, to do any thing againt my will. This o enrag'd Don Pedro,
that he gave Don Leopold a challenge. The dipute grew higher and higher, which oblig'd the Ladies to come in between them, and to give order the doors hould be hut, let they might get out to fight.

While thee things pas'd, the Ambaadour minded not the peron of Don Pedro, and imagin'd him ome other peron come thither after his Siter: for, eeing him o well clad with the Cros of Alcantara, and without Spectacles, which he contantly wore, he knew him not: but having conider'd him better, he found that he who challeng'd his Nephew was the ame peron, who, by his pleaant extravagancies, had found him o much port. The Lady Margaret perceiving her Father had his Eyes faten'd on him, with ome atonihment, imagin'd the caue of it, and gave it a check in thee words. He, Sir, whom you ee in a habit o different from that he was wont to wear, and who eem'd o ridiculous to you, is Don Pedro d'Oorio and Toledo. When this dipute is over, you hall know the motives oblig'd him to that diguie.

The Ambaadour was the more atonih'd at that, and would have pres'd his Daughter to make a further dicovery of that ecret, had he not een the two Cavaliers, with Swords drawn, ready to make that Room the place of their Duel. He ran in between them, and endeavour'd by mildnes to peruade his Nephew, not to contet in a buines, which was not to his advantage; that if he atisfy'd not the injur'd Cavalier, michief would follow; that he hould not rely on any protection he might hope from him, inamuch as eeing the little reaon he had of his ide, and the affront he intended that Lady, he hould
rather be againt him, by aiting his Adverary, than countenance him in o unjut a buines. That as to his Daughter, he might quit all hope of her, that he hould never be her Husband, and that it would dicover a great poornes of pirit in her, if he had any thoughts of kindnes for him, after he had been o unworthily treated by him.

Don Leopold, finding himelf pres'd with reproaches on all ides, and withall hearkning to the advice of his Concience, thought it bet, to follow his Uncle's counel. He thereupon went with open arms to his true Wife, to whom he once more gave his hand as a Husband, and then embrac'd his Brother-in-law, whom he yet knew not. The Lady Margaret thought it a good opportunity, before the whole Company, to give her Father an accompt how Don Pedro had fallen in love with her, how he got into his Retinue in the quality of a Jeater; that he conceiv'd her elf oblig'd to requite the extraordinary demontration of his affection to her, by an exchange of hers to him, if her Father approved thereof. The old Gentleman had o much mettal left, as to admire the trange conduct of Love in all its operations, and particularly, how it made the wiet Men mad, and the Mad wie, making its advantages of extravagance it elf, to compas its deigns. Without any further demurring, he gave his conent, whereupon the Lady Margaret took him by the hand, and Don Pedro was o happy, as, by odd and unlikely means, to ee all his deires accomplih'd. The olemnities of both the Marriages were put off till eight days after; all the Grandees about the Court came to them. The Balls thereat,
and the Tilting were extraordinary: but what more nearly touches the tory, is, that the King honour'd thee two Cavaliers with great advantages, wherewith Don Pedro had alo thoe of a numerous iue, for which Don Leopold needed not much to have envi'd him, being the mot atisfi'd man in the world with his choice, whom he infinitely loved, and thereby made it appear, that the Inclinations of two perons, before they are united by Matrimony, though by ome intervening occurrences omewhat remitted, may yet, by that acred Tie, be heightned into a noble and vigorous flame of perfect Love.

THE Novel was lik'd and commended by all that heard it, nay Rufina was extremely atisfi'd therewith. Brother Cripin, who repos'd a very great confidence in her, was nothing troubled that he hould over-hear the deigns laid by him and his Camerades to earch thoe places, where they had notice there was anybooty. Cripin approved of ome of the Robberies propos'd by them, and oppos'd others, for the inconveniences he found in the execution thereof: for they look'd on him as a peron of great authority among them. His experience in affairs of that kind was uch, that he aum'd the title of Director, or rather Dictator of that famous Society: inomuch that not any one durt contradict what he had once decreed. It was by this time grown very late, o that they would not make a Divident of what they had brought in that night, leaving it to be done at the next meeting, and committing it to the cutody of the Hermit, who was their very faithful Steward.
Crispin's Companions being gone to their quarters, he thought it incivility for him to do the like ere he had made a viit to Rufina, to wih her a good night's ret. He found her a little more chearful than he had ever oberv'd her before, whereat he was very glad. He ask'd her what he thought of the Novel; he told him, that he thought it very pretty and full of diverion, and that if he might often hear the like, they would procure ome abatement of her melancholy. Take a good heart, Madam, ays the Hypocrite to her, I hope you will here ee an end of your affliction; we hall endeavour to find you all the divertiement we can, and 'tis poible you may not repent your being among us, if you will but remit omething of your reerv'dnes, and lay aide, as a thing extremely trange in this place, ome part of your modety. Rufina thought it time to alleviate her everities with ome affability, and to quit her feigned grief. From that time, he began to treat the Hypocrite with greater kindnes, that he might the better execute the deign he had to make a Novice of an old Projector. Cripin went to bed, half laid aleep with her favourable looks, and the hopes derived thence, that the Fort would within a hort time be reduc'd, ince he had made his approaches o near, and taken off the Mask of his feign'd Hypocriie.

The next morning at the very break of day, Cripin's companions left the Hermitage, to eek out their livelihood, at their cot, who leat mitruted them. The Hermit himelf was oon after for his march into the City, to beg alms, where he was wont to receive any. He went to take his leave of Rufina,
who deir'd him to make very diligent enquiry for her Brother, giving him the marks of his face, peron, and cloaths, much different from thoe whereby Garay might have been found out. He lock'd the door on the out-ide, and carried away the key with him, which Rufina was not much troubled at; for he had brought with her from Corduba ome of thoe keys, which open all locks, an invention better than Picklocks, and ome other devices, which he had ued at the Genoee's. Thus was he left all alone in the Hermitage, having before-hand appointed Garay to come to her as oon as Brother Crispin got to Malaga; which he accordingly did, mounted on one of the two hores he had brought with him. Rufina having heard him, open'd the door, and gave him a hort account what trade Brother Crispin drove, of his falling in love with her, and how there was a coniderable umme of mony in the Hermitage, brought thither the night before by his Camerades. Rufina had reolv'd to carry away all the ready mony, in order whereto, he ent away Garay back to the City, to get ome leeping-powders, to be adminitred to Crispin at his return, that o they might have the whole night to do their work in. Garay brought the powder's before Cripin got home, for he pent the whole day in begging, and return'd not to the Hermitage till towards night.

Being got home, he was very kindly receiv'd by Rufina, whereat he was tranported with joy, for he grew more and more in love with her. He hew'd her what he had gather'd that day, and beides what had been voluntarily given him, he had very uncharitably taken, of his own accord, two ilver poons,
and a neck-lace of pearl. The neck-lace he immediately preented Rufina with, and put it about her neck, with a thouand amorous complements. She gave him infinite thanks for his Preent, after which they upp'd very merrily together, he ever and anon entertaining her with ome dicoveries of his love, whereto he gave him very favourable Anwers, promiing it hould not be long ere he had of her what he o much deired.

It had been ordered among the Ferrets that frequented the Hermitage, at the lat Committee, that a general meeting hould be had there that night, as well for the diviion of the former booty, as the making of new propoals. Cripin, who was not willing Rufina hould be een, and expected ome ecret kindnes of her, thought it concern'd him to prevent it. As oon as they were come together, he found out an evaion to dipere them. He told them, that he had received notice from the City, that there was a trict earch made for a peron who had treacherouly murther'd another; and inamuch as Sacred places were no Sanctuaries for uch cowardly Offenders, he feared there would be ome ent to the Hermitage, and if it chanc'd any one of them hould be apprehended for ome other crimes, he might be eiz'd and carried away prioner, and afterwards, brought to the Torture, confes what he had not been charg'd with at his apprehenion. Perons of that profeion are commonly tartled at any thing; accordingly they oon credited what their Director aid to them and left the Hermitage, adjourning the Aembly to the fourth night after. By this means Crispin was left alone in the Hermitage, with his Mitres,
who had promis'd to give him atisfaction that night; whereat he was almot out of himelf for joy, thinking he hould never ee the hour, that hould give him the poeion of that Beauty.

Soon after they went to upper, which was very magnificent, for Crispin had brought ome, both wild and tame, fowl, ready for the pit, and a good large bottle of Malaga, which is the bet of any wine in Spain. Rufina having plaid the cook, and made all things ready, they began both to eat very heartily, their minds disburthen'd of all care and trouble; healths were drunk, Rufina out-vying the Hermit at that exercie, and having the management of the bottle, he took care that Crispin never drunk without the powder prepar'd for him. He drunk as liberally as the other fill'd, till at lat, tumbling down under the table, he fell dead aleep, inomuch that Rufina, to try whether the potion had wrought its effect, pull'd him by the ears and noe, to awake him, but it was to as little purpoe as if he had done it to a dead corps. With that aurance, he went down into the Cellar, which was under ground, and out of certain chets he found there, he took all the mony he met with, whereof there was no mall quantity. She dipos'd it into bags, which he ty'd with cords, and into long leather pouches, wherein the Thieves had brought it, they having robb'd a rich Drover who was going to Madrid. That done, Rufina comes out, and, by a ignal, got Garay to her, who lay hard by perdue for that purpoe.

They took all the ready mony they could find and put it on Garay's Bay, and got up on the other hore, and put forward towards Mal • ga, extremely
pleas'd that they had o eaily trapann'd the ubtilet and mot experienc'd Thief in Europe. They left ome things behind them, which might have been well worth the conveyance thence; but it was a Maxim of theirs, never to burthen themelves with any thing that might be known or challeng'd. They oon got to Malaga, and took up their quarter's in Garay's Inn, Rufina not being een by the people of the houe, that night nor the next day. She knew what night the Conclave of the Hermitage was to meet; but ere I tell you what coure he took, me-thinks I hear Crispin noring, and calling to me, to give an account of him. He pent that night more innocently than he had done any one of a long time before, for, never tirring from the place where he had fallen aleep after upper, it may be preum'd he thought no hurt. By that time the Sun was got high enough to raie the flies from creeping to flying, he awoke, having not the leat apprehenion of what had happened to him in the night. He call'd Rufina, recollecting himelf o far, that by his exceive leepines he had mis'd the opportunity he had o much wih'd for; but all his calling was to no purpoe. He ought her all about the houe, in the Church, in the Cellar, and not finding her, he went out into the fields to look for her, thinking ome trange accident mut needs happen to her, when he found all the doors lock'd. He made a econd earch for her, but finding the chets open'd, and the bags of white and yellow pieces dilodg'd, he was convinc'd of his being robb'd, and that the poor innocent woman, frightned by the thieves, had made her ecape, and lay lurking omewhere about the neighbouring fields,
inamuch as he would not venture to go far in a dark night. He ought after her till he grew weary, but he was got far enough out of his reach. At lat, hearing no account of her, it came into his mind that he might be guilty of the robbery; which truck him o to the heart that he was ready to hang himelf, to think that o famous a Rogue, and one that had been, for o many years, the Dictator of a Crew of Villains, hould be o baely trapann'd by a woman; and then he inferr'd that all he had done was onely to bring him into the nooe. However, he went that day, as he was wont to do, to Malaga, to try if he might find her in the City. He met Garay, but having never een him before, he was never the nearer.

Rufina and Garay had et things in order for their departure to Cateel; but he would not go till he had erv'd the hyppocritical Hermit uch a curvy trick as that he might never fear any requital from him. She knew the time of their meeting at the Hermitage, a place intended for other ues than to be the Rendezvous of a pack of high-way-men and houe-breakers. That they might be all found together, to receive the chatiement due for their villanies, he writ a Letter to one of the Magitrates, acquainting him with the time, when, and the place where he hould find the Malefactors, and how they might be taken. That done, Garay and Rufina took their way for Toledo, towards which place, we hall leave them on their way, to give an account what was done upon the Letter. As oon as it was night, the Magitrate, attended by ome of his men, went to the Hermitage, beieg'd it, and got in. He found in the firt place Crispin, little thinking to receive
uch a viit: yet was it eaonable as to the preent ecuring of his life; for they were beginning to quabble about the mony lot, and the others charg'd Crispin with treachery, and 'tis likely he had had the wore among them, being but one to three. Having ecur'd him, they earch'd the whole houe, and at lat, went into the Cellar, where they found his Companions, as alo ladders of cords, pick-locks, iron-crows, and all the other engines fit for Gentlemen of their profeion. They alo earch'd the chets, in which they found everal pieces of Plate, and other things of value, undeniable demontrations of the devout exercies of that vertuous company. They were all taken and brought away Prioners. Crispin himelf was o much at a los, that he knew not what Anwer to make to what was ask'd him. Whereupon one of the Officers made him this comfortable dicoure: Ungracious and unfortunate man, vile Hypocrite, who, cover'd with the cloak of anctity, dot commit uch robberies! How will the world be urpriz'd to find it elf o mitaken in thee? How will others, who have entred into that holy profeion of renouncing the world and its enjoyments, uffer in the repects of men, when the infamous Hitory of thy life comes to be publih'd? Were not the charities betow'd on thee every day by o many good people, ufficient for thy competent ubitance, that thou might't pend thy time comfortably in a place o holy and o convenient for the erving of God as this is, but thou mut give thy elf over to the baet and mot digraceful employment in the world? Thou art now fallen into my hands, and I promie thee, that
neither thou, nor thy companions, hall get out of them, till you are to be honourably conducted to the Gallows or ome wore place.

With thee jut reproaches, he carried them away to the City, where they were condemn'd to die, all the others having, upon the Rack, confeed everal crimes, charging Crispin to have been the man, who gave them intelligence of the robberies, that were to be committed, and many times open'd the door for the better execution thereof. As for his part, he expres'd o much courage and reolution in the midt of his torments, that he obtinately deni'd whatever was laid to his charge. Yet could not all prevent the paing of the entence upon him, but the execution of it was a little delai'd, as to him, by reaon of his falling into a violent Feaver in the prion: but his companions were all trus'd out of the way. Not long after, Crispin being, upon his recovery, to follow them, went out of the prion, at noon-day, in womans cloaths, not without the great atonihment of all the world, who expected to ee his Exit hence, and to the greater affliction of the Jayler, who was conceiv'd to have been corrupted with mony, and to have et him at liberty. But he clear'd himelf, by producing the peron who had furnih'd him with the cloaths, wherewith he had diguis'd himelf, who was condemn'd to pend the remainder of his life, though he liv'd ninety-nine years, in the Gallies.
div.trailer: The end of the Third Book.

div.head: LA PICARA, OR The Triumphs of Female Subtilty.
The Fourth Book.
div.p:
Rufina and Garay were by this time gotten to the Imperial City of Toledo, where they had reolv'd to ettle themelves. To give the greater credit to her reputation, he pretended that Garay was her Father, and took a very fair Houe in the mot eminent quarter of the City; her train coniting of a Slave he had bought at Malaga, a waiting Gentlewoman, a Lackquey, and a Gentleman-uher, he had taken up at Toledo. She put on the habit of a Widdow, and Garay, very handomely clad for a peron of his Age, went under the name
of Don Jeronimo, and he under that of Donna Emerentiana, their Surname de Menezez, auming their decent from the illutrious Family of thoe, who, under that name, are o well known in Portugal. She bought Houhold-tuff uitable to the condition of a Widdow of Quality, and accordingly he was viited by the chiefet Ladies of the Quarter, who were extreamly atisfy'd, as well with the charms of her beauty as thoe of her converation, inomuch that they accounted themelves very happy in her Neighbour-hood. She oon became acquainted with many of her own Sex, who took for Gold all that Gliter'd in that ubtle Woman. Going every day to hear Mas in the great Church, it could not be long ere he was oberv'd by ome of the young Gallantillos of the City, who, having dipatch'd their Devotions, pend ome time in contemplations of the Ladies who may be preent. Accordingly, he being noted to be one newly come to Toledo, and withall very handome, there wanted not thoe who began to Languih for her, and make their Addrees to her.

While he is informing her elf who were the richet and likely to have mot ready Money, that he might not, for want of practice, forget her old Trade. We hall leave her taking her meaures, and her new Gallants preparing for their amorous adventures, and take a turn to Malaga, to ee what became of Crispin, after he had o cleaverly got out of Prion.

Finding himelf once more at liberty, he left Malaga, and got into a Wood, not far from the City, where he continu'd till Night, and then he
went to the Hermitage, where he had Liv'd many years in the reputation of a good Chritian, and a peron of a very exemplary Life. As oon as he was convicted of the crimes laid to his charge, there was put into his place a very Religious man, who went about to everal Churches, begging alms, to build a little Hopital there. He was not as yet fully etled in the Hermitage, the place being not yet furnih'd. Crispin got thither in the night, and oppoite to the South-ide of it found a place, where he had laid up omewhat againt a Rainy day. Breaking up the ground with a Hoe he had left in the Wood, he came at lat to a little Earthen pot, wherein was a Bagg, and in that all the Money he had reerv'd, of all the Robberies he had been engag'd in; for he ever had two hares of the Booty, for his two Offices of Director, and Concealer, of the good Company which frequented the Hermitage.

With that Summ, which might amount to five or ix hundred pounds terling, all in Gold, he went to the City of Jaën, where he had a friend of the ame profeion. This friend of his had heard of his ecape out of Prion, whereat he had been not a little troubled, inamuch as he might have made ome commemoration of his Camerade upon the Rack, with whom he had been engag'd in everal Robberies. He was very glad to ee Crispin at liberty, in hopes of his direction and aitance in ome new enterpries. Crispin was but poorly accoutred, as having been uncas'd of the Hermit's habit, which he had hewn himelf unworthy of; but the Bagg he had o well Lin'd was a overaign remedy againt Nakednes. He gave his companion Money to buy
him a Light-colour'd uit, and having taken off his long Beard, he put on a Periwig, which, with a Sword by his ide, diguis'd him o that he eem'd to be quite another Man, and not to be eaily known even by thoe who had been particularly acquainted with him. In that Equipage he continu'd ome time at Jaen, till there happen'd an opportunity to commit a coniderable Robbery at Andujar, which was very faithfully divided between him and his companion. But fearing the peron who had been Robb'd would make a diligent earch after them, Crispin thought it their bet coure to be gone thence in time, the adventure at Malaga being till freh in his memory.

They took into their company a third peron, whom they met with by chance, a young Man, born and bred in the City of Valentia; and they came to Toledo, where they had never been but as they travell'd through it. The new Camerade they had taken in, was call'd Jaimo, a poor Rope-maker's Son of Valentia, who, for ome roguih exploits he had done there, which brought him ome Money, had been oblig'd to abent himelf thence for ome years. He was a handome, fair-hair'd, prightly young Man, and beides the accomplihments of his peron, he had an excellent Wit, and was not inferiour, in ubtilty, to either Crispin or his Camerade.

This young Adonis went very Gallantly, upon their charges who either were ignorant or mindles of the old Proverb, Fast bind, fast find. He had the art to transform into the current Mode all the Cloaths he got by light of hand, and o diguis'd them by changing the Laces and Trimming, that the
very Owners could not have known them. On a certain Fetival day, he put on a very Rich uit, and went along with Cripin to Mas, in the great Church, and into the ame Chappel, where Rufina was at her Devotions, under the name of Donna Emerentiana. Though, as I told you, he was in a Widdow's habit, Cripin knew her at the firt bluh, and was not a little glad to ee her. He kept himelf from her knowledge, for fear of being dicover'd, though there was no great fear of it, as he was then accoutred. He hew'd Rufina to his Camerade Don Jaimo, who was infinitely taken with her; and having deir'd him to dogg her, o as he might not perceive it, he did it o cunningly, that he kept his Eye on her, though eeming to look another way, till he aw her go into her Houe. He was very glad to hear by the Neighbours, that he Liv'd there, and that in great Reputation, under the name of Donna Emerentiana de Menezez, lately come from Badajos, with her Father, to live at Toledo.

Crispin had a devillih pique againt her, for the curvy trick he had hewn him at Malaga, and heartily wore, that ince he had o fortunately dicover'd her, he would not leave Toledo, ere he had call'd her to an accompt for the Money he had carried away from the Hermitage, together with the interet, and all the charges of his Imprionment. To compas his deign, he intructed Jaimo what he had to do, and whom he hould repreent, without making a real dicovery of himelf to her. It was not long ere an opportunity offer'd it elf to proecute the deign they had agreed upon. One evening, about an hour before night, there chanc'd to be a
quarrel in the Street, where Rufina liv'd, wherein there were two Men wounded. The Officers of Jutice preently came in, and carried the wounded to their Houes to be dres'd, and ecur'd ome others that happen'd to be then in the treet, though nothing engag'd in the quarrel; which occaion'd others to run for't, it being no great pleaure to come into trouble and retraint for another Man's crime.

Crispin's plot took its rie from that Quarrel. Jaimo, intructed by that ubtle Hypocrite what he had to do, had taken the Cros of Knight of the Order of Montea, an honour betow'd by the King onely on the natural Inhabitants of the Kingdome of Valentia; and to that purpoe he had gotten a very light handome black uit made him. In this Equipage, being come to Rufina's houe, and having given his Cloak to Cripin, he drew his Sword, and went in, acting the part of a Man much atonih'd. Finding the door which led up tairs open, he goes up, and came into the room where the jovial Widdow was with her Maids. They were a little tartled to ee a Man coming in to them with his Sword drawn, without a Cloak, and in a manner frightned out of his Wits. Rufina roe from the place where he was ate, and found the Impotor in the poture of a uppliant, addreing himelf to her in thee words. If compaion be not at too great a ditance from o beautiful a countenance, be pleas'd, Madam, to let your Houe be my Sanctuary againt the Officers of Jutice by whom I am puru'd. That I have Kill'd a man, I mut acknowledge, but it was in my own defence, in this treet, where
he had et upon me with advantage. The Officers peruing me at the heels, I had infallibly been taken, had I not very courageouly made my party good, by laying two of the mot forward with their Bellies to the Sun, who with the Commiary had me in a manner by the Collar. I ecap'd from the ret, by the pure activity of my Leggs; for it is prudence for a Man to give way to the Magitrate, whom he is oblig'd to repect. But they periting till in the puruit, I found your Houe open for my afety, and I have taken the boldnes, hutting the door after me, to come up into your Chamber. I therefore mot humbly beeech you Madam, if it may be done without your inconvenience, that you would dipoe me into ome ecret corner of your Houe, till the people now in the treet be dipers'd, and that I may afely go hence. But if my preumption puts you to any ditraction, or give you any trouble, you need onely give me the leat ignal, and I will immediately go out into the Street, though I were ure to leave my Life in it, as chooing rather the horrours of Imprionment, than to be over-importunate to o fair a Lady.

We have already given a decription of this fine Orator. Rufina look'd very earnetly upon him; and he who never had lov'd any thing comparably to Money, immediately found her elf uceptible of an inclination towards that young Man, who eem'd to her as eloquent as he had thought him handome. Whereupon he return'd him this Anwer. You have done me but jutice, Sir, when you thought me enible of honour and compaion; perons
of my condition are never detitute thereof towards uch as you are. I preume, by what I ee of you, that you are a peron of Quality; and therefore ympathizing with your affliction, I heartily proffer you my Houe, to continue in it as long as you hall think fit, to avoid the puruit of thoe who look after you: for it were not jut you hould fall into their hands, ince, by my means you may be ecur'd from o great a danger. Fear not any thing here; for though the Officers hould come into the Houe, I hall put you into o ecret a place, that they hall never find you.

The young Spark gave her a thouand thanks for o ignal a favour, which oblig'd her to make him this further dicoure. You very well know, Sir, by the habit I am in, with what reerv'dnes I ought to live in my Houe, and yet I freely proffer you the ecurity you promie your elf in it, till you have accommodated your affairs. But I have a Father, now from home, who will expect an accompt of my demeanour: and if, at his arrival, which it may be will be this day, he will entertain you with a Room in his Lodgings, as I am confident he will think it an honour, I hall be content. The young Gallant renew'd his thanks to her, for that continuance of her kindnees, and he expres'd himelf o gentilly, that he was more and more taken with him.

In the mean time, thoe who were of the Plot, knock'd very confidently at the door, calling upon them to open to the Officers. The family was at firt a little tartled; but Rufina, recovering her elf out of the little diorder which appear'd in her countenance,
took Jaimo by the hand, and led him into an upper Room which had a double Partition, before which there was a piece of Hangings, and left him there, with an aurance it would be impoible to find him out. That done he went to open the door, and Cripin impudently comes in, without the leat fear of being known, being diguis'd as he was. He was attended by ome Rogues of his Profeion, who with Lanterns and Fire-arms, peronating the Officers of Jutice, uncivilly ruh'd into the Room where Rufina was. Cripin gave her a kind alute, and counterfeiting his Voice uitably to his Peron. I know, Madam, aid he, that it peaks a kind of incivility, to come o boldly into a VViddow's Houe; but my Charge obliges me thereto, and therefore you will excue me. The Lieutenant Criminal hath commanded me, to earch all the Houes hereabouts to ee if I can find a Malefactor we look for. Our earch hath hitherto been to no purpoe, and we have but this one Houe to earch; give us therefore leave to look into all the Rooms of it, that we may atisfie our Superiours, and withall our own Conciences. You may aure your elves, aid he to them, upon my word, that I aw no Body come into my Houe; but, that you may not think amis of me, or conceive me a Woman to helter Murtherers, and Michievous perons, earch, and ee whether you can find the peron you look for.One of the Maids took a Wax-candle to light them, and they viited everal Chambers, yet not too exactly, that the lightnes of the earch might be thought a Courteie.

That done, he civilly took leave, recommending
the proecution of the plot to his Camerade. The counterfeit Knight came out of his hole, pretending an extraordinary gladnes, that he had ecap'd their hands, who ought after him, and in expreions full of acknowledgment, he highly celebrated the favour he had receiv'd from the fair widow. She, who, the more he look'd on him, more and more fancied him, made him a thouand demontrations of Friendhip, aur'd him he hould be waited on at her houe according to his worth; and if he would have the patience to tay till her Father came in, he was confident he would not uffer him to go out of the houe that night.

The Gallant, who perceiv'd the Lady began to grow warm, was the more earnet to beg a leave which he aw would not be eaily granted him, told her, it would be his bet coure to take Sanctuary in ome Religious houe, whence he might end notice to his people at the Inn, where he was; that he was to go the next day for Sevil; and that he thought it not afe for him, to go that night to his quarters. Rufina, troubled to find him o reolv'd, more earnetly prees his tay, repreented to him the great hazard he ran, and deir'd him by all means to tay two hours longer.

Jaimo, who deir'd nothing o much, was peruaded to do o. She deir'd his permiion, to go and take order about ome things her Father had left her to do, whereof he was to give an account at his return. This was onely a pretence to get out, to confer with her lave, in whom he repos'd great confidence, what coure he hould take. She took her into another room, and freely acknowledg'd to her the
inclination he had for that Knight; that it troubled her to let him go out of the houe, let he might endanger his life, or at leat hazard his liberty: but on the other ide, he knew not, whether Garay would take it well that he detain'd him, and that he hould be in the houe all night. At lat, much troubled at thee difficulties, he deir'd her to give her the bet advice he could, and what he would reolve, were he in her condition.

The Slave, who was as ubtil a baggage as her Mitres, and immediately apprehended, that the advice he would bet like mut be uch as promoted her paion; I mut acknowledge, Madam, aid he to her, that it would argue an exceive eaines of nature in you, conidering the hort time you have known this Cavalier, to unboom your elf o far, as to give him a paage into your heart; and I think you would do imprudently on the other ide to peruade Garay, when he comes, to uffer his abode this night in the houe. My advice is, ince the houe is large enough, and that there are two or three empty rooms, into one whereof he may go through your lodgings, that you lodge him there, and make not any body acquainted therewith. It hall be my care to bring him thither, when I have made his bed, and upply him with all things requiite, without Garay's knowing of it. You know Garay is to be gone within thee two days for Madrid, and then you may freely enjoy your elf with this young Gentleman, whom it will be eaie for me to peruade, that the earch being till about the treet, it is abolutely neceary that he tay, if he will not hazard his life or liberty. The Slave's
advice was extremely pleaing to Rufina, who order'd her to go immediately and lay clean heets on the bed, and to put the Cavalier in poeion of the room. 'Twas preently put in execution, and not long after, the amorous Widow went by a private pair of tairs, to viit her Gallant. You will haply wonder, Sir, aid he to him, that without my Father's permiion, I have ventur'd to receive you into my houe, and that in the night: but to ecure a peron of worth, there may be a little breach made of the rules of modety. I have thought it mot convenient, that, as I have been a means of your avoiding the eyes of Jutice, o you hould alo keep out of my Fathers, to the end you may be here in all afety. Be pleas'd to think your elf oblig'd to me for this little ervice; but I render it you very heartily, nay I think it neceary, in order to your afety.

Jaimo, who perceiv'd this fih would come into the Weel, multiplies his acknowledgments by thouands for this new favour. That begat abundance of pleaant dicoures between them, whereof the iue was, that he heightning his flattery by his eloquence, ininuated himelf more and more into her good opinion; & celebrating, one after another, all the perfections and accomplihments of Rufina, he got the abolute dipoal of her heart. Yet would he have a little further trial of his incerity, to ee whether it were onely her beauty that drew him in, and whether it were true that the charms of it had o uddenly transform'd a peron, who fearfully fled into her houe for helter, into a confident Lover.

Upon this the Slave coming in, and giving her Mitres
an account that he had obey'd her commands, he took Jaimo by the hand, and led him to the room prepar'd for him. He found it light enough, as having in the midt of it a Branch, of Crytal, wherein were many wax-candles, and a magnificent Collation taying for him. He was a little urpriz'd to ee he left him alone, but her excue atisfi'd him, that he would be with him again, as oon as he had een her Father in bed. At her departure out of the room, he beheld him with eyes o full of love and tendernes, that that new demontration heightned the Gallant into an abolute confidence of the good ucces of his enterprie. Garay was not o far tricken in years, but that he had the courage left to pretend to the poeion of Rufina; he acted the part of her Gallant, and had he not been already married, he would have treated of a marriage with her. He kept his wife at Madrid, who, as many others do that are cat off, and lighted, betow'd the time of her Husband's abence on uch as would accept of her kindnes. Some years had pat ince he had heard from her, whereupon imagining he might be dead, he had reolv'd upon a journey to Madrid, to make a ecret enquiry after her, that, in cae he were remov'd out of the world, he might proecute his intentions to marry Rufina, who was infinitely oblig'd to him. Upon this account it was that he reolv'd his departure within two days.

Leaving him in thoe thoughts, let us return to Rufina, who et him to upper as oon as he was come in, and, pretending ome indipoition, excus'd her elf that he could not bear him company. It being his cutom to go to bed as oon as he had upp'd,
Rufina taid, till word was brought her, that he was fat aleep, and then went to her Gallant, cauing her own upper, which was that night omewhat more than ordinary, to be carried along with her. As oon as the cloth was taken away, during the interval which the ervants had to up, Rufina, who was more and more in love with her new Guet, entreated him to give her an account of his life, and incerely to acquaint her with his name, his country, and the occaion of his coming to Toledo. Jaimo, whoe deign it was onely to abue her, entertain'd her with this Romance, whereto he gave very earnet audience.

p.q:
My Country, Madam, is Valentia, one of the mot eminent Provinces of Spain; you know it well enough by name, and haply are not to learn, that it hath a great advantage over everal others, as well in regard of Nobility and wealth, as the temperature of its climate, and the delightful fertility of its oil. I am of the noble and antient Family of Pertua, well known all over that Kingdom. My name is Don Jaimo de Pertua, and the King, for the many good ervices done him by my Ancetors, hath honour'd me with the Order of Knight of Montea, and the Commanderie of Silla, which is the bet of any belonging to that Order. Beides what that brings me in, I have in other etate as much as may amount to three thouand Crowns per annum. I am the onely Son of the Family, and I made my addrees to a noble Lady of the City I was born in, named Donna Blanca Ceintillas, of one of the mot illutrious Families of Valentia, a Lady of excellent endowments. I have erv'd her with all the affection imaginable, whereto he gave
me no return, as being pre-ingag'd to another Cavalier, who was alo a Servant of hers, named Don Vincent Poiadas; whereupon eeing my Rival preferred before me, I was exaperated beyond meaure. Don Vincent was a peron of uch an humour, as that nothing would atisfie him, les than to rid out of the way whatever might obtruct his amorous pretenions. Accordingly, one night, meeting with me in the treet where my Mitres liv'd, attended by three ervants, he et upon me, though I had but one with me. I defended my elf as well as I could, but at lat came off with uch wound; as it was conceiv'd I mut have di'd of them. There could never be any perfect dicovery made of him who had hurt me, though every one upected who it might be: but the common report coming in to the Magitrate that Don Vincent was my Corrival, he was imprion'd; but, having clear'd himelf either by favour or mony, he was et at liberty. Being recover'd of my wounds, and reflecting on the advantage, wherewith my Rival had engag'd me, I thought it but a jut requital to fall on him, upon the ame unequal terms. I therefore urpriz'd him in the ame manner as he had done me, and the reult was, that he got off much more wounded than I had been. There happen'd to be ome in the treet, who knew me, and took their oaths againt me, a thing not much practis'd at Valentia, in regard the truth is eldom dicover'd by that means. Upon this accident it is, that I came thence, for Don Vincent was o dangerouly wounded, that the Chirurgeons gave but little hopes of his recovery. I aw his Friends were reolv'd to revenge his
death, and was afraid to fall into the hands of Jutice. This oblig'd me to leave Valentia, and to come to this City, where I have now been about a month. I have undertood by a peron of this City, who hath correpondents in everal others, that he whom I had hurt is out of all danger, nay in perfect health, and that the treaty of marriage between him and Donna Blanca is concluded, whereof I have a greater reentment, then of having this day met with two men, who hir'd by Don Vincent came hither purpoely to murther me. They et upon me in this treet, one I have mortally wounded, as I think, and by that means made a hift to ecape out of their hands, with the aitance of thoe who came in to part us. I found your houe open, and being come into it for refuge, I find my elf ecure, and that all I have to fear now, is, your fair eyes. Avoiding one prion, I am fallen into another; but I think my imprionment o pleaant, that, if you dicharge me not, I hall continue it as long as I live.

div.p:
Thus did the counterfeit Don Jaimo conclude his relation, leaving Rufina extremely atisfi'd, to ee in that Cavalier, not onely thoe endowments which might deerve love, but alo uch initiations of affection, as rais'd in her a certain hope he might one day be his wife: which having dicours'd within her elf, he immediately made him this Anwer. Signor Don Jaimo Pertua, I am very much troubled, that you hould come to the knowledge of me at Toledo, upon o ad an occaion to your elf; but it abates much of it, that you intend not to return o oon into your Country, for I could wih
your reidence in this City, and aure you, for my own particular, that if I could oblige your tay, I would endeavour it by all means poible, nay though it were fatal to my liberty. The advantages you would make of it might not haply amount to much, yet can you no les than think your el • oblig'd to me, for the good will I bear you, conidering the little time I have had the honour to know you. Such as it is, if it oblige you to any reciprocation, I hall think my elf but too too happy, and that I have attain'd the greatet of my wihes. In order to uch a deign, Heaven hath not haply made me handome enough; but I dare tand on my good nature, and withal that I have otherwie wherewith to atisfie a peron of your worth and quality. Madam, replies Don Jaimo, I kis the very dut you tread on, though I think not my elf worthy enough it hould be touch'd by my mouth, when I conider the favour I receive from you. Yet can I not but think I have fully atisfi'd whatever I ought you, ince I have reign'd up to you my heart and oul, and o I fear not any Action you may have againt me, as to that particular. As to your forcing of my will, you may pare your further trouble, I am already enible, Madam, that it is at your devotion, and therefore you may forbear ineffectual remedies, where there needs onely that Sovereign one of your Beauty, which is o full of vertue, that it hath tranported me out of my elf, that I might be abolutely at your dipoal. 'Twas a happy day to me, that I was et upon by thoe Aains of my Country, ince the michief they intended me hath procur'd me the favours I have receiv'd
from you. Now I wih Heaven would prolong my Life; for if you approve of the affection I have for you, as you are pleas'd to aure me, in pight of all the torms of my ill fortune, I hall get into a haven where I may defie all dangers, I mean that of your good inclinations towards me. The thought of them gives me repit, and fills me with an abolute oblivion of my Country, ince I mut look on a place, where uch happines is prepar'd for me, as my Paradice.

Thee dicoures, and others yet more amorous, pas'd between Don Jaimo and Donna Emerentiana; and the crafty Youth had the length of her Foot o rightly, that he was eaily ennar'd in the ubtle Webb of his cunning ininuations, and made it her main buines to ingratiate her elf more and more with him. The time inenibly pas'd away in thee amorous conferences, inomuch that it was two in the morning ere Rufina retir'd to her own Chamber, yet troubled, that he was forc'd to do it o oon; and the Impotor Jaimo preently went to Bed, extreamly pleas'd, that his Camerade's plot had taken o well. Cripin was extreamly perplex'd, that all that Day and the next, he had receiv'd no news of what pas'd, by reaon of Garay's being in the Houe: but as oon as he was gone, for Madrid, the amorous Rufina gave her elf more liberty, being till more and more deeply in Love with her Guet. Jaimo acquainted Cripin, by a Letter brought him by the Slave, how he was favour'd by Rufina. Cripin anwer'd him by the ame hand, and withall ent him a Pure with a hundred pieces,
to get her in to Play, and to make preents to the Servants, that he might be ure of them when occaion erv'd.

The day of Garay's departure for Madrid, Rufina was taken up with the reception of two Gentlewomen of her Neighbour-hood, an employment he was not at all pleas'd with, for he wih'd them far enough, and her elf in her Gallant's company. As oon as they were gone, he went to her beloved Jaimo, whom we hall Don—as long as this Scene of the impoture lats. She found him tuning a Lute, which her Slave had brought him; for he was an excellent Muician, and had a mack of Poetry, an accomplihment not extraordinary in the Natives of Valentia, where there are alo admirable Muicians. Rufina, hearing him at a ditance, came oftly into his Chamber, charm'd with the weet harmony of his Lute, which he touch'd with a miraculous dexterity, and being not een by the young Man, he hearkned to him a good while, perceiving he intended to ing a Song, as he afterwards did with an admirable grace, and he had made the Veres, which were upon the occaion of his Love. This added to the flames of her affection, which were before grown too violent for to keep within the bounds of modety: but what mot ravih'd her, was, that the Veres he had Sung were made for her, and upon the accident which had happened to him. VVhereupon the Love-tung VViddow coming up to him, What, aid he, Signor Don Jaimo, you are Mater of thoe excellencies which I little imagin'd? I am extreamly glad of it, yet wonder not much thereat, as knowing Valentia to be famous for excellent Voices.
Mine is but ordinary, aid he, and it is rather the words, than the goodnes of the Voice that induc'd me to Sing. I find, aid he, this Song is very new, and that it was not made two days ince. 'Tis very true, ays Don Jaimo, yet is it not to be much wondred at, ince the ubject, upon which it is made, hath uch an influence over me, as would make me undertake things impoible, as trancending whatever yet I thought worth my admiration. No flattery, I pray you, aid he to him, for though I know that what you ay is not true, and that you Men allow a ditance between your words and thoughts, and, when you do not love, mot pretend it, yet I cannot but take all kindly from you. You may be deceiv'd in both, Madam, aid he • , and therefore be pleas'd to believe me, that I think my elf extreamly happy in that unhappy adventure, which procur'd me the glory of your acquaintance. All I have to beg of you is, that you take a more particular notice of my freedome, and thence infer, that my Soul cannot be fuller of affection towards you than it is.

In fine, thee and other ininuating dicoures crew'd up the feign'd Widdow to uch a height of kindnes, that the crafty companion began to deit from the enterprize which had occaion'd his coming to her, and eriouly dipoe himelf to aure her more and more of his love. And thinking her fully atisfy'd with the relation he had made her of himelf, he became o familiar, as to deire her to give him the like accompt of her extraction She thought fit to make her condition equal with his, and accordingly,
he acquainted him in a hort dicoure, how he was decended from the illutrious Counts of Menezez in Portugal, though he had been born in the City of Badajos. The crafty companion immediately apprehended what Game he would be at, and that her deign was to oblige him to Marry her. This was directly contrary to the entiments of Cripin, who would not by any means that he hould think of any uch thing, but continually reflect on the dangers they are apt to run into, who following the profeion he was engag'd in, are concern'd to be expeditious in the execution of their enterpries, let being, by ome unexpected accident, prevented, they come to make their lat Wills on a Gibbet, before they are willing to remove into the other World.

The young Gallant grew more and more warm in his love towards Rufina, particularly upon this accompt, that, according to her relation, he was nobly decended. He thereupon did all lay in his power to heighten her affection towards him. She on the other ide, had the ame thoughts, o that concurring in the ame deires, as Lovers mutually paionate, Rufina behav'd her elf o freely and familiarly towards him, that he might eaily perceive he had dicarded all modety: inomuch that, upon little intreaty, he permitted him to invert the order of the Alphabet, and to put Q. before P. But in the midt of her enjoyments, he remembred her old Acquaintance Garay; he reflected on the familiarites had pas'd between them; he conider'd how much he was oblig'd to him; and that he was look'd on all over
the City as her Father. She imagin'd to her elf the reentment he mut needs have at his arrival, when he found that he had baely foraken him. She bethought her elf to give him a um of Money privately, and to dimis him: but thinking more eriouly of it, he thought it a better coure to leave Toledo before his return, and to peruade Don Jaimo to carry her into his Country, Valentia. She reolv'd within two or three days to declare her mind to him, for Garay was not expected home till fifteen days after.

In the mean time Rufina and her Gallant pas'd away the time very jocundly, and he, being very heartily in love with her, was fully reolv'd to give Cripin the bag, and not to proceed any further in his firt deign. 'Twas in the Winter-time, when the Nights are longet, that thee Lovers deceiv'd the low-pac'd Seaon with an intermixture of Carees, Songs, and amorous Dicoures, nay many times, they ung together, their everal parts, to a Muical Intrument, which he play'd on. One night, after they had Sung and Talk'd of everal things, Rufina entreated her Gallant to entertain her and her Maids with ome pleaant Story, or Novel, if he knew any. The young Man, who was Vers'd in all things, and of an excellent Wit, was content to anwer the deires of his Mitres, to give her a new demontration of his further perfections, and aid to her Though to uch a Peron as you are, divine Emerentiana and my dearet Mitres, my dicoure will eem very ordinary, yet o punctually would I obey your Commands, as if I knew what you impos'd
on me were onely for a trial of my compliance: And in regard I do it, in this, o much of a udden, I hope to find you the more ready to excue my failings. The Novel I intend to tell you, I heard from an accomplih'd Cavalier of Valentia; I thought it not unpleaant, and hall endeavour to preent it to you as well dres'd as I receiv'd it. Whereupon having recollected himelf a little, he began his dicoure thus.

div.head: THE THIRD NOVEL.
The Trapanner Trapann'd.
div.p:
IN the great and famous City of Sevil, the Metropolis of Andaluia, Mother of o many noble Families, and excellent Wits, the Treaury of all the Wealth, which flows into Spain from the West-Indies, was born Don Pedro de Ribera, a very accomplih'd Cavalier, of the illutrious Family of the Dukes of Alcala, o highly
eteem'd all over the Kingdome. By their death, from whom he deriv'd his being in this world, there fell to him an etate of four thouand Crowns annual rent, upon which he liv'd very nobly at Sevil, being the mot remarkable Peron at all publick actions done about the City. He had at Madrid a Couin-german, who follow'd the Spanih Court, and was gone thither about ome affairs of great importance, which he had brought to a happy iue. Having liv'd there a while, he lik'd it, and the converation of the Cavaliers inhabiting it, o well, that he exchang'd the place of his birth for that illutrious City. He there became intimately acquainted with an old Cavalier, whoe name was Don Juan de la Cerda, a peron who had rais'd himelf into a general eteem, by the excellent endowments he had. Beides which he was honour'd with the illutrious Order of the Patron of Spain, with a Commandery of two thouand Ducats of annual rent. This old Gentleman was a Widdower, having but one onely Daughter, to whom all his vat Etate was to fall at his Death. Nature it eems had made it her particular buines to enrich this young Lady, with all the graces and perfections to be wih'd in one of her Sex. Which occaion'd the envy of all the Ladies about the Court towards her, ince he had, in point of Beauty, the ame advantages over them, as the Sun hath over all the ret of the Planets. Her Father, Don Juan, wih'd her married with a peron to his mind, that is, one equal to her, in etate and extraction. Don Rodrigo de Ribera (o was called Don Pedro's Couin whom I poke of firt) might have apir'd to the honour of making his Addrees to her, as well upon
accompt of the Houe, from which he was decended, as the familiar acquaintance there was between him and her Father, Don Juan. But being a younger Brother, he thought himelf too low, in point of etate, to pretend to o advantageous a match. However he thought fit to make ome propoal to the old Gentleman, on the behalf of his Couin Don Pedro, who liv'd at Sevil, whom he highly recommended to him for his excellent Qualities, and the greatnes of his Etate; for he was the onely Son of a Noble houe. Don Juan took it very kindly from him, but thought it withall prudence, to make further enquiry into the buines, knowing that perons peaking for their own Relations are commonly very partial, and think it no mortal in to exceed the truth. So that Don Juan, immediately writ to a particular friend at Sevil, earnetly deiring him to give him an account of the Peron and Etate of Don Pedro de Ribera, inamuch as it highly concern'd the honour of his Houe, to meet with a Cavalier worthy his alliance, to be Husband to his onely Daughter Donna Brianda.

'Twas not long ere he receiv'd an Anwer, wherein his friend confirm'd all that Don Rodrigo had aid of his Kinman, with omewhat more, proteting in the concluion, that he was o far from being partial or inincere, in the accompt he had ent him, that he rather told les than truth. He thereupon went to Don Rodrigo, and told him, that he might write to his Couin, and aure him he hould be very welcome, if he had any inclinations for his Daughter. He made him Anwer, that he would, and Don Juan, as a further obligation, would have his Daughter's Picture
ent him, that he might therein find ome of the rare qualities that were in her, permitting his Couin to be preent at the taking of it, that he might aure Don Pedro, the Painter had not flatter'd her, and that the Copy was below the Original.

Don Rodrigo fail'd not to write to his Couin, to whom he alo ent the Picture, celebrating the vertues of that amiable peron, which the Painter could not repreent, as he had done the lineaments of her beautiful countenance. His Couin Don Pedro was extremely atisfi'd therewith, and referr'd it to him to make ome overtures in the treaty of Marriage, till he came thither himelf, for the further proecution whereof, he ent him a full procuration.

In the mean time Don Pedro was preparing for his journey to Madrid, to wait on his Mitres, who, having receiv'd his Picture, was as much taken with it, as he had been with hers. Leaving his retinue at Sevil, till a rich Livery, then making, were finih'd, he began his journey, having onely one peron to wait on him, and a Groom to look to their Mules, who follow'd them at a little ditance. Don Pedro carri'd always about him his Mitres's picture inclos'd in the ame Letter, wherein his Couin had ent it him. Being come within half a days journey of Toledo, he ent away the Groom, to provide Lodgings for them in the City. He had entertain'd at dinner ome of the Inhabitants of Orgaz, which was the place where they had baited. The cloth being taken away, they fell to Cards; he lot his mony, and was vex'd, which occaion'd their playing on till he had recover'd his loes, and by that time it was grown later than he could have wih'd. Being hors'd, he and his man put
forward, but ere they had rode a League, night urpriz'd them, o that they made a hift to loe their way, and got in among certain Olive-trees, about half a League hort of Toledo. Not knowing where they were, and fearing to go too far out of their way, they thought it their bet coure to alight, and ret themelves under one of the Olive-trees, till it were day. They accommodated themelves the bet they could, and wearines oon laid them aleep, yet little dream'd of the misfortune which was to happen to them. Being in their firt leep, which is commonly the oundet, four men came to the place, very oftly, for the noie of their Mules brought them thither; and thee were of a profeion, which for the mot part finds thoe that are of it more work by night than by day. They had then been upon a deign which had not taken, and o they were returning omewhat diconolately with empty pockets to Toledo.

Coming up to them, and finding them both aleep, they ty'd their hands behind them, and took away all they had, but their Doublets and Drawers, and, to get off with more peed and afety, they made ue of their Mules. Don Pedro, being thus baely urpriz'd, was exaperated at the misfortune, but his Man told him that it had happened to them through his fault, becaue he had not given over playing ooner. They dicours'd of it, till the Birds gave them notice of the approach of Aurora. Soon after, hearing the noie of ome cattle not far from them, they call'd to him that look'd after them, who came up to them, and unbound them, very much bemoaning the condition they were in. They ask'd him, how far it was to Toledo, and he told them it was not quite half a
league, but if they would go along with him to a Country Houe hard by, he would gladly hew the • the way, and that he doubted not the Lady, w •• liv'd in it, would relieve them in that extremity. They took his advice, and he brought them to a very fai • houe. Having knock'd at the Gate, it was immediately open'd by an old man, who was Steward to the Lady, and had the overight of the Shepherds and the profits ariing from the Sheep. The Shepherd who brought them thither went in to the Lady, and in few words gave her an account of the misfortune had hapned to thoe Strangers, and the condition he had found them in, whereupon he order'd them to be brought up to her chamber. Don Pedro preented himelf to her, very much abah'd to ee himelf almot naked, as having about him onely an old Coat, which the Shepherd had lent him. He told her that his journey was for Madrid, about a Law-uit of great importance, not dicovering who he was, but onely that he was a Gentleman of Sevil, named, Don Ferdinand Sanchez de Trivegno. The Lady, whoe name was Donna Victoria, was much troubled to ee him in that deplorable condition. There were in the houe two chets full of cloaths, which had been a Brother's of hers, who died not long before. She order'd two utes to be brought out, which they put on, that which Don Pedro had proving o fit, that the Lady was much taken with his peron, and had her eyes always fatned on him. She invited Don Pedro to dine with her, which he did, taking occaion ever and anon, to make extraordinary acknowledgments of the favours he receiv'd from her.

They continu'd two days in that Country houe,
ere the Lady made any dicovery of the affection he had for Don Pedro, ave onely what he did with her eyes, which were the ilent interpreters of the trouble he was in. Don Pedro was not inenible of it, and had ome dicoure concerning it with his Man; yet had he not the confidence to tell him what he really thought of it, being (as he was) upon the point of dipoing himelf otherwie. The Servant advis'd him not to let lip o fair an opportunity, and told him he hould not be o hard-hearted, towards a Lady of o great worth, and one that had o highly oblig'd them. The olitude of the place, the beauty of the Lady, and the ilent dicoveries he made him by her getures, oblig'd Don Pedro to anwer her affection. He entred into ome Lovedicoures with her; but though he were really in love with him, yet would he not grant him any particular favour, unles he firt aur'd her he hould be his wife, and that he had a promie of it under his hand.

Don Pedro, on the other ide, had o great a kindnes for her, that he had in a manner forgot the Mitres, whoe Picture he carri'd about him, and adviing with his Servant, (who was a dangerous Confident, and a ubtil fellow) what he hould do, he told him very roundly, that he ought not to let lip o weet and favourable an opportunity; that he might eaily have the enjoyment of her, and withal give her the promie of marriage he deired, provided he put not into it his own name, but fill'd it with the uppoititious name he had aum'd, ince he knew neither his Country nor extraction. Don Pedro follow'd his advice, and thereupon had his deires of Donna Victoria,
who having made the blot, could do no le • than give him leave to enter. He continu'd there four days, at the end whereof, acquainting the Lady that his buines at Madrid was of uch importance as requir'd his peronal attendance there, he conented to his departure, on condition he would return again as oon as he could; which he, with oaths, promis'd to do.

The next morning betimes, he departed, leaving the Lady o're-flown with tears; he was omewhat troubled, or at leat pretended it. The Lady having furnih'd him with all things neceary, he put forward; but ere he had gone far, he receiv'd ome part of the chatiement which he deerv'd for his perfidiounes, for the Mule he was mounted on being apt to tart gave him a fall, whereby he o prain'd one foot, that he was forc'd to make ome tay at Illecas, a place half way between Toledo and Madrid, and to end for Chirurgeons to et all things right again.

Leaving him there confin'd to his chamber for ome days, let us return to Donna Victoria, who very much bewail'd the abence of her Gallant, the very thought of whom caus'd her no mall affliction. A Servant of hers who had made the bed where he lay, ound, under the bolter, a Picture of the Lady whom Don Pedro was to be married to, folded up in a Letter which his Couin had writ to him from Madrid, which he deliver'd to her Mitres, who opening the Paper, aw the Picture, whereat he was much diquieted; but he was much more atonih'd, when he cat her eye on the enuing

body.head: LETTER.
body.p: YOu will receive herein incloed the Picture of the Lady Donna Brianda de la Cerda, which is very exactly taken from the Original; I doubt not but the charms of her Beauty will oblige you to haten your departure. Her Father, Don Juan de la Cerda, expects you with great impatience. In the mean time the Contract of Marriage is a drawing up, and will be ready, before you be here to ign it. Aure your elf you will be extremely atisfi'd, that you have found o excellent a wife. I am

closer.signed: Your affectionate Couin, Don Rodrigo de Ribera.

div.p:
Donna Victoria had carcely come to the period of this Letter, but, through the trouble he receiv'd at the reading of it, he fell into a wound, and continu'd therein above half an hour, in the arms of her Maid. At lat he came to her elf, burting into ighs and tears; he rail'd at the Sevillian Impotor, but much more at her own implicity, that he had o lightly protituted her honour to an unknown peron, whom o trange an adventure had brought to her houe. She pent that whole day in weeping and bemoaning her misfortune: but conidering withal, what hazard her reputation was in, he reolv'd it
hould not be aid of her, that he had been o baely affronted by any man. Whereupon with the light he receiv'd from the Letter, of the occaion of his journey, and the peron to whom he was to be married, he put things in order to her removal to Madrid; which he might better do than any other, in regard he had not any Kinman near enough to whom he might communicate her intention. She communicated her deign to Albert, an old Servant of hers, who had brought her up from the cradle, and was very glad to wait on her.

Upon this reolution, he caus'd two Wagons to be loaden with all things neceary to furnih a houe fit to receive a peron of Quality, and took her way towards Madrid. Being come thither, he commanded her Servant Albert, to enquire whereabouts lived Don Juan de la Cerda, and whether the young Cavalier, whom he intended to make his Son-in-law, were come from Sevil. She undertood by him, that he was not yet come, but that they expected him, which much troubled the Lady, who knew nothing of the accident had happen'd to him near Illecas.

The firt thing this affronted Lady did, was to take a houe for her elf, near that of Don Juan de la Cerda, and order'd Albert to live in it as Mater thereof. That done, he ent him to Don Juan's, to enquire whether he wanted a waiting-Gentlewoman, for he would diguie her elf, that he might not be known by Don Pedro. The buines had the effect he deired, for Donna Brianda was then enquiring for a widow to wait on her, a cutom much practis'd in Spain, where Ladies of quality have everal of them, whom, being Widows, they call Duennas.
When this was propoed by Albert, who went under the name of Father to his Mitres, Donna Brianda not onely receiv'd her into her ervice, but her Father, Albert, was alo entertain'd into Don Juan's. Albert gave his Mitres an account of his Negotiation, whereat he was extremely atisfi'd: o that having put her elf into the habit of a Duenna, he went the next day to preent her elf to Donna Brianda, conducted by her pretended Father, Albert. They were both very kindly entertained by Don Juan de la Cerda and his Daughter. Donna Victoria wih'd he had not been o handom, that the Sutor he expected might be the les taken with her; however, he couragiouly reolv'd to proecute the impoture he was ingag'd in. Donna Brianda ask'd Albert, what Country-man he was. He told her that he was born at a place called Utrera, near Sevil; that his name was Stephen de Santillana (by which we hall henceforth call him) that his Daughter had been married to a Merchant of that City, who di'd as he was going for the Wet-Indies, leaving o great Debts behind him, that all his Etate went to atisfie his Creditors. Don Juan hearing that Santillana was of Andaluia, ask'd him, whether he had liv'd any time at Sevil. He told him, that he had often been in that City, but that his Daughter had liv'd there. Don Juan would not at that time enquire any farther, nor enter into any dicoure with him concerning Don Pedro de Ribera. Donna Victoria was entertain'd as Duenna to Donna Brianda, who took uch an affection to her, that he truted her with all her Keys, to the great dicontent of her other Servants, who had liv'd with her many years. Santillana told them
that he had a Houe of his own, not far from Don Juan's, and a Wife (for Marcella an ancient Maid of Donna Victoria's was to act that part) whereupon he had no Lodgings aign'd him in Don Juan's.

It is now time we return to Don Pedro de Ribera, who being recover'd of his fall, came to Madrid, and lighted at the Houe of his Couin Don Rodrigo, who was much troubled that he had not been there ooner. He told him the caue of it, and gave him a particular account of all had pas'd in Donna Victoria's Country-houe, even to the promie he had made her, under a feign'd name. Don Rodrigo ask'd him, what quality the Lady was of, whereto be anwer'd, that her name was Donna Victoria de Sylva, and that he was of one of the mot noble Families of Toledo. Don Rodrigo was very much diatisfy'd with his procedure, reproaching him with the unworthy action he had done, in abuing and dihonouring that Lady, and that it was to be fear'd, he might hear of his coming to Madrid in order to a Marriage with another, and find means to be reveng'd for that affront.

They afterwards fell into dicoure concerning Donna Brianda, and Don Pedro told him, he extreamly fancied the Picture he had een of her, but that, with the other things he had been robb'd of, he had lot it: though he knew well enough, he had left it under the beds head at Donna Victoria's, which troubled him not a little, however he diembled it. Don Rodrigo told Don Pedro, that it were fit he put himelf into other Cloaths, before he waited on his Mitres, and that he mut keep within doors till they
were ready. Within two days a very fair riding Suit was brought him, wherein pretending he was but newly come to Town, he goes to the Houe of Don Juan de la Cerda, by whom he was receiv'd with great demontrations of kindnes. Notice was immediately carry'd up to Donna Brianda, that the peron deign'd to be her Husband was coming up to her Chamber, where he was with her Maids about her, who had jut made an end of Dreing her. Don Pedro coming in, conducted by Don Juan and Don Rodrigo, was infinitely atisfy'd at the ight of his Mitres, whom he very civilly and dicreetly aluted, for he was a peron of an excellent wit and a confident carriage and demeanour. He found by the original of Donna Brianda, that the Painter had done his work very faithfully, a virtue not much practis'd by Painters, epecially upon uch occaions as that was. He was ravih'd, to ee o great a Beauty, and he on the other ide was well atisfy'd with the handome peronage of Don Pedro.

There were yet ome things to be done in order to the abolute concluion of the Marriage, at which there was a neceity of Don Pedro's preence; whereupon he, Don Juan, and Don Rodrigo withdrew into another room, where they lock'd themelves in with a Notary, and ome Friends, who were to be witnees at the Articles of the agreement. Donna Brianda continu'd all that time in her Chamber, with her Servants, talking of Don Pedro, her Husband-to-be, every one congratulating her good fortune, ave onely Donna Victoria, who aying nothing at all, her Mitres oberv'd it, and being all alone with her, Donna Theodorn, aid he to her,
(that was the name he had aum'd) whence comes it, that, while all the ret celebrate the happines of my choice, you onely are ilent? Me-thinks you might have contributed omewhat to the publick congratulation, though you had done it onely out of complaiance. I pray give me ome reaon for it. Donna Victoria had done it purpoely, in proecution of her deign, and this quetion came as eaonably as he could have wih'd it, o that he made her this Anwer. As to the peron of Don Pedro, Madam, there is not any thing to be aid againt it, nay he is o accomplih'd, that there is not any thing to be wih'd in him which he hath not already. My ilence proceeds hence, that I had a particular knowledge of him at Sevil, for I liv'd in a Quarter of the City, which he much frequented. I neither will, nor ought to conceal from you the occaion of his o often coming thither, for it is my duty to be faithful to you, as having no other deign than to erve you, and endeavour your quiet, o as that you may not live in a perpetual di-enjoyment of your elf all the ret of your days. Know then, Madam, that if you match your elf with Don Pedro, you will be brought to a kind of civil death, intead of receiving the atisfactions of wedlock. Donna Brianda was much atonih'd at this dicoure, and pres'd her Duenna, to dicover to her more clearly, what he had but too great a deire to tell her. Whereupon entreating her to retire into a more ecret place, where they might not be oberv'd by her other Women, Donna Victoria gave her this malicious account of the perfidious Don Pedro.

p.q:
I hould not live with the repect and duty I owe you as my Mitres, nor according to the affection I bear you, if I expres'd not my elf clearly to you, in a buines wherein you are o highly concern'd, and on which depends your greatet felicity in this world. Know then, Madam, that Don Pedro fell in love with a Lady at Sevil, one very handome and well decended, in a word wanting nothing but a fortune uitable to her quality. He courted her o earnetly, that he, finding her elf oblig'd by o great demontrations of Affection, Letters, and continual Embaies, attended with preents, from Don Pedro, atisfy'd his deires, upon a promie that he would make her his Wife, whereof there are many witnees. But the buines was to be kept ecret for a time; for Don Pedro's Father was then alive, who, having receiv'd ome intelligence of that Love, endeavour'd all he could to prevent Don Pedro's marriage with Donna Elvira de Monalvo; o was the Lady called. The continuance of his viits to her produc'd living proofs, which were two Sons and a Daughter, who are at this time with the Mother. When Don Pedro's Father was remov'd out of the way, (which happen'd not long after) Donna Elvira expected he hould make good his promie, and marry her, but he, for ome time, came not o much as to ee her. What inconveniences he was put to from the time of their acquaintance he knows to her orrow, and I am not ignorant thereof, for I Liv'd near her, and went often to her Houe. Being now convinc'd that he intended to leave her in the Lerch, he dicover'd the buines
to two Couin-Germans of hers, who were o enrag'd thereat, that they immediately reolv'd to oblige Don Pedro, by force, to perform the promie he had made to their Kinwoman. Don Pedro went to a certain Farm he had, not far from Sevil, to avoid his Adveraries, who, knowing he went out of the way purpoely becaue he would not atisfie their Couin, reolv'd to be the death of him. Things were in this poture when my Father brought me to Madrid, where I have been about thee ix weeks. This is the accompt I can give you of Don Pedro, who mut not think himelf ecure in this Court, for the Lady's Kinmen, whom I know to be gallant and tout Perons, as oon as they hear of his being here, will be ure to attend his motion, and revenge the affront done to their Couin; nay it will be eaier for them to do it here than at Sevil.

div.p: Donna Brianda heard very attentively the tory told her by the Duenna, and was extreamly troubled, to find Don Pedro o far engag'd with another. She ask'd her a thouand quetions, among others, whether he was much in love with that Mitres, whether that Donna Elvira was very handome, &c. whereto he made uch Anwers as were uitable to her deign, which was to put Don Pedro clearly out of her favour. Donna Brianda reolv'd to give her Father an account of all, and leave it to him to inform himelf more fully of the buines. She immediately went to the Room where he was to peak to him, for all things were concluded as to the Marriage.

In the mean time, Donna Victoria was left in the
outer-room, where the Women and Duennas are wont to wait. There came in to them a Servant of Don Pedro's whom he had ent to the Pot for Letters from Sevil. Enquiring for his Mater, to give him the pacquet, Donna Victoria told him, that he was within, but that as oon as he came out he would deliver it to him. Having opened the pacquet, he put into it a Letter he immediately writ, and, ealing it up again, came where her Mitres was. She ask'd her whither he was going with thoe Letters?
