The other anwered without the leat dicovery of any malice, that they were directed to Signor Don Pedro, and had been brought thither a little before by one of his Servants from the Sevil-Pot. Curioity was an ingredient of the firt Woman, and it is very fruitfully pread through the whole Sex. Donna Brianda hew'd her elf nor free from it on this occaion, and he was the more excuable conidering the tory had been told her by the ubtle Duenna. She was tempted to open the pacquet, wherein finding one Letter written with a Woman's hand (which was that written by Donna Victoria) he could do no les than open it, and directing her Eye down to the bottom of it, found it ubcribed by one Donna Elvira de Monalvo. She read it, and was confirm'd in what before he not fully credited.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p:
YOur abence and my indipoition have reduc'd me to uch extremity, that I cannot imagine I have any long time to live, it being impoible I hould hold out, after the news I have heard of your reolution to be married at Madrid, which cannot eaily be done, without a trancendent baenes, by a peron o nearly engag'd to me as you are. You know that you cannot bestow on another what is o lawfully due to me, epecially if you make the least reflection on the precious pledges there are between us thereof. I have no other advice to give you, as things now tand, but that, if you are at uch a los of all hame and concience, there is a God in Heaven, who ees our most ecret thoughts, and paes a jut judgement on them; and that I have many noble friends, who meauring the mall account you make of them by your lighting of me, will not fail to revenge the affront done to us all. I hope we hall not be forc'd to thoe extremities, conidering how highly you are oblig'd to do things uitably to the noblenes of your Birth, and to acknowledge, as you ought,
her, whom, while we both Live, you must look on, as

closer.signed: Your lawful Wife Donna Elvira de Monalvo.

div.p: This Letter fully atisfy'd Donna Brianda that all he had heard from the malicious Duenna was true. Her Father coming into the room as he had done reading it, he acquainted him with all that concern'd Don Pedro, hewing him the Letter from Donna Elvira. He was extreamly atonih'd, to find that a Cavalier of o noble a Family, had abus'd a Lady of uch quality, and that, having Children by her, he hould be o impudent as to make his addrees to his Daughter. He forbore reproaching him therewith, till he had better inform'd himelf from a Friend of his of Sevil, then at Madrid, whom he immediately went to look for.

Don Juan was but hardly got out of doors, but Don Pedro and his Man came in, for his man having told him that he had deliver'd the pacquet to one of Donna Brianda's Women, he was come to receive it from her, ince it was not brought to his Couin's, whither all his Letters were directed. It was his fortune to meet with Donna Brianda in the outer-room, where her Father had left her. I hould not have return'd o oon, my dearet Lady, aid he to her, had not omewhat extraordinary oblig'd me thereto; it is to receive ome Letters, which my Man tells me he delivered to one of your Women.
She thought, ays Donna Brianda, that you had been till with my Father. I caually meeting her as he was coming into the room, ask'd her what he came for. She anwering, it was to deliver you the pacquet, I took it from her, and (preuming that a Cavalier of your age and complexion could not have lived to this time in Sevil, and not have an inclination for ome Lady) a certain conjunction of curioity and jealouie peruaded me to open it. That curioity hath done me a courteie, and hath atisfy'd me in ome things, which before I onely upected: and therefore I forbear deiring your excue, ince I have receiv'd o good an information, before I was any further engag'd with you; for had it come too late, I had been ruin'd. Here's a Letter from a peron you hould be well acquainted with; this would have been enough to undeceive me, but it onely confirms a relation I had receiv'd before, upon which I was almot reolv'd to put uch a check to your pretenions to me, as that you hould have but little encouragement to continue them. Farewell, my preence will but trouble you, this Letter will acquaint you with what you are not ignorant of.

Don Pedro receiving the Letter out of her hand was not a little urpris'd, not imagining what might have happen'd to him. He read it, and preently inferr'd, that it was a trick put upon him by ome envious peron, who was deirous to obtruct his happines. Meeting with Donna Victoria (whom, as we aid before, he knew not in her Widdow's habit) Ah Madam, aid he to her, what forgeries are thee? I a Mitres at Sevil, and of this name?
I children by her, and that upon a promie of marriage? If it be not the greatet lye that ever humane malice invented, let me never look Man in the face again. For my part, replies the ubtle Duenna, I find my elf inclin'd to believe, that what you ay may be true; but your main concernment is to bring my Lady to that peruaion. I know her to be of uch an humour as not eaily to quit a reentment, which he entertains upon jut grounds, and I much quetion whether he will admit your addrees any further, for I know he hath acquainted her Father withall, and he is gone to a Gentleman of Sevil, an intimate friend of his, who is now in this City. I am very glad of it, ays Don Pedro, for he will find it to be an abolute impoture, and that there is not any Lady in Sevil that goes under the name of Donna Elvira de Monalvo. But I beeech you tell me, Madam, whether your intimacy be very great with the Lady Donna Brianda.
So great repli'd he, that I am the onely peron in her favour, and to whom he is pleas'd to communicate her thoughts. If it be o, ays Don Pedro, it's poible you may procure me the favour from her, that I may vindicate my elf. I much quetion whether he will ever peak to you again, aid he, for he is extreamly incens'd againt you, and when once angry, if jutly, he is the hardet to be appeas'd that ever I knew. But, aid he, if you are o much in her favour, you may prevail omewhat with her, by repreenting to her the extraordinary affection I bear her. It is in my power, aid he, to do with her what you deire; but what will you give me if I can procure you a
favourable audience from her? Any thing you can deire, aid he to her, if you mind onely matter of advantage. You ee I am very young, ays he, and conequently may hope to be married again, mony is the onely thing I want; if I do what you wih, may I rely on your liberality for my reward. That you may know how earnetly I deire it, ays he, do what I deire, and I will make your fortune he •
vier by five hundred Crowns than it is. I mot humbly thank you, replies he, but I mut tell you, Sir, that I have been o deluded by the verbal promies ometimes made me by a peron of your quality, that I have reaon to mitrut what-ever is promis'd, if I have it not in writing. You will be pleas'd to excue me, Sir, if my fear to be deceiv'd as I have been force me to thee precautions, and to aure your elf, that thoe atisfi'd, I will endeavour to erve you to the utmot of my power. To give you abolute atisfaction, as to that point, Madam, aid he, help me with pen, ink and paper, and you hall have the ecurity you deire your elf.

Donna Victoria would ee the iue of it, and o brought him what he deired. Don Pedro kept his word with her; nay either out of ignorance of the form of uch obligations, or to make a greater expreion of his earnetnes that he hould ait him, he prov'd o liberal, as to give her a Blank ign'd and eal'd, not mentioning the umme whereto he oblig'd himelf, telling her he had not pecifi'd it, out of a deign to requite her beyond his promies, proportionably to the ervice he hould do him, in the recovery of his Mitres's favour. She aw this happen'd according to her wihes, o that acknowledging the
favour Don Pedro had done her, he promis'd him her utmot endeavours to deerve it, by recovering him into the favour of his Mitres. The amorous Cavalier believ'd her, and took his leave. Albert coming in oon after, Victoria gave him an account of what progres he had made, and putting into his hands the Blank ign'd by Don Pedro, bid him write above his name a formal promie of marriage, dating it about the time of his being at her Country houe near Toledo, with two witnees: which Albert did, imitating as near as he could Don Pedro's hand.

That day, Don Juan fail'd to meet the Gentleman of Sevil, and put off the viit he intended him till the next. In the mean time, Donna Victoria undertood from Donna Brianda, that he was reolv'd to lead Apes in hell, rather than have Don Pedro to her husband. Having already truted her Duenna with ome of her ecrets, he thought he might make an abolute dicovery of her elf to her, and thereupon told her, how that before her Father had treated of a marriage between her and Don Pedro, he had been courted by a peron of Honour, named Don Sancho de Leyba; that he had ome inclination towards him; and that the peruaions of her Father had prevail'd with her to entertain the applications of Don Pedro; but having dicover'd his unworthines, he was reolv'd to re-addres her affection to Don Sancho.

Donna Victoria was almot out of her elf for joy to hear that news, for it put her into a confidence that her deign would take: and the more to promote it, he dipos'd Donna Brianda as much as lay in her power to favour Don Sancho. He mut needs be dipleas'd with me, ays he to her, yet I doubt not
but a Letter from me will re-engage him my humble Servant. The crafty Duenna proffer'd to be the bearer of it, on condition he might do it by Coach. Donna Brianda was very glad to find her Woman o ready to erve her, epecially in a buines which he was o much pleas'd with; and o he commanded a Coach to be made ready, and that he hould go immediately to ee Don Sancho, to whom he writ a Letter. Donna Victoria took Coach, pretending to go to Don Sancho's houe, but he went to her own, and bid the Coach-man return to Donna Brianda, and tell her, that for fear notice might be taken of the Coach, he would go afoot to the place where he had ent her, conducted by Santillana her pretended Father. From that houe, he writ two Letters, one, to Don Juan, deiring him to come to her; the other to Don Sancho, to the ame effect, with directions to find the houe.

While the Letters were carried abroad, he put off her Widows habit, and put on that of a peron of the highet quality, expecting thee two viits with the accutomed ceremonies of Spain. Don Sancho de Leyba was not long a coming, though he knew nothing of the peron who had written to him. There had not pat many complements between him and Donna Victoria, but word was brought her, that Don Juan de la Cerda was alighted out of his Coach, and was coming into the houe. Sir, aid he to Don Sancho, I am oblig'd to peak with the peron who is coming up all alone. Not but that you may hear the dicoure we hall have together; and therefore let me intreat you to tand behind this Curtain, whence you will hear all we ay, for it concerns you more
than you imagine, and will prove to your advantage. Don Sancho compli'd, not knowing what might be the iue of this precaution.

Don Juan came in, and having taken a eat, Donna Victoria (whom he knew not as he was then dres'd) addres'd her elf to him with this dicoure. I doubt not, Sir, but you omewhat wonder, you hould be intreated hither by a Letter, and that from a peron not known to you. To recover you from that confuion, I will give you an account of my elf. I was born in the Imperial City of Toledo, the onely Daughter of the Houe from which I am decended, and Heir thereof. I am of the Family of Sylva, o well known all over Spain, that I need ay nothing of it. As to my quality, I am to tell you farther, that my Father was, in his time, honour'd with the Order of St. James, and my Brother, of that of Alcantara, with the command of a Troop of Hore under his Majety in Flanders. Upon his death, I retir'd to a Country-houe I have near Toledo, where I liv'd privately, contenting my elf with the innocent enjoyments of a Country life, without the leat acquaintance of any thing of Love, till that, one morning a Shepherd of mine brought to my houe, two men, who had been robb'd and tripp'd the night before by certain High-waymen. I took compaion on them, epecially him, who by his demeanor eem'd to be the Mater, and out of two chets of cloaths my Brother had left, I furnih'd them with two utes, wherewith they cover'd their nakednes. They eem'd to be very thankful for o eaonable a favour; but the more coniderable of the two hath treated me very ungratefully,
which is the ordinary tyle of Courtiers, and hath required my charitable offices onely with flatteries and deceit. I was o imple as to be cajoll'd, by the carees he made me, during four days that I kept him at my houe, and he prevail'd o far with me, that I was no longer at my own dipoal. The reiterated oaths and protetations of a peron of that worth, rais'd me into a peruaion that he really lov'd me, and that induc'd me to love him again; to be hort, upon a promie he made me of marriage, he got me in an humour to grant him the greatet of favours. He made me believe that his going to Court was for the proecution of ome Law-buines that concern'd him very highly. He deir'd my leave to go to Madrid, promiing to return again in a hort time, but with uch demontrations of love as might eaily have prevail'd with one who had not fanci'd him o affectionately as I had done. I uppli'd him with all things neceary, and he left me extremely troubled at his departure. Now, by a Picture and Letter he left behind him under the bolter, I found that the occaion of his coming to this Court was in order to a marriage between him, and that miracle of Beauty, Donna Brianda, your Daughter. Now our Honour being the mot coniderable thing we ought to be tender of, I could do no les, upon this procedure of Don Pedro, than reolve to come to this Court, and to apply my elf to my friends, that, by their favour, I might cros the marriage he is about, and you will find, that I may eaily do it, if you but ee what Cards I have to play. I conceiv'd my firt overture hould be to acquaint you with my digrace,
the dihonour I have run into by the acquaintance of Don Pedro, and his treachery towards me, that receiving it from my own mouth, you may not bee too forward to conclude what is already reolv'd between you, as I have undertood. With the Paper I have here in my hand, I will proecute him to the utmot; it is under his own hand and eal, and witnees to it: be pleas'd, Sir, to perue it, and ee whether I have not reaon to proecute this ungrateful and perjur'd man, and to force him to a performance of the promie he hath made me.

Don Juan was atonih'd at this relation of Donna Victoria's, and, by what was put into his hands, found out the dipoition of Don Pedro, and concluded him a fickle imprudent peron, who puru'd his enjoyments, without any thought of the conequences thereof, and thereupon he reolv'd there hould be no further talk of any marriage between him and his Daughter. Opening the Paper which Donna Victoria had given him, he found in it thee words.

body.p:
THis preent writing, written with my own hand, and ealed with my Seal, witneeth, that I, Don Pedro de Ribera, an Inhabitant of Sevil, acknowledge my elf to be the lawful husband of Donna Victoria de Sylva, an Inhabitant of Toledo, and that I will perform the preent promie I make her of marriage whenoever I hall be, by her, thereto requir'd. Signed and Sealed
in the preence of Albert and Marcella, Servants to the aid Donna Victoria.

div.p: Having read this promie, and knowing the h • nd and eal of Don Pedro, Don Juan aid to her, Madam, I am very much troubled, that Don Pedro (a peron o well decended as he is) hould be guilty of o unworthy an action, and a demeanour o full of treachery; for at the time when he gave you this writing, he was coming hither purpoely to be married to my Daughter. But the account you have given me of him is uch, that I aure you, I wil • have no more to do with him, ince you have o much reaon to oppoe it. Proecute your own right, and leave him not till you have obtain'd your deires, and be aar'd, I hall ait you to the utmot of my power, ince I find your honour o highly concern'd in it I have ome friends here, and thoe powerful, I will engage them all to erve you, that you may find I am a peron, who prefers a jut cause before all elf-interet.

Donna Victoria gave him very humble thanks for o great a favour, and the tears that fell from her at the cloe of her dicoure, heightned his zeal and tendernes towards her. Don Juan took along with him the writing which Donna Victoria had hewn him, that he might thereby induce Don Pedro to an acknowledgment of his fault. With thoe protetations he took leave of Donna Victoria, promiing to ee her again within a hort time, and to return the promie of marriage, reiterating the deires he had to erve
her. He thereupon left her, giving Don Sancho the liberty to come upon the tage. As oon as he had taken a eat, You have undertood, ays Donna Victoria to him, if o be you have heard the dicoure between Don Juan and my elf, what hath pas'd between me and Don Pedro. Upon which account (as you have heard from her Father) you find he is never like to be husband to the fair Donna Brianda. She ent me hither to acquaint you, that what hath been done on her part in order to the marriage between her and Don Pedro was purely out of compliance with the commands of her Father, and that he is glad of the occaion he now hath to quit him, and re-aume that kindnes and affection he ever had for you. What I ay, you will find in writing under her hand, when you have perus'd this Letter. Don Sancho, having read it, was the mot atisfi'd man in the world, to find his blated hopes now beginning to pring again.

Donna Victoria perceiving it, to conirm his atisfaction, continu'd her dicoure to him thus. I know, Seignor Don Sancho, you will be atonih'd in your elf, how this Letter hould fall into my hands. It is my elf onely can unriddle it. Being in love, as you are, you know that that little Divinity is the Author of many diguies and transformations, as you are taught by Ovid in his Metamorphois, and conequently you doubt not, but that I, loving an uncontant peron, who had had uch precious pledges of my affection, hould leave nothing unattempted to recover my honour, and oblige him to the atisfaction of what he owes me. I am come to this Court, with a deign, being what I am, to get into the ervice of Donna Brianda, and have effected it.
For though you ee me in this houe, (which was taken upon my account) I live in hers, waiting on her in the quality of a Duenna, a part I have aum'd, the better to elude Don Pedro, and to do all ay in my power to put him out of my Mitres's favour: and I have alo brought that o far about, that I am confident there will never be any marriage between them, and he is wholly inclin'd to favour you. Now conider with your elf what you would have me to ay to your Mitres, for I am jut going to put on my Widows habit, and I mut return preently, and am afraid he will think I have taid too long. If you will return her an Anwer, you have here all things requiite to do it. I think it were fit you hould, that Donna Brianda may ee, I have punctually obey'd her commands. As to the ecret of my diguie, I pray keep it uch, for it concerns me, that it hould not be dicover'd a while. I rely on your dicretion, and, knowing you to be a peron of Honour and worth, I preume you will not dicover it.

This dicoure very much urpriz'd Don Sancho, who took occaion to commend her courage and generoity, and return'd her his mot humble thanks, for the favour he had done him, in entruting him with the ecret of her Love, and prayed Heaven to give him life to acknowledge and require o great an obligation. He promis'd her not to dicover any thing till he commanded him to do it; and thereupon, eeing her in hate to be gone, he writ a Letter in Anwer to what he had receiv'd from his Mitres, full of amorous complements, and pro • etations of fidelity to the lat gap. While he was writing, Donna Victoria but on her Widow's habit, and made all the hate he could to Don Juan's.

In the mean time Don Pedro, extremely reenting the impoture put upon him, acquainted his Couin Don Rodrigo with it, whereupon they went both together to Don Juan's. He not being within, they ask'd for Donna Brianda, who came out without any ceremony to receive their viit, that it might be the horter; for he had no great mind to ee Don Pedro. The poor Gentleman endeavour'd to vindicate himelf, wearing a thouand oaths, that he never heard of any Lady in Sevil, of the name mentioned in the Letter, and that no doubt ome envious peron had put this trick upon him: and that if Don Juan hould upon enquiry find it to be true, he would be content to loe his honour and life, nay more, the hopes of ever enjoying her.

The earnetnes of his dicoure put Donna Brianda into ome doubt, that what he had heard was ome impoture advanc'd purpoely to obtruct his pretenions, and referr'd it to her Father to make a full dicovery thereof. Her Anwer to them was, that he was not at her own dipoal, that it was her duty, to comply with that of her Father, and conequently, he could not quit the ill-impreion he had receiv'd of Don Pedro, till he were better inform'd of the Truth: that her Father would come in ere long, and that he could take no reolution without his orders, in a buines of o great importance.

While they were engag'd in this dicoure, Don Juan comes in from the viit he had made to Donna Victoria. Don Rodrigo made him a hort relation of what had happen'd, and renew'd to him the jut complaint which his Couin had reaon to make of the crime laid to his charge. Whereupon both deiring him to hold his hand, at leat till there were an exact
enquiry made into the buines, he deir'd them to it down, and gave them this Anwer.

p.q: Gentlemen, I went out in hopes to be inform'd by ome friends of Sevil, now here, whether that which is imputed to Don Pedro were true, and I could not meet with them: but if I had found them, it's poible they might know nothing of the buines, for Sevil is a great City, and ome parts of it lye at uch a ditance from others, that they may well be accounted different places. What I found mot certain is, that Don Pedro hath made a promie of Marriage to a Lady of Toledo, who entertain'd him at a Country-houe of hers, after he had been robb'd by certain Thieves; and what is yet more to be conider'd, he thought it not much to ecure his affection by the forfeiture of her Honour. I have it from the Lady her elf, who ent for me, and hew'd me the promie under his hand, which ince we all know, there can be no evaion.

div.p:
He thereupon hew'd it to both the Couins, who were both at uch a los that they knew not what to ay, epecially Don Pedro, who ufficiently betray'd his guilt by his atonihment, but wore withall that he had not made that promie under his own name, but under a feigned. But Don Rodrigo knowing all the circumtances of the buines, was mot liberal of his reproaches to his Couin, which raiing a certain compaion in Don Juan, forc'd this dicoure from him. Signor Don Pedro, We find by many experiences, that a young Man, once fallen in Love, will do any thing to obtain his deires. That Love hould overcome you, I wonder not at all; but what occaions my atonihment, is, that you hould have the confidence to addres your elf to a peron
of the quality this Lady is of, and dihonour her, without ever conidering, that, in time, he might acquaint her friends therewith, who would be ure to revenge the affront. And what adds to this atonihment, is, that you durt do uch an action when you were coming hither purpoely in order to your matching with my Daughter, for whom, if any credit may be given your Letters, you pretended to have a paionate affection. I ee not how your heart could be capable of uch a competition of paions, that you hould pretend the greatet inclinations imaginable for one, and treat of a marriage with another. Being a peron of Honour, I doubt not but you will make it appear in your actions, and that is, that you tand to the promie you made to the Lady Victoria, though it were onely out of this conideration, that it argues a more generous nature to do that willingly, which mut otherwie unwillingly be done. The Lady is not o detitute of Friends as you haply imagine; he is now at Madrid, come exprely to recover her debt, which no doubt he will; and her caue being o jut, 'tis not likely he will want aitance. My advice is, that you endeavour to prevent the ill reports which the buines mut raie of you; perform what you have promis'd, and let not your Love to my Daughter blind you any further, for I am reolv'd to hut her up in a Cloiter, for the remainder of her Life, rather than he hall ever be your Wife.

With that he roe up, and, without any complement, went into another room. Donna Brianda follow'd him, and the two Couins, without o much as a word exchang'd, went home, where Don Rodrigo
fell into bitter expotulations with his Couin, for his engaging himelf in o unworthy an action. Don Pedro had nothing to reply, but that he was atonih'd how that promie came to be ign'd with his own name, having made it onely under a uppoititious.

Leaving them in that confuion, making everal reflections on the adventure, let us return to the feign'd Waiting-woman, who was got back to Don Juan's, and had deliver'd Don Sancho's Letter to Donna Brianda. She was infinitely atisfy'd with it, as fearing he would not have been o eaily retriv'd into her ervice. Donna Brianda acquainted her, how that Don Pedro and his Couin had been there; what had pas'd between them and her Father; and that he had abolutely dimis'd them, it being dicover'd, that Don Pedro had committed another impertinence, and had made a promie of Marriage to a Lady of Toledo, who was come expres to Madrid, to obtruct his pretenions to her. Donna Victoria pretended the greatet atonihment in the world, and burt forth into imprecations againt Don Pedro.

In the mean time there came a meage to Donna Brianda from a She-Couin of hers, inviting her to a Comedy which was to be repreented at her Houe, that night, whereto he ent Anwer, that he would come. Donna Victoria having made o uccesful a progres in her buines, bethought her elf of an invention that hould bring it to an abolute period, for he had the management of all. She told Donna Brianda, that if he pleas'd to wave her going to the Comedy he might have a meeting that night with Don Sancho, in a ecure place, to wit at her Father's houe, where he might do what he pleas'd her elf. The Lady had a great kindnes for Don Sancho, and
was deirous to prevent the reproaches he might make upon her former dicarding of him, and o he accepted the proffer made by her Woman. She immediately ent for Santillana, and gave him a Letter for Don Sancho, whereby he was deir'd to come that night at eight to Donna Victoria's houe. He was ent with another to Don Pedro de Ribera, acquainting him that Donna Brianda, notwithtanding the indignation of her Father, and what he her elf had aid, was reolv'd ecretly to marry him, and deir'd to meet him that night, at a Houe, whither the Bearer would bring him, and that he hould not fail to be there at nine. The two Cavaliers kindly receiv'd their Letters, epecially Don Pedro, who being but a little before dimis'd, was re-call'd to joyn hands with Donna Brianda, and imagin'd it done by the interceion of the Waiting-Gentlewoman, to whom he thought himelf infinitely oblig'd, and the preent he had made her well betow'd. The two Gallants fail'd not to be there at the time appointed, and in the mean time Donna Brianda and her Woman took Coach, leaving Don Juan at home, ready to go to bed. They went to Donna Victoria's houe, which eem'd to be that of Santillana, where they were receiv'd by Marcella, Victoria's maid, who went under the name of her Step-mother. While Donna Brianda was expecting the arrival of Don Sancho, he ent Albert with a Letter to Don Juan, which contained thee words.

body.head: THE LETTER.
body.p: MY Lady Donna Brianda, intead of going to ee the Comedy, whereto he had been invited, is come to my Father's houe, with a reolution to be ecretly married to Don Pedro, notwithstanding your prohibitions to the contrary. I conceiv'd it my duty to give you notice thereof, it is your work to take what coure you think fit to prevent it; for my part I have done what lay in me, and I hall not need to fear any reproach from you, ince I have ent you timely notice of her intention.

div.p:
Santillana was dipatch'd away with this Letter, and order'd not to deliver it till half an hour after nine, which he did. In the mean time Don Sancho fail'd not to come, preciely at his time, and was directed to his Mitres, who gave him uch atisfaction as ilenc'd all his complaints. Victoria left them together in a room, where he lock'd them in. Not long after came Don Pedro, according to the time appointed him, and was receiv'd by Victoria, who dipos'd him into a room, without light, alledging it concern'd him, that he were not een; that he hould forbear making any noie, and that it would not be long ere his Mitres came to him. He promis'd to obey her in all things, and taid there o long
as that Victoria might hift her elf into Cloaths uitable to her quality. That done, he went into the room, and peaking very low, it was no hard matter for her to deceive Don Pedro, and to make him believe he was very much in his Mitres's favour.

Leaving thee young people thus match'd let us return to Don Juan, who receiv'd the Letter from the Duenna jut as he was getting into bed. The old Gentleman was extreamly urpris'd thereat, and going out of doors, attended by Albert, he went to the Commiary's houe, which was hard by. The afflicted Man acquainted him what poture things were in; whereupon the Commiary taking ome of his people about him, they went to Albert's houe, where, after ome knocking, they were let in. They happily had a Lantern with them, and it did them good ervice, for they found the Houe without any light. They lighted a Torch, and went into everal rooms, in one whereof finding Don Sancho and Donna Brianda, the Commiary ask'd them what they did there? Don Sancho told him he was there with his Wife, which was confirm'd by Donna Brianda. Don Juan would have run him through; but the Commiary telling him he was not with the peron he imagin'd, that that Gentleman was Don Sancho de Leyba, a peron of great quality and well known about the Court, Don Juan could do no les than approve of their Marriage, though 'twere onely out of a atisfaction, that he was not fallen into the hands of Don Pedro, whom he hated extreamly, for the trange pranks he had plaid.

They went thence into another room, which they found lock'd, and thereupon threatning to break open the door, Don Pedro open'd it within, and comes out
telling them he was there with Donna Brianda his wife, and that it was with her conent, he was come into that houe to marry her. Upon that dicoure Donna Victoria came out of the room and aid to him, You are deceiv'd, weet Seignor Don Pedro, I a • not the woman you think me, but Donna Victori • de Sylva, who expects from you the reparation o • her honour; the recovery whereof oblig'd me t • enter into the ervice of Donna Brianda, erving he • in the quality of a Waiting-woman. Don Juan de <> Cerda looking on her a little more attentively that he had done, knew her, as alo did the fair Lad •
Donna Brianda. Both of them reflecting on the diguies he had run through to retrive her Honour, very eriouly commended her courage and contrivances, and as much blamed Don Pedro, who finding himelf convinc'd, and condemn'd of all, ratifi •• once more the promie he had made her. Don Sanch •
and his Mitres were enur'd one to the other, an • the olemnity of their marriage ordered to be eigh • days after. They prov'd both very happy in thei • wives, of whom they had many children, who were the comfort and felicity of their Parents. But particularly for Don Pedro, when he reflected on the trange adventures whereby Donna Victoria engag'd him to his duty, he look'd on all as o many extraordinary demontrations of her affection, towards him, which occaion'd his to be multipli'd towards her, beides the kindnes he had for her upon the account of her ingenuity. For wit in a Woman is a great enflamer of Love, epecially that Woman's wit whic • is ever bet at a dead lift.

RUfina and her Maids were extremely pleas'd with this Novel of Don faimo's; that eloquence which was o natural in him, added as o many precious grains to the perfect metall of his other excellent qualities, rendred him of o good weight in her eteem, that he could no longer forbear expreing it in her words and actions. On the other ide, the Gallant, finding her o tractable, reolv'd to deit from the intention he had to rob her, and wih'd for a handome opportunity to acquaint her therewith, which oon happened. For Rufina peruading her elf that Don Jaimo was the ame peron he had decrib'd himelf in his relation, told him, that he had ome intentions, before her Father were return'd from Madrid, to leave the houe he was in, to carry along with her all the bet houhold-tuff, and to go with him into Valentia, ince he was o powerful in thoe parts, and decended from o illutrious a Family, and that her Father would not be dis-atisfi'd with her marriage, when he hould come to hear of it.

The diguis'd Cavalier was forc'd, upon this occaion, to dicover how it had been reolv'd that he hould trapan her, and not deirous he hould continue any longer ignorant of the impoture, My dear heart, aid he to her, having experienc'd the kindnes and affection wherewith you have been pleas'd to honour me, I were the mot ingrateful peron in the world, if I hould keep you in darknes any longer. No, I will make an abolute and full dicovery of my elf to you, and tell you uch things as have hitherto not o much as entred your imagination; and certainly I were not pardonable, if the incere affection I bear you did not omewhat alleviate my crime. I do not ay it conits in my loving
of you, for it is impoible, that thoe who have once a ight of your divine beauty hould not love you: I have een it, and, ubdu'd by your charms, am become a captive thereto, my liberty and all the powers and faculties of my oul being abolutely at your dipoal. 'Tis a Victory, Madam, which you might eaily obtain over hearts much more rebellious againt Love than mine is, which became your lave, upon the firt ight of thoe two Suns; and this is a truth I hall never recant while I live.

p.q:
The meaning of this Preamble is, to induce you to pardon me the offence I have committed againt you. I now ingeniouly acknowledge, that I am not the peron I decrib'd in the account you oblig'd me to give me of my extraction, though it be true I was born in Valentia; but one meanly decended, yet of people of good repute. My Father got his livelihood by the labour of his hands, and the weat of his brows, being by profeion a Rope-maker. Me-thought I had ome apprehenions above my condition; and therefore unwilling to fall to my Father's laborious trade, I went into Cateel, having before been in Andaluia, and I made thoe advantages of my Travel and the converation I met with, and improv'd the natural Talent I had o well, that I never wanted either friends or mony. I came to this City in the company of a man named Cripin, who had been a prioner ome time at Malaga, for ome crime he would by no means acknowledge to me. The peron hath oblig'd me, having born my charges all the way; nay more, he hath lent me mony, out of a confidence of the reality I had to erve him, in the ecret trade we drove together. He declar'd his mind to me one
day, and advis'd me, by ome pretence or other, to get into your houe, for he knew you had good tore of mony, and was deirous to disburthen you of ome part of it. From the dicoure he made, I inferr'd, that he had been a prioner at Malaga for ome robbery. Now to compas our deign, we pretended a quarrel, which hould oblige me to take refuge in your houe: and in the mean time, you have entertain'd me with uch extraordinary kindnes, and have o nobly oblig'd me, that I find the favours you have done me will frutrate Crispin's intention. And therefore now that I acquaint you with the trick we deign'd to put upon you, aure your elf I will endeavour to retort it upon himelf, and get out of him what mony he hath, to chatie him for his folly. For heaven forbid I hould prove ingrateful to a peron who hath oblig'd me o highly as you have done. I have dicover'd my Soul to you, dipoe of me now as you think fit, for I am reolv'd to perih, ere I ever conent you hall receive any injury, though I have diclaim'd the quality, I had unjutly aum'd.

div.p:
Rufina was extremely exaperated againt Cripin, not o much for his deign to be reveng'd on her for the prank he plaid him at Malaga, but upon an apprehenion that he might have acquainted Jaimo what kind of peron he was, and what trade he drove. Whereupon condering that he had o ingenuouly dicover'd himelf to her, and acknowledg'd even to the meannes of his birth, he thought her elf oblig'd to do the like, and to give him a incere account of her decent, coure of life, friends, in a word, all her adventures, to her arrival at Toledo. But Love and Wine make people talk more than they hould.
Jaimo was glad that Rufina was no better decended than himelf: that equality of condition not onely occaion'd a greater kindnes, but begat thoughts of a match, between them. They reolv'd to leave Toledo, and to take up their habitation at Madrid; but Rufina told him, he would firt be reveng'd of Cripin, who intended to erve her uch a bae trick. Jaimo undertook it, telling her, that under pretence of their acquaintance and friendhip, he might eaily bring him into the nooe, and not onely leave him mony-les, but alo find him a good ecure lodging, let he hould attempt to revenge himelf.

With this reolution, leaving Rufina's he went to Cripin, whom he found at his lodging, not expecting to have een him o oon. He was over-joy'd to heat how his Companion had ininuated himelf into Rufina's favour, whereupon the other telling him, that to make ure work of her, he wanted a umme of mony, as well for expence, as to gain rhe Servants, the Apotate Hermite anwered he hould not want it. By this means Jaimo thought to oblige him to a greater confidence of him, heightning the intended cheat with a thouand oaths of an inviolable Friendhip. Thus was that old experienc'd Turn-key of villany brought into a Fool's paradie; for, that Jaimo might live utably to the relation he had made of himelf, he gave him a hundred pieces in gold, to be dipos'd of as he pleas'd, hoping to have them return'd, attended with ix times as many. He took them out of a bag where were five or ix hundred more, ome part of his former atchievments. Jaimo oberv'd the place, where he put up that treaure, and wore to himelf, that he would not leep heartily till be had alter'd the property of that bag. While Cripin was gone out
to give the Hotes order for a brace of Partridges and a Rabet for his, and his Camerade's upper, he went to the port-manteu, wherein the mony was garion'd, and opening the chain (a thing he could do as cleaverly as any of his profeion) took out the bag, and dipos'd it into a place, whence he might eaily remove it at his departure. They upp'd very merrily, which ended, Jaimo tooke leave of Cripin, putting him over head and ears in hope, that he would bring his deign to a period.

He went traight to Rufina's, who it may well be preum'd, receiv'd him very kindly. He gave her an account what had pas'd between him and Cripin, and how he had with his own mony promoted the deign he had to choue him. Being alone with her, he hew'd her the goodly pieces, for he had a great affection to mony of that colour. Jaimo repreented to her, how much it concern'd them to leave Toledo, before Cripin hould take notice of the los of his mony. Rufina told him, that he knew an expedient for that, which was, to erve Cripin such a trick at Toledo, as he had done at Malaga. Having thereupon writ a large Letter to the Magitrate, whoe province it is to perecute uch people, they et things in order for their departure, and met with two Wagons, then going for Madrid, wherein they put their goods, taking onely the She-lave to wait on them. They went to the Court, where, as in a Sea, o many Rivers meet, having reolv'd that Rufina hould not appear, till they had ome news of Garay.

Leaving them there, let us ee what was the effect of the Letter ent to the Provot. As oon as he had read it, he went, according to the directions therein receiv'd, attended by ome of his Officers, to Cripin's
lodging, who, impatiently expecting, that Jaim •
hould make his way into Rufina's houe, and thereby put him into poeion of all her mony, was taken in his chamber, and thence conducted to prion. Not long before, one of the Judges of Malaga, had been at Toledo, to look for him, and not finding him, had left with the Provot ome obervations on his Phyiognomy, by which, though the habit he then was in diguiz'd him very much, it was more then preum'd, that he was the peron. They eiz'd on what he had in the houe, among which he thought the Gold, which Jaimo had eas'd him of, had been, for he knew nothing of its departure, which happen'd well for the two Lovers, who were already dilodg'd. The iue of his imprionment, was, that, being put to the Torture, he could not keep his own counel, and o was entenc'd to receive the reward of his confeions, Hanging. 'Twas Heaven's kindnes towards him, that he hould end his days with ome remore for his ins, for though that be the ordinary exit of uch as engage themelves in that wretched kind of life, yet are there many of them whoe guilty ouls, are, by word and pitol, dipatch'd into the other world, without the leat act of contrition. This was the end of poor Cripin, who made a publick acknowledgment of all the robberies and villanies he had committed, while he was a Hermit, to the great edification of the people. He was alo oberv'd to have this generoity, that he named not any peron who had been engag'd with him in his deigns; nay though he knew, the preent misfortune had been procur'd him by his Friend Jaimo, yet he Chritianly forgave him and all the world at his death.

In the mean time Rufina and Jaimo were married
as oon as they came to Madrid, but kept out of Garay's fight. He went oon after to Alcala, where he had been told his Wife was, but finding her not, he truck in with ome of his own Profeion, and the reult was, that being urpris'd in a Robbery, they were all condemn'd to the lah, and ix years recreation in the Galleys. He was brought to the chain at Toledo, which eas'd his mind a little, for, thinking Rufina had been there till, he writ a Letter to her, deiring her, in regard he had gotten all he was worth by his co-operation and aitance, that he would have compaion on him, and exempt him from that penance, by buying a Slave in his tead, a thing commonly practis'd. The Beater enquires for Rufina, where he had directed, but the Neighbours told him, that he had left Toledo; o that honet Garay, burthen'd with Iron, Years, and Hardhip, came to have that relation to his Catholick Majety, which he and many others, though they jutly deerv'd it, little expected to be preferr'd to.

On the contrary Don Jaimo liv'd like a Prince at Madrid, where he oon met with ome of his own Contitution, a ort of people, who, like Foxes, never fare better than when they are mot curt. They committed ome ecret Robberies, with uch caution and indutry, that the Authors thereof could never be dicover'd, whereby they were o fleh'd and encourag'd, that they daily found out new deigns. There was tarted up about this time at Madrid an excellent Company of Players, brought together by the exceive charge and liberality of a Grandee of Spain, a peron of vat Wealth. What his deign was in it, I know not, whether he did it out of charity, or for his particular divertiement, or upon ome other account
to me unknown; but he made it his buines to ee it furnih'd with all things requiite. He was deirous they might have the advantages of the Feat of the B. Sacrament, at which time, the Players of the City may, during all the days of the Octave, repreent their Plays in the open treets, where all are welcome without paying; and this is done every year at Madrid, at the time of that Feat. To effectuate his deign, he bought them ome new Plays of the bet Poets in Spain, whom he paid well, and put upon ome other pieces, for the accomplihment of that famous Company. So that another Company, which was then at Madrid, being too weak to tand in competition with this, was forc'd to leave the City, and go to Toledo, where they had, from that Imperial City, the ordinary Salary for repreenting the bet pieces they had, at the ame Feat. This new Company had the whole Court to it elf, and the aid Grandee gave them by way of advance four thouand Crowns, to provide Cloaths uitable to the Pieces they intended to repreent. This um of money was brought into the Houe of one of the Players, an ingenious and undertanding peron, for whom the ret had uch repect, that all things pas'd through his hands; he alo took care for all things, and gave a very faithful account thereof. He dipos'd this money into a great Chet, whereof he always carried the Key about him. Jaimo's company oon had an inkling of it, and thinking it a noble prize to hook in that money, they propos'd everal ways to compas it, but at lat referr'd all their deliberations to Jaimo, whoe advice they had, upon other occaions, found the bet. He deir'd time to conider till the next day. That night he pent in communicating the buines to his Wife,
whom he acquainted with the everal propoals of his Camerades. She gave him infallible directions how the buines hould be effected. Jaimo had the reputation of being able to do omewhat in Poetry, upon which they laid the Plot, and it was approv'd by his Companions.

The next day, Jaimo was clad like a Scholar newly come from the Univerity, in a Caock and long Cloak very bare, and potted in many places. Thus accoutred, he melt as trongly of the Poet as if he had fed on nothing but Veres from his Mother's milk. They fitted his Noe with a good large pair of Spectacles, which were faten'd to his Ears with a Lute-tring, a thing very common in Spain, and furnih'd him with a huge broad-brimm'd Hat; in fine he had all things requiite, to act the part of a ridiculous and extravagant Poet, which was the way they conceiv'd mot likely to compas their deign.

He went thus to the Comedians, who were met at their Theatre, and upon the rehearal of a piece, which was to be repreented within three days. He addres'd himelf to the peron who had the overight of the Company, for he had enquir'd out his name, and coming to him with a great many congees, (after he had ask'd him how he did.) I am a Poet, Sir, aid he to him, o you take it not ill. The Comedian, as we told you, was a very apprehenive peron, and often had to do with uch phantams of extravagant Men, uch as Jaimo eem'd to be by that abrupt introduction. Many years may you be o, Sir, repli'd he, aure your elf, it hall not trouble me at all. The deign of my tudies, ays the other, was to become eminent in Divinity, that o I might be capable of a good Benefice, in order
to which I have already taken the degree of Batchelour of Divinity, in the Univerity of Iracha, with the great applaue of all my Country-men; for I am a Bicayan, to erve God, and your illutrious Company. I was born at the Town of Ordugna, and I have the advantage to be alli'd to the mot honourable families of that ancient place. I am known by the name of the Batchelour Dominico Joancho, and my fame is great in my own Country, which I told you is Bicay. There it was (not lighting the Talent, which it hath pleas'd Heaven to give me gratis, by cauing me to be born a Poet) that I addicted my elf to the tudy of Poetry, wherein I have been wonderfully fortunate; and finding that all people admir'd my works, and many were importunate with me to publih them, I would needs make a trial what kind of fancy I might have in the writing of Plays. Thoe I have made are not uch as are now in Vogue, written by ome Novice Poets as I may call them; No, I thank Mercury and the Mues, mine are of a kind of extraordinary tile, and I can furnih you with a dozen at leat ready for the Stage. I am come to this Court, where there are excellent Wits, and I have had the honour to be eteem'd here according to my worth, and I may without vanity affirm it, that the mot humorous Judgements have acknowledg'd that my perfections are more than ordinary. But I think it my greatet happines, Sir, that I flourih in the ame Age with o noble and illutrious a Company, which may be called the Flower of all thoe that ever were in Spain, in whoe ervice I would employ the Talent God hath betow'd on me, if your elf, and the ret of your honourable
Company be o pleas'd. What number of Plays I have promis'd you, all of my own Writing, you need but call for. As to the price, you are o reaonable, that we hall not diagree: Be pleas'd, Sir, to honour me o far, as to make me acquainted with the ret of your Company, that they may give me their ence, as to what I propoe.

This Comedian was of an humour much different from many others of that Quality, who, when a Poet, whom they know not, comes to preent them with a Comedy, light him o far as that they will not o much as give him audience, as if that Divine Power, which hath inpir'd thoe that are in Vogue, had confin'd his gifts to them, and had nothing left to betow on others. But this Comedian, I ay, was of a very jovial and pleaant humour, and was glad of any uch occaion to divert himelf. So that meauring the inide of the peron by his out-ide and dicoure, he told him, that he did them a trancendent honour, and that he gave him thanks in the name of the whole company. Then turning about to his Companions, Gentlemen, aid he to them, be pleas'd to take notice of the renowned Batchelor Dominico Joancho, a Nobleman of Bicay and mot excellent Poet, whoe productions for the Theatre are beyond all admiration, and who proffers to exhaut his precious vein for our's, having already finih'd at leat a dozen pieces, which he hath a deire to hew us. The other Comedians, by the dicoure of their Camerade, and by the ill equipage, and wore looks of the peron, eaily dicover'd, that he and his wits were at a little ditance, which oblig'd them to pretend, that they were extreamly engag'd to him, and o they all gave him, one after another, a very civil alute, which he very unhandomely
return'd. He who had firt poken to him, ask'd him, whether he would have the patience till they had done rehearing, which would not be long, in regard they had gone over it three or four times before, and had now but ome particular Scenes to look over, and then they would ee ome of his Pieces, if he would be pleas'd to communicate them; which he promis'd to do. He took a chair and ate very quietly till the Rehearal was over. By that time they had made an end, it was o near night, that they could not well do any thing without candles. They call'd for ome, and itting all about him, they deir'd him to read the titles of the twelve Comedies, which he aid were ready for the Stage. The counterfeit Author, who acted his part very pleaantly, took a Paper out of his Pocket, and read to them, as followeth.

list.head: A Catalogue of Plays written this preent year, by the Batchelour Dominico Joancho, a Bicayan Poet.
list.item: 7. Almonds for uch as have no Teeth.
9. Between two Stools the—comes to the ground.
11. The Good Thief on the Cros.

p.q: Thee, ays he, are the twelve Comedies I have already finih'd: I would not willingly have any of them repreented before the lat, becaue the Adventure is of my own Country, and it is a mot excellent Comedy, the contrivances of it are admirable, and I need give you no further commendation of it, than that it hath cot me abundance of oil and time, and that I bit my nails above a hundred times at the writing of it.

div.p:
The Comedians had much ado to keep their countenances, for they could hardly forbear laughing at extravagant Titles of the Comedies, and wih'd they had had more time to enjoy the converation of the Bicain Poet. He who had poken to him firt, giving him thanks in the name of the whole company; I am infinitely glad, Sir, aid he to him, that I have had the honour of coming to the knowledge of you, from your own elf, for till now, I mut, to my hame, acknowledge, that I had not o much as heard of your illutrious name: you will injure your elf extremely, if you do not make the Court of Spain enible of your excellent parts. I am therefore to intreat you, in the name of our whole Company, that you will be pleas'd to honour us with that Piece of yours, which you conceive mot likely to take, though we quetion not but your reputation is even beyond your own expreions of it. You know the cutom of Poets, when they are firt to appear on the Stage, which is, to preent it with the firt Piece gratis; for what we hall receive from you afterwards, you hall be atisfi'd according to our agreement, and it is poible, they may pleae o well, that we hall act onely yours, for one year at leat; and rather than we hall be behind-hand
with you, we hall not tick to borrow mony, though at ever o great interet. 'Tis now late, and upper-time calls us away, which ended, we hall have more leiure to dicoure further, if you pleae to give me and my Companions the meeting at my chamber. There we hope you will communicate to us your thoughts of that Comedy, which you hall be pleas'd to recommend to us. If you leave it to my choice, as it is fit you hould, repli'd he, the Seignores of Bicay hall be the firt I will read to you, for I have a confidence, by that, to raie my elf into the reputation of a good Author, and to acquire the eteem of this Court. He who was the Speaker of the Company, aid to him, Will you be pleas'd, Sir, to give me a little atisfaction as to the Title of that Comedy; you call it, The Seignores, whereby me-thinks it hould rather have been The Lady of Bicay, that being a more uual tearm. You are very much in the right, replies the feign'd Poet; but I do it purpoely, for the King entitles himelf onely Seignor of Bicay, and not Prince, Duke, Earl, or Marques: beides I have another reaon, why I do not call her Lady, but Seignores, which is, that it rhimes with Princes, and all other words of the like termination. To this I may adde, that the word is new, and you know the times are uch now, that all the world runs after Novelties, even to the very lowet ort of people, who expres a certain digut towards things common and trivial.

p.q: Your reaons are beyond all expectation, replies the Commedian, and therefore I hall not trouble you much with further demands.

No trouble at all, ays the counterfeit Poet, you oblige me, for though you your elf may be atisfi'd as to my worth, yet
ome others here preent may be glad of uch directions, as I onely am able to give them.

Your mot humble Servant, ays the Comedian, then for their better information who you conceive may want it, give me leave to tell you, that I am not atisfi'd as to the title of one of your Plays, I mean that which you call Noah's Ark, I cannot imagine how you can accommodate that Piece to the Theatre, nor who can be the Actors, for I ee but very few can be brought to peak in it.

I mut pardon your ignorance of my deign, replies the Poet, for if you knew it, you would admire the invention, which is wholly new. I bring in as Actors in that Piece all thoe Creatures that are taught to peak, as Parrats, Mag-pies, Jays, Starlings, Daws, and others, a thing never een before, and which, for its novelty, mut needs be admir'd.

div.p: They could hardly forbear laughing at his former dicoures, but this humour was o pleaant, that it was impoible to hold, which oblig'd the Author to ask them very eriouly what they laugh'd at. You ee, Sir, ays the Speaker, how likely this Novelty is to take with the people, ince it makes us o merry, out of a conceit, that we hall make a great advantage thereby. No doubt of it, ays the Poet. But no more, of the titles of my other Pieces, let us talk onely of that which I would have repreented firt. I hall hereafter, at more leiure, atisfie the difficulties you have to propoe concerning the other titles, whereof I hall give you the explication. It hall be o, aid he who had poken to him; to which purpoe, we hall deire your company at my houe anon after upper, where we hall all be ready to entertain you. Whereupon he took his leave, promiing he would not fail to be with them.

Having made this progres in his buines, he went and gave his Camerades an account thereof, and appointed them to wait about his houe where the mony was. He undertook to keep the Company in play, while they hould do their work, which they would not be long about, having all the implements requiite for men of their profeion. The Comedians, on the other ide, prepar'd all things to hew him uch a trick, as his extravagance deerv'd, getting ome quibs and crackers made, to frighten him, if 'twere poible, out of the little wit he had.

His hour being come, he went to his houe who had invited him, to read the Seignores. He who expected him had provided what he thought requiite to make port enough that night for the whole Company. The chief Comedian, eeing they were all met, told them that the Room was too narrow for the whole Company, and that they were better to appoint their meeting at the Theatre, where they hould not be diturb'd. The feign'd Poet was glad to hear the propoition, and econded it, inamuch as, the coat being clear, his Camerades might the more eaily dipatch their buines. It happen'd according to his wihes, for the Mitres of the houe, who had heard her husband and others of the Company talk of the extravagant Poet, and how they intended to erve him, would needs ee the port, and let it might be late ere they return'd home, he took all the ervants, both men and maids, along with her; o that the Garrion was clearly dimantled. They brought the Poet to the Theatre with a great deal of ceremony, and plac'd him at the end of a Table, on which there were two candles. Having taken the Comedy out of his pocket, and the Company ilently expecting, after
two or three grave Hems, he began to read thus.

div.head: THE SEIGNORESS OF BISCAY, A NEW COMEDY.
div.byline: Written by Dominico Joancho, Batchelor of Divinity, born at Ordugna in the Seignory of Bicay.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: GOZENEGO, Tom-Ladle, the Fool in the Play.

div.p: Hold a little, I pray, Sir, ays the principal Comedian, why do you give the Fool two names, would not one erve? No, Sir, ays the Poet; for the former is his name, as he is a Chritian, or his Chritian name, and the other he hath in relation to the part he acts. For as the Ladle tirs the meat which is in the Pot, o he is the peron which tumbles, and turns upide down the everal parts of the Plot, and huffles all the contrivances and intrigues of the Comedy. You hall find nothing but I can give you a very good reaon for it, and therefore you may pare your elf the trouble of raiing any further objections. Excellent! I am atisfi'd, Sir, ays the other, pray go on.

list.item: GRACE GELINDA, Seignores of Bicay, a name very pertinent to ignifie the Graces that are in her.
L'ORDOVY, an old Gentleman-Uher belonging to the Seignores.

div.p: Your patience, a little, Sir, ays the principal Comedian, is that Forge to peak any thing in the Play? No, Sir, ays the Poet; but there is a neceity of it in this Piece, in regard there is frequent mention made of it, as being the mot coniderable revenue of our Country, that is, of her Highnes the Seignores. Very well, very well, replies the other; but however put it not among the Actors. That's eaily mended, ays the Batchelor.

list.item: Item, THIRTEEN VESSELS, belonging to the Seignores.

div.p: How Thirteen! ays the Comedian, can they not be reduc'd to leer number? No, Sir, ays the Poet, becaue they repreent Thirteen of the mot eminent Families of Bicay, and every one, in the name of its whole Houe, hath a Voice in the General Aembly, to conent to the marriage of the Seignores; and if there were any one wanting, 'twould argue a certain contempt of an illutrious Family. I am very punctual and exact, as to what concerns the Hitory of Bicay, and I would not mis an atome of it. But it will be hard for us to repreent it, ays the Comedian, for we are not o many Actors in our whole Company. Take ome at hire out of ome other, replies the Poet, for upon uch an accompt as this is you mut pare for no cot. Have you any more Actors, ays the Comedian? Yes, replies the Poet.

list.item: SEVEN YOVNG MAIDS, between 15 and 20 years of age, who dance a Ball, before their Mitres, at her enrrance into Bicay.

div.p: Well, Sir, ays the Comedian, I have een many Comedies in my time, but never any that had uch extraordinary particulars as yours. How do you imagine I hould find even young Maids, epecially o near the Court? Sir, ays the Poet, no profit comes in without charge; but you need not be o crupulous, they will not be earch'd, to try, whether they really be uch or not, though 'twere more convenient they hould. Nay there is yet another expedient, which is, to have them in Perpective, or in Scenes, and artificially mov'd to dance the Ball; but to do well, they hould be alive. There you give us ome comfort, ays the Comedian, for we may make up that number out of our Company, if thoe will erve who appear not upon the Stage: but I hall not undertake they will be uch as you would have them. Now, Sir, if you pleae, let's have a little of your way in carrying on the deign of this Piece.

In the firt Scene, aid he, comes out Don Ochoa, Sutor to the Seignores, and Gozenego, Tom-Ladle, his man, in country cloaths, with each of them a good thick riding hood, or Capouche, and an Indian Umbrello. How, ays the Comedian, what need is there of the Paraol, or Umbrello, if they have Capouches? I ee, ays the Poet, you are not much acquainted with the temperature of the climate of Bicay. In ummer, Sir, there are uch furious deluges of waters, as if the sky were broken to pieces; preently after, there comes uch a corching Sun, as will et a man's brains a boiling in
his head. I cannot diprove you, ays the Comedian; pray go on.

He then began to read the veres, but after uch a ridiculous and extravagant manner, that when he had gone over about an hundred of them, the Players perceiving that the Piece contain'd many heets, cloe written, and tir'd with the impertinence of what they had already heard, and withall that they had pent mot part of the night o trivially, interrupted the Reciter with a kind of a buzzing noie. That was the Cue which the feign'd Batchelor expected, yet eeming to be angry at it, he clapp'd both hands on the Table with uch violence, that he hook the two Candleticks, and cri'd out with a loud voice, Tacete, Tacete. But the Players and others that were preent, not undertanding the Latine, the noie increas'd, the table was over-turn'd, and the Candles were put out, and then all retiring from him, they et fire to the train they had laid for the poor Poet. He found himelf encompas'd by a number of quibs and crackers, and long bags full of and like nakes, all in open hotility againt him. He was in a very ad pickle, for there was nothing but confuion on the Theatre, beides the flames of roin which came up from beneath the Stage, and were ready to choke him, inomuch that to cure him of all future thoughts of Poetry, there needed onely a gentle toing in a blanket. He eem'd to take it very unkindly, that he had been brought thither, to receive uch an affront, for beides the danger his tinder Cloak and Caock had been in of a general conflagration, he lot the Comedy, than whichthere could not a greater los happen to him. The Epilogue of the Piece was, that Jaimo's companions, while the Company was thus
entertain'd at the Theatre, had found a way into the Comedian's houe, and plaid the Ferrets in all the rooms, and examin'd the chets and trunks that tood in their way, in one whereof they found the mony they look'd for, which they cleaverly carried to Jaimo's houe, where it was very fairly divided; and in regard Jaimo's wife had been the inventres of the Plot, he had an equal hare with thoe who had been emploi'd in the execution of it.

The next day, the Comedian going to take up certain tuffs for cloaths, was not a little atonih'd to find the chet open, and the mony fled. He was for a while at uch a los, that he knew not where he was. At lat, he ask'd his wife who had been in the houe? whereto he could give him no account at all. He ent people to abroad to earch, and acquainted the Magitrate with what had happen'd. The nearet treets to the houe were viited, but to no purpoe. The poor Comedian went to relate his misfortune to the Grandee, of whom he had receiv'd that preent. But he thinking it a cheat of the Comedians, would not believe him. He fell ick out of pure dicontent, and kept his bed, and then began to doubt it was a trick put upon him by that feign'd Poet, for whom he immediately caus'd a earch to be made; but he could never be found, for he and his Companions had taken a coure for that. Thee things being repreented to the Lord, who had betow'd the mony on them, he was o generous as to upply them with the like um.

In the mean time, the Officers were till upon duty, to ee, whether, earching for the Poet, they hould meet with the Author of the Robbery. The indipos'd Comedian recover'd upon the ight of the
Mony's return into the chet. Jaimo and his Companions had a conultation how they might trapan the Comedian of that recrute, but when it was propos'd to Rufina, who had always a voice in the Conclave, 'twas immediately quah'd, and he prevail'd with her Husband to leave Madrid, ince they had mony enough to retire ele-where, and drive ome trade therewith. Jaimo took her advice, and o leaving Madrid, they went into Arragon, and planted themelves at Saragoa, the Metropolis of that Kingdom. They took a Houe, and kept a Silk-hop, pending ome time in that employment. What deigns they were engag'd in during their abode their, and upon what account they were forc'd to remove thence hall be the ubject of a Second Part of this work; wherein the Reader hall find Rufina, improv'd in ubtilty by experience, contriving and compaing cheats much more pleaant and more ingenious, than any he hath been hitherto concern'd in, with a little aitance from her Husband Don Jaimo.
